911µsrequire 5.008_001;
10
11BEGIN {
1212µs$DBI::VERSION = "1.616"; # ==> ALSO update the version in the pod text below!
13150µs}
14
15=head1 NAME
16
17DBI - Database independent interface for Perl
18
19=head1 SYNOPSIS
20
21 use DBI;
22
23 @driver_names = DBI->available_drivers;
24 %drivers = DBI->installed_drivers;
25 @data_sources = DBI->data_sources($driver_name, \%attr);
26
27 $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $username, $auth, \%attr);
28
29 $rv = $dbh->do($statement);
30 $rv = $dbh->do($statement, \%attr);
31 $rv = $dbh->do($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
32
33 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectall_arrayref($statement);
34 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectall_hashref($statement, $key_field);
35
36 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref($statement);
37 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref($statement, \%attr);
38
39 @row_ary = $dbh->selectrow_array($statement);
40 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectrow_arrayref($statement);
41 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectrow_hashref($statement);
42
43 $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement);
44 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached($statement);
45
46 $rc = $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value);
47 $rc = $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value, $bind_type);
48 $rc = $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value, \%attr);
49
50 $rv = $sth->execute;
51 $rv = $sth->execute(@bind_values);
52 $rv = $sth->execute_array(\%attr, ...);
53
54 $rc = $sth->bind_col($col_num, \$col_variable);
55 $rc = $sth->bind_columns(@list_of_refs_to_vars_to_bind);
56
57 @row_ary = $sth->fetchrow_array;
58 $ary_ref = $sth->fetchrow_arrayref;
59 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchrow_hashref;
60
61 $ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref;
62 $ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref( $slice, $max_rows );
63
64 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchall_hashref( $key_field );
65
66 $rv = $sth->rows;
67
68 $rc = $dbh->begin_work;
69 $rc = $dbh->commit;
70 $rc = $dbh->rollback;
71
72 $quoted_string = $dbh->quote($string);
73
74 $rc = $h->err;
75 $str = $h->errstr;
76 $rv = $h->state;
77
78 $rc = $dbh->disconnect;
79
80I<The synopsis above only lists the major methods and parameters.>
81
82
83=head2 GETTING HELP
84
85If you have questions about DBI, or DBD driver modules, you can get
86help from the I<dbi-users@perl.org> mailing list. You don't have to subscribe
87to the list in order to post, though I'd recommend it. You can get help on
88subscribing and using the list by emailing I<dbi-users-help@perl.org>.
89
90I don't recommend the DBI cpanforum (at http://www.cpanforum.com/dist/DBI)
91because relatively few people read it compared with dbi-users@perl.org.
92
93To help you make the best use of the dbi-users mailing list,
94and any other lists or forums you may use, I I<strongly>
95recommend that you read "How To Ask Questions The Smart Way"
96by Eric Raymond: L<http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html>.
97
98If you think you've found a bug then please also read
99"How to Report Bugs Effectively" by Simon Tatham:
100L<http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/bugs.html>.
101
102The DBI home page at L<http://dbi.perl.org/> and the DBI FAQ
103at L<http://faq.dbi-support.com/> are always worth a visit.
104They include links to other resources.
105
106Before asking any questions, reread this document, consult the
107archives and read the DBI FAQ. The archives are listed
108at the end of this document and on the DBI home page.
109
110You might also like to read the Advanced DBI Tutorial at
111L<http://www.slideshare.net/Tim.Bunce/dbi-advanced-tutorial-2007>
112
113This document often uses terms like I<references>, I<objects>,
114I<methods>. If you're not familiar with those terms then it would
115be a good idea to read at least the following perl manuals first:
116L<perlreftut>, L<perldsc>, L<perllol>, and L<perlboot>.
117
118Please note that Tim Bunce does not maintain the mailing lists or the
119web page (generous volunteers do that). So please don't send mail
120directly to him; he just doesn't have the time to answer questions
121personally. The I<dbi-users> mailing list has lots of experienced
122people who should be able to help you if you need it. If you do email
123Tim he is very likely to just forward it to the mailing list.
124
125=head2 NOTES
126
127This is the DBI specification that corresponds to the DBI version 1.616
128($Revision: 14568 $).
129
130The DBI is evolving at a steady pace, so it's good to check that
131you have the latest copy.
132
133The significant user-visible changes in each release are documented
134in the L<DBI::Changes> module so you can read them by executing
135C<perldoc DBI::Changes>.
136
137Some DBI changes require changes in the drivers, but the drivers
138can take some time to catch up. Newer versions of the DBI have
139added features that may not yet be supported by the drivers you
140use. Talk to the authors of your drivers if you need a new feature
141that is not yet supported.
142
143Features added after DBI 1.21 (February 2002) are marked in the
144text with the version number of the DBI release they first appeared in.
145
146Extensions to the DBI API often use the C<DBIx::*> namespace.
147See L</Naming Conventions and Name Space>. DBI extension modules
148can be found at L<http://search.cpan.org/search?mode=module&query=DBIx>.
149And all modules related to the DBI can be found at
150L<http://search.cpan.org/search?query=DBI&mode=all>.
151
152=cut
153
154# The POD text continues at the end of the file.
155
156

252# If you get an error here like "Can't find loadable object ..."
253# then you haven't installed the DBI correctly. Read the README
254# then install it again.
25513µsif ( $ENV{DBI_PUREPERL} ) {
256 eval { bootstrap DBI } if $ENV{DBI_PUREPERL} == 1;
257 require DBI::PurePerl if $@ or $ENV{DBI_PUREPERL} >= 2;
258 $DBI::PurePerl ||= 0; # just to silence "only used once" warnings

29612µs%DBI::installed_drh = (); # maps driver names to installed driver handles
297sub installed_drivers { %DBI::installed_drh }
29811µs%DBI::installed_methods = (); # XXX undocumented, may change
299sub installed_methods { %DBI::installed_methods }
300
301# Setup special DBI dynamic variables. See DBI::var::FETCH for details.
302# These are dynamically associated with the last handle used.
30316µstie $DBI::err, 'DBI::var', '*err'; # special case: referenced via IHA list
30413µstie $DBI::state, 'DBI::var', '"state'; # special case: referenced via IHA list
30513µstie $DBI::lasth, 'DBI::var', '!lasth'; # special case: return boolean
30613µstie $DBI::errstr, 'DBI::var', '&errstr'; # call &errstr in last used pkg
30713µstie $DBI::rows, 'DBI::var', '&rows'; # call &rows in last used pkg
3081021µssub DBI::var::TIESCALAR{ my $var = $_[1]; bless \$var, 'DBI::var'; }
309sub DBI::var::STORE { Carp::croak("Can't modify \$DBI::${$_[0]} special variable") }

311{ # used to catch DBI->{Attrib} mistake
312215µs sub DBI::DBI_tie::TIEHASH { bless {} }
313 sub DBI::DBI_tie::STORE { Carp::carp("DBI->{$_[1]} is invalid syntax (you probably want \$h->{$_[1]})");}
31412µs *DBI::DBI_tie::FETCH = \&DBI::DBI_tie::STORE;
315}

372my %dbd_class_registry = map { $dbd_prefix_registry->{$_}->{class} => { prefix => $_ } }

376sub dump_dbd_registry {
377 require Data::Dumper;
378 local $Data::Dumper::Sortkeys=1;
379 local $Data::Dumper::Indent=1;
380 print Data::Dumper->Dump([$dbd_prefix_registry], [qw($dbd_prefix_registry)]);
381}

388
389 common => { # Interface methods common to all DBI handle classes
390 'DESTROY' => { O=>0x004|0x10000 },
391 'CLEAR' => $keeperr,
392 'EXISTS' => $keeperr,
393 'FETCH' => { O=>0x0404 },
394 'FETCH_many' => { O=>0x0404 },

396 'NEXTKEY' => $keeperr,

398 _not_impl => undef,
399 can => { O=>0x0100 }, # special case, see dispatch
400 debug => { U =>[1,2,'[$debug_level]'], O=>0x0004 }, # old name for trace
401 dump_handle => { U =>[1,3,'[$message [, $level]]'], O=>0x0004 },

528sub CLONE {
529 my $olddbis = $DBI::_dbistate;
530 _clone_dbis() unless $DBI::PurePerl; # clone the DBIS structure
531 DBI->trace_msg(sprintf "CLONE DBI for new thread %s\n",
532 $DBI::PurePerl ? "" : sprintf("(dbis %x -> %x)",$olddbis, $DBI::_dbistate));
533 while ( my ($driver, $drh) = each %DBI::installed_drh) {
5343934µs111µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 11µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
535 next if defined &{"DBD::${driver}::CLONE"};
536 warn("$driver has no driver CLONE() function so is unsafe threaded\n");
537 }
538 %DBI::installed_drh = (); # clear loaded drivers so they have a chance to reinitialize
539}
540
541sub parse_dsn {
542 my ($class, $dsn) = @_;
543 $dsn =~ s/^(dbi):(\w*?)(?:\((.*?)\))?://i or return;
544 my ($scheme, $driver, $attr, $attr_hash) = (lc($1), $2, $3);
545 $driver ||= $ENV{DBI_DRIVER} || '';
546 $attr_hash = { split /\s*=>?\s*|\s*,\s*/, $attr, -1 } if $attr;
547 return ($scheme, $driver, $attr, $attr_hash, $dsn);
548}
549
550sub visit_handles {
551 my ($class, $code, $outer_info) = @_;
552 $outer_info = {} if not defined $outer_info;
553 my %drh = DBI->installed_drivers;
554 for my $h (values %drh) {
555 my $child_info = $code->($h, $outer_info)
556 or next;
557 $h->visit_child_handles($code, $child_info);
558 }
559 return $outer_info;
560}
561
562

sub connect_cached {

574 };

sub connect {
5794084µs my $class = shift;
58040266µs my ($dsn, $user, $pass, $attr, $old_driver) = my @orig_args = @_;
5814054µs my $driver;
582
58340112µs if ($attr and !ref($attr)) { # switch $old_driver<->$attr if called in old style
584 Carp::carp("DBI->connect using 'old-style' syntax is deprecated and will be an error in future versions");
585 ($old_driver, $attr) = ($attr, $old_driver);
586 }
587
5884097µs my $connect_meth = $attr->{dbi_connect_method};
5894053µs $connect_meth ||= $DBI::connect_via; # fallback to default
590
5914072µs $dsn ||= $ENV{DBI_DSN} || $ENV{DBI_DBNAME} || '' unless $old_driver;
592
5934069µs if ($DBI::dbi_debug) {

595 pop @_ if $connect_meth ne 'connect';
596 my @args = @_; $args[2] = '****'; # hide password
597 DBI->trace_msg(" -> $class->$connect_meth(".join(", ",@args).")\n");
598 }
5994091µs Carp::croak('Usage: $class->connect([$dsn [,$user [,$passwd [,\%attr]]]])')
600 if (ref $old_driver or ($attr and not ref $attr) or ref $pass);
601
602 # extract dbi:driver prefix from $dsn into $1
60340768µs40486µs $dsn =~ s/^dbi:(\w*?)(?:\((.*?)\))?://i
# spent 486µs making 40 calls to DBI::CORE:subst, avg 12µs/call
604 or '' =~ /()/; # ensure $1 etc are empty if match fails
60540190µs my $driver_attrib_spec = $2 || '';
606
607 # Set $driver. Old style driver, if specified, overrides new dsn style.
60840141µs $driver = $old_driver || $1 || $ENV{DBI_DRIVER}
609 or Carp::croak("Can't connect to data source '$dsn' "
610 ."because I can't work out what driver to use "
611 ."(it doesn't seem to contain a 'dbi:driver:' prefix "
612 ."and the DBI_DRIVER env var is not set)");
613
6144050µs my $proxy;
61540111µs if ($ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY} && $driver ne 'Proxy' && $driver ne 'Sponge' && $driver ne 'Switch') {
616 my $dbi_autoproxy = $ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY};
617 $proxy = 'Proxy';
618 if ($dbi_autoproxy =~ s/^dbi:(\w*?)(?:\((.*?)\))?://i) {
619 $proxy = $1;
620 $driver_attrib_spec = join ",",
621 ($driver_attrib_spec) ? $driver_attrib_spec : (),
622 ($2 ) ? $2 : ();
623 }
624 $dsn = "$dbi_autoproxy;dsn=dbi:$driver:$dsn";
625 $driver = $proxy;
626 DBI->trace_msg(" DBI_AUTOPROXY: dbi:$driver($driver_attrib_spec):$dsn\n");
627 }
628 # avoid recursion if proxy calls DBI->connect itself
6294080µs local $ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY} if $ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY};
630
6314062µs my %attributes; # take a copy we can delete from
63240201µs if ($old_driver) {
633 %attributes = %$attr if $attr;
634 }
635 else { # new-style connect so new default semantics
63640708µs %attributes = (
637 PrintError => 1,
638 AutoCommit => 1,
639 ref $attr ? %$attr : (),
640 # attributes in DSN take precedence over \%attr connect parameter
641 $driver_attrib_spec ? (split /\s*=>?\s*|\s*,\s*/, $driver_attrib_spec, -1) : (),
642 );
643 }
64440106µs $attr = \%attributes; # now set $attr to refer to our local copy
645
64640131µs113.3ms my $drh = $DBI::installed_drh{$driver} || $class->install_driver($driver)

647 or die "panic: $class->install_driver($driver) failed";
648

6504094µs $user = $attr->{Username} if defined $attr->{Username};
6514063µs $pass = $attr->{Password} if defined $attr->{Password};
65240100µs delete $attr->{Password}; # always delete Password as closure stores it securely
6534074µs if ( !(defined $user && defined $pass) ) {
654 ($user, $pass) = $drh->default_user($user, $pass, $attr);
655 }
65640156µs $attr->{Username} = $user; # force the Username to be the actual one used

# spent 37.0ms (8.41+28.6) within DBI::__ANON__[extlib/lib/perl5/x86_64-linux-thread-multi/DBI.pm:732] which was called 40 times, avg 926µs/call: # 40 times (8.41ms+28.6ms) by DBI::connect at line 734, avg 926µs/call
my $connect_closure = sub {
6594083µs my ($old_dbh, $override_attr) = @_;
660
661 #use Data::Dumper;
662 #warn "connect_closure: ".Data::Dumper::Dumper([$attr,\%attributes, $override_attr]);
663
6644048µs my $dbh;
665401.04ms4018.0ms unless ($dbh = $drh->$connect_meth($dsn, $user, $pass, $attr)) {
# spent 18.0ms making 40 calls to DBI::dr::connect_cached, avg 451µs/call
666 $user = '' if !defined $user;
667 $dsn = '' if !defined $dsn;
668 # $drh->errstr isn't safe here because $dbh->DESTROY may not have
669 # been called yet and so the dbh errstr would not have been copied
670 # up to the drh errstr. Certainly true for connect_cached!
671 my $errstr = $DBI::errstr;
672 # Getting '(no error string)' here is a symptom of a ref loop
673 $errstr = '(no error string)' if !defined $errstr;
674 my $msg = "$class connect('$dsn','$user',...) failed: $errstr";
675 DBI->trace_msg(" $msg\n");
676 # XXX HandleWarn
677 unless ($attr->{HandleError} && $attr->{HandleError}->($msg, $drh, $dbh)) {
678 Carp::croak($msg) if $attr->{RaiseError};
679 Carp::carp ($msg) if $attr->{PrintError};
680 }
681 $! = 0; # for the daft people who do DBI->connect(...) || die "$!";
682 return $dbh; # normally undef, but HandleError could change it
683 }
684
685 # merge any attribute overrides but don't change $attr itself (for closure)
68640648µs my $apply = { ($override_attr) ? (%$attr, %$override_attr ) : %$attr };
687
688 # handle basic RootClass subclassing:
68940163µs my $rebless_class = $apply->{RootClass} || ($class ne 'DBI' ? $class : '');
6904053µs if ($rebless_class) {
6913703µs111µs no strict 'refs';

693 delete $apply->{RootClass};
694 DBI::_load_class($rebless_class, 0);
695 }
696 unless (@{"$rebless_class\::db::ISA"} && @{"$rebless_class\::st::ISA"}) {
697 Carp::carp("DBI subclasses '$rebless_class\::db' and ::st are not setup, RootClass ignored");
698 $rebless_class = undef;
699 $class = 'DBI';
700 }
701 else {
702 $dbh->{RootClass} = $rebless_class; # $dbh->STORE called via plain DBI::db
703 DBI::_set_isa([$rebless_class], 'DBI'); # sets up both '::db' and '::st'
704 DBI::_rebless($dbh, $rebless_class); # appends '::db'
705 }
706 }
707
70840288µs if (%$apply) {

# spent 13.3ms (8.98+4.32) within DBI::install_driver which was called: # once (8.98ms+4.32ms) by DBI::connect at line 646
sub install_driver { # croaks on failure
75611µs my $class = shift;
75712µs my($driver, $attr) = @_;
75811µs my $drh;
759
76011µs $driver ||= $ENV{DBI_DRIVER} || '';
761
762 # allow driver to be specified as a 'dbi:driver:' string
76317µs11µs $driver = $1 if $driver =~ s/^DBI:(.*?)://i;
# spent 1µs making 1 call to DBI::CORE:subst
764
76512µs Carp::croak("usage: $class->install_driver(\$driver [, \%attr])")
766 unless ($driver and @_<=3);
767
768 # already installed
76912µs return $drh if $drh = $DBI::installed_drh{$driver};
770
77111µs $class->trace_msg(" -> $class->install_driver($driver"
772 .") for $^O perl=$] pid=$$ ruid=$< euid=$>\n")
773 if $DBI::dbi_debug;
774
775 # --- load the code
77612µs my $driver_class = "DBD::$driver";
777130µs eval qq{package # hide from PAUSE
# spent 88µs executing statements in string eval
778 DBI::_firesafe; # just in case
779 require $driver_class; # load the driver
780 };
78112µs if ($@) {
782 my $err = $@;
783 my $advice = "";
784 if ($err =~ /Can't find loadable object/) {
785 $advice = "Perhaps DBD::$driver was statically linked into a new perl binary."
786 ."\nIn which case you need to use that new perl binary."
787 ."\nOr perhaps only the .pm file was installed but not the shared object file."
788 }
789 elsif ($err =~ /Can't locate.*?DBD\/$driver\.pm in \@INC/) {
790 my @drv = $class->available_drivers(1);
791 $advice = "Perhaps the DBD::$driver perl module hasn't been fully installed,\n"
792 ."or perhaps the capitalisation of '$driver' isn't right.\n"
793 ."Available drivers: ".join(", ", @drv).".";
794 }
795 elsif ($err =~ /Can't load .*? for module DBD::/) {
796 $advice = "Perhaps a required shared library or dll isn't installed where expected";
797 }
798 elsif ($err =~ /Can't locate .*? in \@INC/) {
799 $advice = "Perhaps a module that DBD::$driver requires hasn't been fully installed";
800 }
801 Carp::croak("install_driver($driver) failed: $err$advice\n");
802 }
80311µs if ($DBI::dbi_debug) {
8043301µs111µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 11µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
805 (my $driver_file = $driver_class) =~ s/::/\//g;
806 my $dbd_ver = ${"$driver_class\::VERSION"} || "undef";
807 $class->trace_msg(" install_driver: $driver_class version $dbd_ver"
808 ." loaded from $INC{qq($driver_file.pm)}\n");
809 }
810
811 # --- do some behind-the-scenes checks and setups on the driver
81218µs185µs $class->setup_driver($driver_class);
# spent 85µs making 1 call to DBI::setup_driver
813
814 # --- run the driver function
81528µs1389µs $drh = eval { $driver_class->driver($attr || {}) };
# spent 389µs making 1 call to DBD::mysql::driver
81613µs unless ($drh && ref $drh && !$@) {
817 my $advice = "";
818 $@ ||= "$driver_class->driver didn't return a handle";
819 # catch people on case in-sensitive systems using the wrong case
820 $advice = "\nPerhaps the capitalisation of DBD '$driver' isn't right."
821 if $@ =~ /locate object method/;
822 Carp::croak("$driver_class initialisation failed: $@$advice");
823 }
824
82512µs $DBI::installed_drh{$driver} = $drh;
82611µs $class->trace_msg(" <- install_driver= $drh\n") if $DBI::dbi_debug;
82715µs $drh;
828}

83012µs*driver = \&install_driver; # currently an alias, may change

833
# spent 181µs (144+37) within DBI::setup_driver which was called 2 times, avg 90µs/call: # once (79µs+17µs) by Isucon::BEGIN at line 1298 # once (65µs+20µs) by DBI::install_driver at line 812
sub setup_driver {
83423µs my ($class, $driver_class) = @_;
83522µs my $type;
836214µs foreach $type (qw(dr db st)){
837610µs my $class = $driver_class."::$type";
8383243µs110µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 10µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
839672µs620µs push @{"${class}::ISA"}, "DBD::_::$type"
# spent 20µs making 6 calls to UNIVERSAL::isa, avg 3µs/call
840 unless UNIVERSAL::isa($class, "DBD::_::$type");
84169µs my $mem_class = "DBD::_mem::$type";
842674µs617µs push @{"${class}_mem::ISA"}, $mem_class
# spent 17µs making 6 calls to UNIVERSAL::isa, avg 3µs/call
843 unless UNIVERSAL::isa("${class}_mem", $mem_class)
844 or $DBI::PurePerl;
845 }
846}

848
849sub _rebless {
850 my $dbh = shift;
851 my ($outer, $inner) = DBI::_handles($dbh);
852 my $class = shift(@_).'::db';
853 bless $inner => $class;
854 bless $outer => $class; # outer last for return
855}
856
857
858sub _set_isa {
859 my ($classes, $topclass) = @_;
860 my $trace = DBI->trace_msg(" _set_isa([@$classes])\n");
861 foreach my $suffix ('::db','::st') {
862 my $previous = $topclass || 'DBI'; # trees are rooted here
863 foreach my $class (@$classes) {
864 my $base_class = $previous.$suffix;
865 my $sub_class = $class.$suffix;
866 my $sub_class_isa = "${sub_class}::ISA";
8673557µs110µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 10µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
868 if (@$sub_class_isa) {
869 DBI->trace_msg(" $sub_class_isa skipped (already set to @$sub_class_isa)\n")
870 if $trace;
871 }
872 else {
873 @$sub_class_isa = ($base_class) unless @$sub_class_isa;
874 DBI->trace_msg(" $sub_class_isa = $base_class\n")
875 if $trace;
876 }
877 $previous = $class;
878 }
879 }
880}
881
882
883sub _rebless_dbtype_subclass {
884 my ($dbh, $rootclass, $DbTypeSubclass) = @_;
885 # determine the db type names for class hierarchy
886 my @hierarchy = DBI::_dbtype_names($dbh, $DbTypeSubclass);
887 # add the rootclass prefix to each ('DBI::' or 'MyDBI::' etc)
888 $_ = $rootclass.'::'.$_ foreach (@hierarchy);
889 # load the modules from the 'top down'
890 DBI::_load_class($_, 1) foreach (reverse @hierarchy);
891 # setup class hierarchy if needed, does both '::db' and '::st'
892 DBI::_set_isa(\@hierarchy, $rootclass);
893 # finally bless the handle into the subclass
894 DBI::_rebless($dbh, $hierarchy[0]);
895}
896
897
898sub _dbtype_names { # list dbtypes for hierarchy, ie Informix=>ADO=>ODBC
899 my ($dbh, $DbTypeSubclass) = @_;
900
901 if ($DbTypeSubclass && $DbTypeSubclass ne '1' && ref $DbTypeSubclass ne 'CODE') {
902 # treat $DbTypeSubclass as a comma separated list of names
903 my @dbtypes = split /\s*,\s*/, $DbTypeSubclass;
904 $dbh->trace_msg(" DbTypeSubclass($DbTypeSubclass)=@dbtypes (explicit)\n");
905 return @dbtypes;
906 }
907
908 # XXX will call $dbh->get_info(17) (=SQL_DBMS_NAME) in future?
909
910 my $driver = $dbh->{Driver}->{Name};
911 if ( $driver eq 'Proxy' ) {
912 # XXX Looking into the internals of DBD::Proxy is questionable!
913 ($driver) = $dbh->{proxy_client}->{application} =~ /^DBI:(.+?):/i
914 or die "Can't determine driver name from proxy";
915 }
916
917 my @dbtypes = (ucfirst($driver));
918 if ($driver eq 'ODBC' || $driver eq 'ADO') {
919 # XXX will move these out and make extensible later:
920 my $_dbtype_name_regexp = 'Oracle'; # eg 'Oracle|Foo|Bar'
921 my %_dbtype_name_map = (
922 'Microsoft SQL Server' => 'MSSQL',
923 'SQL Server' => 'Sybase',
924 'Adaptive Server Anywhere' => 'ASAny',
925 'ADABAS D' => 'AdabasD',
926 );
927
928 my $name;
929 $name = $dbh->func(17, 'GetInfo') # SQL_DBMS_NAME
930 if $driver eq 'ODBC';
931 $name = $dbh->{ado_conn}->Properties->Item('DBMS Name')->Value
932 if $driver eq 'ADO';
933 die "Can't determine driver name! ($DBI::errstr)\n"
934 unless $name;
935
936 my $dbtype;
937 if ($_dbtype_name_map{$name}) {
938 $dbtype = $_dbtype_name_map{$name};
939 }
940 else {
941 if ($name =~ /($_dbtype_name_regexp)/) {
942 $dbtype = lc($1);
943 }
944 else { # generic mangling for other names:
945 $dbtype = lc($name);
946 }
947 $dbtype =~ s/\b(\w)/\U$1/g;
948 $dbtype =~ s/\W+/_/g;
949 }
950 # add ODBC 'behind' ADO
951 push @dbtypes, 'ODBC' if $driver eq 'ADO';
952 # add discovered dbtype in front of ADO/ODBC
953 unshift @dbtypes, $dbtype;
954 }
955 @dbtypes = &$DbTypeSubclass($dbh, \@dbtypes)
956 if (ref $DbTypeSubclass eq 'CODE');
957 $dbh->trace_msg(" DbTypeSubclass($DbTypeSubclass)=@dbtypes\n");
958 return @dbtypes;
959}
960
961sub _load_class {
962 my ($load_class, $missing_ok) = @_;
963 DBI->trace_msg(" _load_class($load_class, $missing_ok)\n", 2);
9643551µs110µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 10µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
965 return 1 if @{"$load_class\::ISA"}; # already loaded/exists
966 (my $module = $load_class) =~ s!::!/!g;
967 DBI->trace_msg(" _load_class require $module\n", 2);
968 eval { require "$module.pm"; };
969 return 1 unless $@;
970 return 0 if $missing_ok && $@ =~ /^Can't locate \Q$module.pm\E/;
971 die $@;
972}

976 return 1;

982sub driver_prefix {
983 my ($class, $driver) = @_;
984 return $dbd_class_registry{$driver}->{prefix} if exists $dbd_class_registry{$driver};
985 return;
986}
987
988sub available_drivers {
989 my($quiet) = @_;
990 my(@drivers, $d, $f);
991 local(*DBI::DIR, $@);
992 my(%seen_dir, %seen_dbd);
993 my $haveFileSpec = eval { require File::Spec };
994 foreach $d (@INC){
995 chomp($d); # Perl 5 beta 3 bug in #!./perl -Ilib from Test::Harness
996 my $dbd_dir =
997 ($haveFileSpec ? File::Spec->catdir($d, 'DBD') : "$d/DBD");
998 next unless -d $dbd_dir;
999 next if $seen_dir{$d};
1000 $seen_dir{$d} = 1;
1001 # XXX we have a problem here with case insensitive file systems
1002 # XXX since we can't tell what case must be used when loading.
1003 opendir(DBI::DIR, $dbd_dir) || Carp::carp "opendir $dbd_dir: $!\n";
1004 foreach $f (readdir(DBI::DIR)){
1005 next unless $f =~ s/\.pm$//;
1006 next if $f eq 'NullP';
1007 if ($seen_dbd{$f}){
1008 Carp::carp "DBD::$f in $d is hidden by DBD::$f in $seen_dbd{$f}\n"
1009 unless $quiet;
1010 } else {
1011 push(@drivers, $f);
1012 }
1013 $seen_dbd{$f} = $d;
1014 }
1015 closedir(DBI::DIR);
1016 }
1017
1018 # "return sort @drivers" will not DWIM in scalar context.
1019 return wantarray ? sort @drivers : @drivers;
1020}
1021
1022sub installed_versions {
1023 my ($class, $quiet) = @_;
1024 my %error;
1025 my %version = ( DBI => $DBI::VERSION );
1026 $version{"DBI::PurePerl"} = $DBI::PurePerl::VERSION
1027 if $DBI::PurePerl;
1028 for my $driver ($class->available_drivers($quiet)) {
1029 next if $DBI::PurePerl && grep { -d "$_/auto/DBD/$driver" } @INC;
1030 my $drh = eval {
1031 local $SIG{__WARN__} = sub {};
1032 $class->install_driver($driver);
1033 };
1034 ($error{"DBD::$driver"}=$@),next if $@;
103531.88ms111µs no strict 'refs';
# spent 11µs making 1 call to strict::unimport
1036 my $vers = ${"DBD::$driver" . '::VERSION'};
1037 $version{"DBD::$driver"} = $vers || '?';
1038 }
1039 if (wantarray) {
1040 return map { m/^DBD::(\w+)/ ? ($1) : () } sort keys %version;
1041 }
1042 if (!defined wantarray) { # void context
1043 require Config; # add more detail
1044 $version{OS} = "$^O\t($Config::Config{osvers})";
1045 $version{Perl} = "$]\t($Config::Config{archname})";
1046 $version{$_} = (($error{$_} =~ s/ \(\@INC.*//s),$error{$_})
1047 for keys %error;
1048 printf " %-16s: %s\n",$_,$version{$_}
1049 for reverse sort keys %version;
1050 }
1051 return \%version;
1052}

1055sub data_sources {
1056 my ($class, $driver, @other) = @_;
1057 my $drh = $class->install_driver($driver);
1058 my @ds = $drh->data_sources(@other);
1059 return @ds;
1060}

1062
1063sub neat_list {
1064 my ($listref, $maxlen, $sep) = @_;
1065 $maxlen = 0 unless defined $maxlen; # 0 == use internal default
1066 $sep = ", " unless defined $sep;
1067 join($sep, map { neat($_,$maxlen) } @$listref);
1068}
1069
1070
1071sub dump_results { # also aliased as a method in DBD::_::st
1072 my ($sth, $maxlen, $lsep, $fsep, $fh) = @_;
1073 return 0 unless $sth;
1074 $maxlen ||= 35;
1075 $lsep ||= "\n";
1076 $fh ||= \*STDOUT;
1077 my $rows = 0;
1078 my $ref;
1079 while($ref = $sth->fetch) {
1080 print $fh $lsep if $rows++ and $lsep;
1081 my $str = neat_list($ref,$maxlen,$fsep);
1082 print $fh $str; # done on two lines to avoid 5.003 errors
1083 }
1084 print $fh "\n$rows rows".($DBI::err ? " ($DBI::err: $DBI::errstr)" : "")."\n";
1085 $rows;
1086}

1088
1089sub data_diff {
1090 my ($a, $b, $logical) = @_;
1091
1092 my $diff = data_string_diff($a, $b);
1093 return "" if $logical and !$diff;
1094
1095 my $a_desc = data_string_desc($a);
1096 my $b_desc = data_string_desc($b);
1097 return "" if !$diff and $a_desc eq $b_desc;
1098
1099 $diff ||= "Strings contain the same sequence of characters"
1100 if length($a);
1101 $diff .= "\n" if $diff;
1102 return "a: $a_desc\nb: $b_desc\n$diff";
1103}
1104
1105
1106sub data_string_diff {
1107 # Compares 'logical' characters, not bytes, so a latin1 string and an
1108 # an equivalent Unicode string will compare as equal even though their
1109 # byte encodings are different.
1110 my ($a, $b) = @_;
1111 unless (defined $a and defined $b) { # one undef
1112 return ""
1113 if !defined $a and !defined $b;
1114 return "String a is undef, string b has ".length($b)." characters"
1115 if !defined $a;
1116 return "String b is undef, string a has ".length($a)." characters"
1117 if !defined $b;
1118 }
1119
1120 require utf8;
1121 # hack to cater for perl 5.6
1122 *utf8::is_utf8 = sub { (DBI::neat(shift)=~/^"/) } unless defined &utf8::is_utf8;
1123
1124 my @a_chars = (utf8::is_utf8($a)) ? unpack("U*", $a) : unpack("C*", $a);
1125 my @b_chars = (utf8::is_utf8($b)) ? unpack("U*", $b) : unpack("C*", $b);
1126 my $i = 0;
1127 while (@a_chars && @b_chars) {
1128 ++$i, shift(@a_chars), shift(@b_chars), next
1129 if $a_chars[0] == $b_chars[0];# compare ordinal values
1130 my @desc = map {
1131 $_ > 255 ? # if wide character...
1132 sprintf("\\x{%04X}", $_) : # \x{...}
1133 chr($_) =~ /[[:cntrl:]]/ ? # else if control character ...
1134 sprintf("\\x%02X", $_) : # \x..
1135 chr($_) # else as themselves
1136 } ($a_chars[0], $b_chars[0]);
1137 # highlight probable double-encoding?
1138 foreach my $c ( @desc ) {
1139 next unless $c =~ m/\\x\{08(..)}/;
1140 $c .= "='" .chr(hex($1)) ."'"
1141 }
1142 return sprintf "Strings differ at index $i: a[$i]=$desc[0], b[$i]=$desc[1]";
1143 }
1144 return "String a truncated after $i characters" if @b_chars;
1145 return "String b truncated after $i characters" if @a_chars;
1146 return "";
1147}
1148
1149
1150sub data_string_desc { # describe a data string
1151 my ($a) = @_;
1152 require bytes;
1153 require utf8;
1154
1155 # hacks to cater for perl 5.6
1156 *utf8::is_utf8 = sub { (DBI::neat(shift)=~/^"/) } unless defined &utf8::is_utf8;
1157 *utf8::valid = sub { 1 } unless defined &utf8::valid;
1158
1159 # Give sufficient info to help diagnose at least these kinds of situations:
1160 # - valid UTF8 byte sequence but UTF8 flag not set
1161 # (might be ascii so also need to check for hibit to make it worthwhile)
1162 # - UTF8 flag set but invalid UTF8 byte sequence
1163 # could do better here, but this'll do for now
1164 my $utf8 = sprintf "UTF8 %s%s",
1165 utf8::is_utf8($a) ? "on" : "off",
1166 utf8::valid($a||'') ? "" : " but INVALID encoding";
1167 return "$utf8, undef" unless defined $a;
1168 my $is_ascii = $a =~ m/^[\000-\177]*$/;
1169 return sprintf "%s, %s, %d characters %d bytes",
1170 $utf8, $is_ascii ? "ASCII" : "non-ASCII",
1171 length($a), bytes::length($a);
1172}
1173
1174
1175sub connect_test_perf {
1176 my($class, $dsn,$dbuser,$dbpass, $attr) = @_;
1177 Carp::croak("connect_test_perf needs hash ref as fourth arg") unless ref $attr;
1178 # these are non standard attributes just for this special method
1179 my $loops ||= $attr->{dbi_loops} || 5;
1180 my $par ||= $attr->{dbi_par} || 1; # parallelism
1181 my $verb ||= $attr->{dbi_verb} || 1;
1182 my $meth ||= $attr->{dbi_meth} || 'connect';
1183 print "$dsn: testing $loops sets of $par connections:\n";
1184 require "FileHandle.pm"; # don't let toke.c create empty FileHandle package
1185 local $| = 1;
1186 my $drh = $class->install_driver($dsn) or Carp::croak("Can't install $dsn driver\n");
1187 # test the connection and warm up caches etc
1188 $drh->connect($dsn,$dbuser,$dbpass) or Carp::croak("connect failed: $DBI::errstr");
1189 my $t1 = dbi_time();
1190 my $loop;
1191 for $loop (1..$loops) {
1192 my @cons;
1193 print "Connecting... " if $verb;
1194 for (1..$par) {
1195 print "$_ ";
1196 push @cons, ($drh->connect($dsn,$dbuser,$dbpass)
1197 or Carp::croak("connect failed: $DBI::errstr\n"));
1198 }
1199 print "\nDisconnecting...\n" if $verb;
1200 for (@cons) {
1201 $_->disconnect or warn "disconnect failed: $DBI::errstr"
1202 }
1203 }
1204 my $t2 = dbi_time();
1205 my $td = $t2 - $t1;
1206 printf "$meth %d and disconnect them, %d times: %.4fs / %d = %.4fs\n",
1207 $par, $loops, $td, $loops*$par, $td/($loops*$par);
1208 return $td;
1209}

# spent 86µs (29+57) within DBI::_new_drh which was called: # once (29µs+57µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 29 of DBD/mysql.pm
sub _new_drh { # called by DBD::<drivername>::driver()
123112µs my ($class, $initial_attr, $imp_data) = @_;
1232 # Provide default storage for State,Err and Errstr.
1233 # Note that these are shared by all child handles by default! XXX
1234 # State must be undef to get automatic faking in DBI::var::FETCH
123512µs my ($h_state_store, $h_err_store, $h_errstr_store) = (undef, 0, '');
123618µs my $attr = {
1237 # these attributes get copied down to child handles by default
1238 'State' => \$h_state_store, # Holder for DBI::state
1239 'Err' => \$h_err_store, # Holder for DBI::err
1240 'Errstr' => \$h_errstr_store, # Holder for DBI::errstr
1241 'TraceLevel' => 0,
1242 FetchHashKeyName=> 'NAME',
1243 %$initial_attr,
1244 };
1245167µs157µs my ($h, $i) = _new_handle('DBI::dr', '', $attr, $imp_data, $class);
# spent 57µs making 1 call to DBI::_new_handle
1246
1247 # XXX DBI_PROFILE unless DBI::PurePerl because for some reason
1248 # it kills the t/zz_*_pp.t tests (they silently exit early)
124912µs if (($ENV{DBI_PROFILE} && !$DBI::PurePerl) || $shared_profile) {
1250 # The profile object created here when the first driver is loaded
1251 # is shared by all drivers so we end up with just one set of profile
1252 # data and thus the 'total time in DBI' is really the true total.
1253 if (!$shared_profile) { # first time
1254 $h->{Profile} = $ENV{DBI_PROFILE}; # write string
1255 $shared_profile = $h->{Profile}; # read and record object
1256 }
1257 else {
1258 $h->{Profile} = $shared_profile;
1259 }
1260 }
126117µs return $h unless wantarray;
1262 ($h, $i);
1263}

1303
1304 sub driver {
1305 return $drh if $drh; # a package global
1306
1307 my $inner;
1308 ($drh, $inner) = DBI::_new_drh('DBD::Switch::dr', {
1309 'Name' => 'Switch',
1310 'Version' => $DBI::VERSION,
1311 'Attribution' => "DBI $DBI::VERSION by Tim Bunce",
1312 });
1313 Carp::croak("DBD::Switch init failed!") unless ($drh && $inner);
1314 return $drh;
1315 }
1316 sub CLONE {
1317 undef $drh;
1318 }
1319
1320 sub FETCH {
1321 my($drh, $key) = @_;
1322 return DBI->trace if $key eq 'DebugDispatch';
1323 return undef if $key eq 'DebugLog'; # not worth fetching, sorry
1324 return $drh->DBD::_::dr::FETCH($key);
1325 undef;
1326 }
1327 sub STORE {
1328 my($drh, $key, $value) = @_;
1329 if ($key eq 'DebugDispatch') {
1330 DBI->trace($value);
1331 } elsif ($key eq 'DebugLog') {
1332 DBI->trace(-1, $value);
1333 } else {
1334 $drh->DBD::_::dr::STORE($key, $value);
1335 }
1336 }
1337}
1338
1339
1340# --------------------------------------------------------------------
1341# === OPTIONAL MINIMAL BASE CLASSES FOR DBI SUBCLASSES ===
1342
1343# We only define default methods for harmless functions.
1344# We don't, for example, define a DBD::_::st::prepare()
1345
134613µs{ package # hide from PAUSE
1347 DBD::_::common; # ====== Common base class methods ======
13483693µs16µs use strict;
# spent 6µs making 1 call to strict::import
1349
1350 # methods common to all handle types:
1351
1352 sub _not_impl {
1353 my ($h, $method) = @_;
1354 $h->trace_msg("Driver does not implement the $method method.\n");
1355 return; # empty list / undef
1356 }
1357
1358 # generic TIEHASH default methods:
1359 sub FIRSTKEY { }
1360 sub NEXTKEY { }
1361 sub EXISTS { defined($_[0]->FETCH($_[1])) } # XXX undef?
1362 sub CLEAR { Carp::carp "Can't CLEAR $_[0] (DBI)" }
1363
1364 sub FETCH_many { # XXX should move to C one day
1365 my $h = shift;
1366 # scalar is needed to workaround drivers that return an empty list
1367 # for some attributes
1368 return map { scalar $h->FETCH($_) } @_;
1369 }
1370
137112µs *dump_handle = \&DBI::dump_handle;

# spent 239µs (172+67) within DBD::_::common::install_method which was called 5 times, avg 48µs/call: # once (43µs+16µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 36 of DBD/mysql.pm # once (31µs+18µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 39 of DBD/mysql.pm # once (34µs+11µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 40 of DBD/mysql.pm # once (33µs+11µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 37 of DBD/mysql.pm # once (31µs+11µs) by DBD::mysql::driver at line 38 of DBD/mysql.pm
sub install_method {
1374 # special class method called directly by apps and/or drivers
1375 # to install new methods into the DBI dispatcher
1376 # DBD::Foo::db->install_method("foo_mumble", { usage => [...], options => '...' });
137759µs my ($class, $method, $attr) = @_;
1378538µs517µs Carp::croak("Class '$class' must begin with DBD:: and end with ::db or ::st")
# spent 17µs making 5 calls to DBD::_::common::CORE:match, avg 3µs/call
1379 unless $class =~ /^DBD::(\w+)::(dr|db|st)$/;
1380514µs my ($driver, $subtype) = ($1, $2);
1381531µs512µs Carp::croak("invalid method name '$method'")
# spent 12µs making 5 calls to DBD::_::common::CORE:match, avg 2µs/call
1382 unless $method =~ m/^([a-z]+_)\w+$/;
138358µs my $prefix = $1;
138457µs my $reg_info = $dbd_prefix_registry->{$prefix};
138554µs Carp::carp("method name prefix '$prefix' is not associated with a registered driver") unless $reg_info;
1386
138758µs my $full_method = "DBI::${subtype}::$method";
1388513µs $DBI::installed_methods{$full_method} = $attr;
1389
1390514µs my (undef, $filename, $line) = caller;
1391 # XXX reformat $attr as needed for _install_method
1392511µs my %attr = %{$attr||{}}; # copy so we can edit
1393588µs538µs DBI->_install_method("DBI::${subtype}::$method", "$filename at line $line", \%attr);
# spent 38µs making 5 calls to DBI::_install_method, avg 8µs/call
1394 }
1395
1396 sub parse_trace_flags {
1397 my ($h, $spec) = @_;
1398 my $level = 0;
1399 my $flags = 0;
1400 my @unknown;
1401 for my $word (split /\s*[|&,]\s*/, $spec) {
1402 if (DBI::looks_like_number($word) && $word <= 0xF && $word >= 0) {
1403 $level = $word;
1404 } elsif ($word eq 'ALL') {
1405 $flags = 0x7FFFFFFF; # XXX last bit causes negative headaches
1406 last;
1407 } elsif (my $flag = $h->parse_trace_flag($word)) {
1408 $flags |= $flag;
1409 }
1410 else {
1411 push @unknown, $word;
1412 }
1413 }
1414 if (@unknown && (ref $h ? $h->FETCH('Warn') : 1)) {
1415 Carp::carp("$h->parse_trace_flags($spec) ignored unknown trace flags: ".
1416 join(" ", map { DBI::neat($_) } @unknown));
1417 }
1418 $flags |= $level;
1419 return $flags;
1420 }
1421
1422 sub parse_trace_flag {
1423 my ($h, $name) = @_;
1424 # 0xddDDDDrL (driver, DBI, reserved, Level)
1425 return 0x00000100 if $name eq 'SQL';
1426 return;
1427 }
1428
1429 sub private_attribute_info {
1430 return undef;
1431 }
1432
1433 sub visit_child_handles {
1434 my ($h, $code, $info) = @_;
1435 $info = {} if not defined $info;
1436 for my $ch (@{ $h->{ChildHandles} || []}) {
1437 next unless $ch;
1438 my $child_info = $code->($ch, $info)
1439 or next;
1440 $ch->visit_child_handles($code, $child_info);
1441 }
1442 return $info;
1443 }
1444}
1445
1446
144711µs{ package # hide from PAUSE
1448 DBD::_::dr; # ====== DRIVER ======
144912µs @DBD::_::dr::ISA = qw(DBD::_::common);
14503349µs16µs use strict;
# spent 6µs making 1 call to strict::import
1451
1452 sub default_user {
1453 my ($drh, $user, $pass, $attr) = @_;
1454 $user = $ENV{DBI_USER} unless defined $user;
1455 $pass = $ENV{DBI_PASS} unless defined $pass;
1456 return ($user, $pass);
1457 }
1458
1459 sub connect { # normally overridden, but a handy default
1460 my ($drh, $dsn, $user, $auth) = @_;
1461 my ($this) = DBI::_new_dbh($drh, {
1462 'Name' => $dsn,
1463 });
1464 # XXX debatable as there's no "server side" here
1465 # (and now many uses would trigger warnings on DESTROY)
1466 # $this->STORE(Active => 1);
1467 # so drivers should set it in their own connect
1468 $this;
1469 }
1470
1471

1482 if $DBI::dbi_debug >= 4;
1483
14844074µs my $cb = $attr->{Callbacks}; # take care not to autovivify

# spent 9.32ms making 39 calls to DBI::db::ping, avg 239µs/call # spent 592µs making 39 calls to DBI::common::FETCH, avg 15µs/call

1490 }

1497 $cb->($dbh, $dsn, $user, $auth, $attr);
1498 }

150812µs{ package # hide from PAUSE
1509 DBD::_::db; # ====== DATABASE ======
151012µs @DBD::_::db::ISA = qw(DBD::_::common);
151131.73ms15µs use strict;
# spent 5µs making 1 call to strict::import
1512
1513 sub clone {
1514 my ($old_dbh, $attr) = @_;
1515 my $closure = $old_dbh->{dbi_connect_closure} or return;
1516 unless ($attr) {
1517 # copy attributes visible in the attribute cache
1518 keys %$old_dbh; # reset iterator
1519 while ( my ($k, $v) = each %$old_dbh ) {
1520 # ignore non-code refs, i.e., caches, handles, Err etc
1521 next if ref $v && ref $v ne 'CODE'; # HandleError etc
1522 $attr->{$k} = $v;
1523 }
1524 # explicitly set attributes which are unlikely to be in the
1525 # attribute cache, i.e., boolean's and some others
1526 $attr->{$_} = $old_dbh->FETCH($_) for (qw(
1527 AutoCommit ChopBlanks InactiveDestroy AutoInactiveDestroy
1528 LongTruncOk PrintError PrintWarn Profile RaiseError
1529 ShowErrorStatement TaintIn TaintOut
1530 ));
1531 }
1532 # use Data::Dumper; warn Dumper([$old_dbh, $attr]);
1533 my $new_dbh = &$closure($old_dbh, $attr);
1534 unless ($new_dbh) {
1535 # need to copy err/errstr from driver back into $old_dbh
1536 my $drh = $old_dbh->{Driver};
1537 return $old_dbh->set_err($drh->err, $drh->errstr, $drh->state);
1538 }
1539 return $new_dbh;
1540 }
1541
1542 sub quote_identifier {
1543 my ($dbh, @id) = @_;
1544 my $attr = (@id > 3 && ref($id[-1])) ? pop @id : undef;
1545
1546 my $info = $dbh->{dbi_quote_identifier_cache} ||= [
1547 $dbh->get_info(29) || '"', # SQL_IDENTIFIER_QUOTE_CHAR
1548 $dbh->get_info(41) || '.', # SQL_CATALOG_NAME_SEPARATOR
1549 $dbh->get_info(114) || 1, # SQL_CATALOG_LOCATION
1550 ];
1551
1552 my $quote = $info->[0];
1553 foreach (@id) { # quote the elements
1554 next unless defined;
1555 s/$quote/$quote$quote/g; # escape embedded quotes
1556 $_ = qq{$quote$_$quote};
1557 }
1558
1559 # strip out catalog if present for special handling
1560 my $catalog = (@id >= 3) ? shift @id : undef;
1561
1562 # join the dots, ignoring any null/undef elements (ie schema)
1563 my $quoted_id = join '.', grep { defined } @id;
1564
1565 if ($catalog) { # add catalog correctly
1566 $quoted_id = ($info->[2] == 2) # SQL_CL_END
1567 ? $quoted_id . $info->[1] . $catalog
1568 : $catalog . $info->[1] . $quoted_id;
1569 }
1570 return $quoted_id;
1571 }
1572
1573 sub quote {
1574 my ($dbh, $str, $data_type) = @_;
1575
1576 return "NULL" unless defined $str;
1577 unless ($data_type) {
1578 $str =~ s/'/''/g; # ISO SQL2
1579 return "'$str'";
1580 }
1581
1582 my $dbi_literal_quote_cache = $dbh->{'dbi_literal_quote_cache'} ||= [ {} , {} ];
1583 my ($prefixes, $suffixes) = @$dbi_literal_quote_cache;
1584
1585 my $lp = $prefixes->{$data_type};
1586 my $ls = $suffixes->{$data_type};
1587
1588 if ( ! defined $lp || ! defined $ls ) {
1589 my $ti = $dbh->type_info($data_type);
1590 $lp = $prefixes->{$data_type} = $ti ? $ti->{LITERAL_PREFIX} || "" : "'";
1591 $ls = $suffixes->{$data_type} = $ti ? $ti->{LITERAL_SUFFIX} || "" : "'";
1592 }
1593 return $str unless $lp || $ls; # no quoting required
1594
1595 # XXX don't know what the standard says about escaping
1596 # in the 'general case' (where $lp != "'").
1597 # So we just do this and hope:
1598 $str =~ s/$lp/$lp$lp/g
1599 if $lp && $lp eq $ls && ($lp eq "'" || $lp eq '"');
1600 return "$lp$str$ls";
1601 }
1602
1603 sub rows { -1 } # here so $DBI::rows 'works' after using $dbh
1604
1605 sub do {
1606 my($dbh, $statement, $attr, @params) = @_;
1607 my $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement, $attr) or return undef;
1608 $sth->execute(@params) or return undef;
1609 my $rows = $sth->rows;
1610 ($rows == 0) ? "0E0" : $rows;
1611 }
1612
1613 sub _do_selectrow {
1614 my ($method, $dbh, $stmt, $attr, @bind) = @_;
1615 my $sth = ((ref $stmt) ? $stmt : $dbh->prepare($stmt, $attr))
1616 or return;
1617 $sth->execute(@bind)
1618 or return;
1619 my $row = $sth->$method()
1620 and $sth->finish;
1621 return $row;
1622 }
1623
1624 sub selectrow_hashref { return _do_selectrow('fetchrow_hashref', @_); }
1625
1626 # XXX selectrow_array/ref also have C implementations in Driver.xst
1627 sub selectrow_arrayref { return _do_selectrow('fetchrow_arrayref', @_); }
1628 sub selectrow_array {
1629 my $row = _do_selectrow('fetchrow_arrayref', @_) or return;
1630 return $row->[0] unless wantarray;
1631 return @$row;
1632 }
1633
1634 # XXX selectall_arrayref also has C implementation in Driver.xst
1635 # which fallsback to this if a slice is given
1636
# spent 7.11s (2.60ms+7.11) within DBD::_::db::selectall_arrayref which was called 40 times, avg 178ms/call: # 20 times (1.42ms+7.07s) by DBI::db::selectall_arrayref at line 62 of lib/Isucon.pm, avg 353ms/call # 20 times (1.18ms+46.2ms) by DBI::db::selectall_arrayref at line 77 of lib/Isucon.pm, avg 2.37ms/call
sub selectall_arrayref {
163740152µs my ($dbh, $stmt, $attr, @bind) = @_;
163840668µs404.40ms my $sth = (ref $stmt) ? $stmt : $dbh->prepare($stmt, $attr)
# spent 4.40ms making 40 calls to DBI::db::prepare, avg 110µs/call
1639 or return;
1640407.08s407.07s $sth->execute(@bind) || return;
# spent 7.07s making 40 calls to DBI::st::execute, avg 177ms/call
164140154µs my $slice = $attr->{Slice}; # typically undef, else hash or array ref
16424078µs if (!$slice and $slice=$attr->{Columns}) {
1643 if (ref $slice eq 'ARRAY') { # map col idx to perl array idx
1644 $slice = [ @{$attr->{Columns}} ]; # take a copy
1645 for (@$slice) { $_-- }
1646 }
1647 }
1648401.34ms8065.5ms my $rows = $sth->fetchall_arrayref($slice, my $MaxRows = $attr->{MaxRows});
# spent 33.2ms making 40 calls to DBI::st::fetchall_arrayref, avg 830µs/call # spent 32.2ms making 40 calls to DBD::_::st::fetchall_arrayref, avg 806µs/call
16494056µs $sth->finish if defined $MaxRows;
165040969µs return $rows;
1651 }
1652
1653 sub selectall_hashref {
1654 my ($dbh, $stmt, $key_field, $attr, @bind) = @_;
1655 my $sth = (ref $stmt) ? $stmt : $dbh->prepare($stmt, $attr);
1656 return unless $sth;
1657 $sth->execute(@bind) || return;
1658 return $sth->fetchall_hashref($key_field);
1659 }
1660
1661 sub selectcol_arrayref {
1662 my ($dbh, $stmt, $attr, @bind) = @_;
1663 my $sth = (ref $stmt) ? $stmt : $dbh->prepare($stmt, $attr);
1664 return unless $sth;
1665 $sth->execute(@bind) || return;
1666 my @columns = ($attr->{Columns}) ? @{$attr->{Columns}} : (1);
1667 my @values = (undef) x @columns;
1668 my $idx = 0;
1669 for (@columns) {
1670 $sth->bind_col($_, \$values[$idx++]) || return;
1671 }
1672 my @col;
1673 if (my $max = $attr->{MaxRows}) {
1674 push @col, @values while 0 < $max-- && $sth->fetch;
1675 }
1676 else {
1677 push @col, @values while $sth->fetch;
1678 }
1679 return \@col;
1680 }
1681
1682 sub prepare_cached {
1683 my ($dbh, $statement, $attr, $if_active) = @_;
1684
1685 # Needs support at dbh level to clear cache before complaining about
1686 # active children. The XS template code does this. Drivers not using
1687 # the template must handle clearing the cache themselves.
1688 my $cache = $dbh->{CachedKids} ||= {};
1689 my $key = do { local $^W;
1690 join "!\001", $statement, DBI::_concat_hash_sorted($attr, "=\001", ",\001", 0, 0)
1691 };
1692 my $sth = $cache->{$key};
1693
1694 if ($sth) {
1695 return $sth unless $sth->FETCH('Active');
1696 Carp::carp("prepare_cached($statement) statement handle $sth still Active")
1697 unless ($if_active ||= 0);
1698 $sth->finish if $if_active <= 1;
1699 return $sth if $if_active <= 2;
1700 }
1701
1702 $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement, $attr);
1703 $cache->{$key} = $sth if $sth;
1704
1705 return $sth;
1706 }
1707
1708 sub ping {
1709 my $dbh = shift;
1710 $dbh->_not_impl('ping');
1711 # "0 but true" is a special kind of true 0 that is used here so
1712 # applications can check if the ping was a real ping or not
1713 ($dbh->FETCH('Active')) ? "0 but true" : 0;
1714 }
1715
1716 sub begin_work {
1717 my $dbh = shift;
1718 return $dbh->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Already in a transaction")
1719 unless $dbh->FETCH('AutoCommit');
1720 $dbh->STORE('AutoCommit', 0); # will croak if driver doesn't support it
1721 $dbh->STORE('BegunWork', 1); # trigger post commit/rollback action
1722 return 1;
1723 }
1724
1725 sub primary_key {
1726 my ($dbh, @args) = @_;
1727 my $sth = $dbh->primary_key_info(@args) or return;
1728 my ($row, @col);
1729 push @col, $row->[3] while ($row = $sth->fetch);
1730 Carp::croak("primary_key method not called in list context")
1731 unless wantarray; # leave us some elbow room
1732 return @col;
1733 }
1734
1735 sub tables {
1736 my ($dbh, @args) = @_;
1737 my $sth = $dbh->table_info(@args[0,1,2,3,4]) or return;
1738 my $tables = $sth->fetchall_arrayref or return;
1739 my @tables;
1740 if ($dbh->get_info(29)) { # SQL_IDENTIFIER_QUOTE_CHAR
1741 @tables = map { $dbh->quote_identifier( @{$_}[0,1,2] ) } @$tables;
1742 }
1743 else { # temporary old style hack (yeach)
1744 @tables = map {
1745 my $name = $_->[2];
1746 if ($_->[1]) {
1747 my $schema = $_->[1];
1748 # a sad hack (mostly for Informix I recall)
1749 my $quote = ($schema eq uc($schema)) ? '' : '"';
1750 $name = "$quote$schema$quote.$name"
1751 }
1752 $name;
1753 } @$tables;
1754 }
1755 return @tables;
1756 }
1757
1758 sub type_info { # this should be sufficient for all drivers
1759 my ($dbh, $data_type) = @_;
1760 my $idx_hash;
1761 my $tia = $dbh->{dbi_type_info_row_cache};
1762 if ($tia) {
1763 $idx_hash = $dbh->{dbi_type_info_idx_cache};
1764 }
1765 else {
1766 my $temp = $dbh->type_info_all;
1767 return unless $temp && @$temp;
1768 # we cache here because type_info_all may be expensive to call
1769 # (and we take a copy so the following shift can't corrupt
1770 # the data that may be returned by future calls to type_info_all)
1771 $tia = $dbh->{dbi_type_info_row_cache} = [ @$temp ];
1772 $idx_hash = $dbh->{dbi_type_info_idx_cache} = shift @$tia;
1773 }
1774
1775 my $dt_idx = $idx_hash->{DATA_TYPE} || $idx_hash->{data_type};
1776 Carp::croak("type_info_all returned non-standard DATA_TYPE index value ($dt_idx != 1)")
1777 if $dt_idx && $dt_idx != 1;
1778
1779 # --- simple DATA_TYPE match filter
1780 my @ti;
1781 my @data_type_list = (ref $data_type) ? @$data_type : ($data_type);
1782 foreach $data_type (@data_type_list) {
1783 if (defined($data_type) && $data_type != DBI::SQL_ALL_TYPES()) {
1784 push @ti, grep { $_->[$dt_idx] == $data_type } @$tia;
1785 }
1786 else { # SQL_ALL_TYPES
1787 push @ti, @$tia;
1788 }
1789 last if @ti; # found at least one match
1790 }
1791
1792 # --- format results into list of hash refs
1793 my $idx_fields = keys %$idx_hash;
1794 my @idx_names = map { uc($_) } keys %$idx_hash;
1795 my @idx_values = values %$idx_hash;
1796 Carp::croak "type_info_all result has $idx_fields keys but ".(@{$ti[0]})." fields"
1797 if @ti && @{$ti[0]} != $idx_fields;
1798 my @out = map {
1799 my %h; @h{@idx_names} = @{$_}[ @idx_values ]; \%h;
1800 } @ti;
1801 return $out[0] unless wantarray;
1802 return @out;
1803 }
1804
1805 sub data_sources {
1806 my ($dbh, @other) = @_;
1807 my $drh = $dbh->{Driver}; # XXX proxy issues?
1808 return $drh->data_sources(@other);
1809 }
1810
1811}
1812
1813
181412µs{ package # hide from PAUSE
1815 DBD::_::st; # ====== STATEMENT ======
181612µs @DBD::_::st::ISA = qw(DBD::_::common);
181731.68ms16µs use strict;
# spent 6µs making 1 call to strict::import
1818
1819 sub bind_param { Carp::croak("Can't bind_param, not implement by driver") }
1820
1821#
1822# ********************************************************
1823#
1824# BEGIN ARRAY BINDING
1825#
1826# Array binding support for drivers which don't support
1827# array binding, but have sufficient interfaces to fake it.
1828# NOTE: mixing scalars and arrayrefs requires using bind_param_array
1829# for *all* params...unless we modify bind_param for the default
1830# case...
1831#
1832# 2002-Apr-10 D. Arnold
1833
1834 sub bind_param_array {
1835 my $sth = shift;
1836 my ($p_id, $value_array, $attr) = @_;
1837
1838 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Value for parameter $p_id must be a scalar or an arrayref, not a ".ref($value_array))
1839 if defined $value_array and ref $value_array and ref $value_array ne 'ARRAY';
1840
1841 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Can't use named placeholder '$p_id' for non-driver supported bind_param_array")
1842 unless DBI::looks_like_number($p_id); # because we rely on execute(@ary) here
1843
1844 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Placeholder '$p_id' is out of range")
1845 if $p_id <= 0; # can't easily/reliably test for too big
1846
1847 # get/create arrayref to hold params
1848 my $hash_of_arrays = $sth->{ParamArrays} ||= { };
1849
1850 # If the bind has attribs then we rely on the driver conforming to
1851 # the DBI spec in that a single bind_param() call with those attribs
1852 # makes them 'sticky' and apply to all later execute(@values) calls.
1853 # Since we only call bind_param() if we're given attribs then
1854 # applications using drivers that don't support bind_param can still
1855 # use bind_param_array() so long as they don't pass any attribs.
1856
1857 $$hash_of_arrays{$p_id} = $value_array;
1858 return $sth->bind_param($p_id, undef, $attr)
1859 if $attr;
1860 1;
1861 }
1862
1863 sub bind_param_inout_array {
1864 my $sth = shift;
1865 # XXX not supported so we just call bind_param_array instead
1866 # and then return an error
1867 my ($p_num, $value_array, $attr) = @_;
1868 $sth->bind_param_array($p_num, $value_array, $attr);
1869 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "bind_param_inout_array not supported");
1870 }
1871
1872 sub bind_columns {
1873 my $sth = shift;
1874 my $fields = $sth->FETCH('NUM_OF_FIELDS') || 0;
1875 if ($fields <= 0 && !$sth->{Active}) {
1876 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Statement has no result columns to bind"
1877 ." (perhaps you need to successfully call execute first)");
1878 }
1879 # Backwards compatibility for old-style call with attribute hash
1880 # ref as first arg. Skip arg if undef or a hash ref.
1881 my $attr;
1882 $attr = shift if !defined $_[0] or ref($_[0]) eq 'HASH';
1883
1884 my $idx = 0;
1885 $sth->bind_col(++$idx, shift, $attr) or return
1886 while (@_ and $idx < $fields);
1887
1888 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "bind_columns called with ".($idx+@_)." values but $fields are needed")
1889 if @_ or $idx != $fields;
1890
1891 return 1;
1892 }
1893
1894 sub execute_array {
1895 my $sth = shift;
1896 my ($attr, @array_of_arrays) = @_;
1897 my $NUM_OF_PARAMS = $sth->FETCH('NUM_OF_PARAMS'); # may be undef at this point
1898
1899 # get tuple status array or hash attribute
1900 my $tuple_sts = $attr->{ArrayTupleStatus};
1901 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "ArrayTupleStatus attribute must be an arrayref")
1902 if $tuple_sts and ref $tuple_sts ne 'ARRAY';
1903
1904 # bind all supplied arrays
1905 if (@array_of_arrays) {
1906 $sth->{ParamArrays} = { }; # clear out old params
1907 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr,
1908 @array_of_arrays." bind values supplied but $NUM_OF_PARAMS expected")
1909 if defined ($NUM_OF_PARAMS) && @array_of_arrays != $NUM_OF_PARAMS;
1910 $sth->bind_param_array($_, $array_of_arrays[$_-1]) or return
1911 foreach (1..@array_of_arrays);
1912 }
1913
1914 my $fetch_tuple_sub;
1915
1916 if ($fetch_tuple_sub = $attr->{ArrayTupleFetch}) { # fetch on demand
1917
1918 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr,
1919 "Can't use both ArrayTupleFetch and explicit bind values")
1920 if @array_of_arrays; # previous bind_param_array calls will simply be ignored
1921
1922 if (UNIVERSAL::isa($fetch_tuple_sub,'DBI::st')) {
1923 my $fetch_sth = $fetch_tuple_sub;
1924 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr,
1925 "ArrayTupleFetch sth is not Active, need to execute() it first")
1926 unless $fetch_sth->{Active};
1927 # check column count match to give more friendly message
1928 my $NUM_OF_FIELDS = $fetch_sth->{NUM_OF_FIELDS};
1929 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr,
1930 "$NUM_OF_FIELDS columns from ArrayTupleFetch sth but $NUM_OF_PARAMS expected")
1931 if defined($NUM_OF_FIELDS) && defined($NUM_OF_PARAMS)
1932 && $NUM_OF_FIELDS != $NUM_OF_PARAMS;
1933 $fetch_tuple_sub = sub { $fetch_sth->fetchrow_arrayref };
1934 }
1935 elsif (!UNIVERSAL::isa($fetch_tuple_sub,'CODE')) {
1936 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "ArrayTupleFetch '$fetch_tuple_sub' is not a code ref or statement handle");
1937 }
1938
1939 }
1940 else {
1941 my $NUM_OF_PARAMS_given = keys %{ $sth->{ParamArrays} || {} };
1942 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr,
1943 "$NUM_OF_PARAMS_given bind values supplied but $NUM_OF_PARAMS expected")
1944 if defined($NUM_OF_PARAMS) && $NUM_OF_PARAMS != $NUM_OF_PARAMS_given;
1945
1946 # get the length of a bound array
1947 my $maxlen;
1948 my %hash_of_arrays = %{$sth->{ParamArrays}};
1949 foreach (keys(%hash_of_arrays)) {
1950 my $ary = $hash_of_arrays{$_};
1951 next unless ref $ary eq 'ARRAY';
1952 $maxlen = @$ary if !$maxlen || @$ary > $maxlen;
1953 }
1954 # if there are no arrays then execute scalars once
1955 $maxlen = 1 unless defined $maxlen;
1956 my @bind_ids = 1..keys(%hash_of_arrays);
1957
1958 my $tuple_idx = 0;
1959 $fetch_tuple_sub = sub {
1960 return if $tuple_idx >= $maxlen;
1961 my @tuple = map {
1962 my $a = $hash_of_arrays{$_};
1963 ref($a) ? $a->[$tuple_idx] : $a
1964 } @bind_ids;
1965 ++$tuple_idx;
1966 return \@tuple;
1967 };
1968 }
1969 # pass thru the callers scalar or list context
1970 return $sth->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub, $tuple_sts);
1971 }
1972
1973 sub execute_for_fetch {
1974 my ($sth, $fetch_tuple_sub, $tuple_status) = @_;
1975 # start with empty status array
1976 ($tuple_status) ? @$tuple_status = () : $tuple_status = [];
1977
1978 my $rc_total = 0;
1979 my $err_count;
1980 while ( my $tuple = &$fetch_tuple_sub() ) {
1981 if ( my $rc = $sth->execute(@$tuple) ) {
1982 push @$tuple_status, $rc;
1983 $rc_total = ($rc >= 0 && $rc_total >= 0) ? $rc_total + $rc : -1;
1984 }
1985 else {
1986 $err_count++;
1987 push @$tuple_status, [ $sth->err, $sth->errstr, $sth->state ];
1988 # XXX drivers implementing execute_for_fetch could opt to "last;" here
1989 # if they know the error code means no further executes will work.
1990 }
1991 }
1992 my $tuples = @$tuple_status;
1993 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "executing $tuples generated $err_count errors")
1994 if $err_count;
1995 $tuples ||= "0E0";
1996 return $tuples unless wantarray;
1997 return ($tuples, $rc_total);
1998 }
1999
2000
2001
# spent 32.2ms (4.20+28.0) within DBD::_::st::fetchall_arrayref which was called 40 times, avg 806µs/call: # 40 times (4.20ms+28.0ms) by DBI::st::fetchall_arrayref at line 1648, avg 806µs/call
sub fetchall_arrayref { # ALSO IN Driver.xst
200240120µs my ($sth, $slice, $max_rows) = @_;
2003
2004 # when batch fetching with $max_rows were very likely to try to
2005 # fetch the 'next batch' after the previous batch returned
2006 # <=$max_rows. So don't treat that as an error.
20074070µs return undef if $max_rows and not $sth->FETCH('Active');
2008
200940102µs my $mode = ref($slice) || 'ARRAY';
20104054µs my @rows;
20114044µs my $row;
201240196µs if ($mode eq 'ARRAY') {
2013 # we copy the array here because fetch (currently) always
2014 # returns the same array ref. XXX
2015 if ($slice && @$slice) {
2016 $max_rows = -1 unless defined $max_rows;
2017 push @rows, [ @{$row}[ @$slice] ]
2018 while($max_rows-- and $row = $sth->fetch);
2019 }
2020 elsif (defined $max_rows) {
2021 push @rows, [ @$row ]
2022 while($max_rows-- and $row = $sth->fetch);
2023 }
2024 else {
2025 push @rows, [ @$row ] while($row = $sth->fetch);
2026 }
2027 }
2028 elsif ($mode eq 'HASH') {
20294086µs $max_rows = -1 unless defined $max_rows;
203040147µs if (keys %$slice) {
2031 my @o_keys = keys %$slice;
2032 my @i_keys = map { lc } keys %$slice;
2033 # XXX this could be made faster by pre-binding a local hash
2034 # using bind_columns and then copying it per row
2035 while ($max_rows-- and $row = $sth->fetchrow_hashref('NAME_lc')) {
2036 my %hash;
2037 @hash{@o_keys} = @{$row}{@i_keys};
2038 push @rows, \%hash;
2039 }
2040 }
2041 else {
2042 # XXX assumes new ref each fetchhash
2043405.45ms44028.0ms push @rows, $row
# spent 28.0ms making 440 calls to DBI::st::fetchrow_hashref, avg 64µs/call
2044 while ($max_rows-- and $row = $sth->fetchrow_hashref());
2045 }
2046 }
2047 else { Carp::croak("fetchall_arrayref($mode) invalid") }
204840291µs return \@rows;
2049 }
2050
2051 sub fetchall_hashref {
2052 my ($sth, $key_field) = @_;
2053
2054 my $hash_key_name = $sth->{FetchHashKeyName} || 'NAME';
2055 my $names_hash = $sth->FETCH("${hash_key_name}_hash");
2056 my @key_fields = (ref $key_field) ? @$key_field : ($key_field);
2057 my @key_indexes;
2058 my $num_of_fields = $sth->FETCH('NUM_OF_FIELDS');
2059 foreach (@key_fields) {
2060 my $index = $names_hash->{$_}; # perl index not column
2061 $index = $_ - 1 if !defined $index && DBI::looks_like_number($_) && $_>=1 && $_ <= $num_of_fields;
2062 return $sth->set_err($DBI::stderr, "Field '$_' does not exist (not one of @{[keys %$names_hash]})")
2063 unless defined $index;
2064 push @key_indexes, $index;
2065 }
2066 my $rows = {};
2067 my $NAME = $sth->FETCH($hash_key_name);
2068 my @row = (undef) x $num_of_fields;
2069 $sth->bind_columns(\(@row));
2070 while ($sth->fetch) {
2071 my $ref = $rows;
2072 $ref = $ref->{$row[$_]} ||= {} for @key_indexes;
2073 @{$ref}{@$NAME} = @row;
2074 }
2075 return $rows;
2076 }
2077
207811µs *dump_results = \&DBI::dump_results;
2079
2080 sub blob_copy_to_file { # returns length or undef on error
2081 my($self, $field, $filename_or_handleref, $blocksize) = @_;
2082 my $fh = $filename_or_handleref;
2083 my($len, $buf) = (0, "");
2084 $blocksize ||= 512; # not too ambitious
2085 local(*FH);
2086 unless(ref $fh) {
2087 open(FH, ">$fh") || return undef;
2088 $fh = \*FH;
2089 }
2090 while(defined($self->blob_read($field, $len, $blocksize, \$buf))) {
2091 print $fh $buf;
2092 $len += length $buf;
2093 }
2094 close(FH);
2095 $len;
2096 }
2097
2098 sub more_results {
2099 shift->{syb_more_results}; # handy grandfathering
2100 }
2101
2102}
2103
210412µsunless ($DBI::PurePerl) { # See install_driver
210524µs { @DBD::_mem::dr::ISA = qw(DBD::_mem::common); }
210623µs { @DBD::_mem::db::ISA = qw(DBD::_mem::common); }
2107211µs { @DBD::_mem::st::ISA = qw(DBD::_mem::common); }
2108 # DBD::_mem::common::DESTROY is implemented in DBI.xs
2109}
2110
21111138µs1;
2112__END__
2113
2114=head1 DESCRIPTION
2115
2116The DBI is a database access module for the Perl programming language. It defines
2117a set of methods, variables, and conventions that provide a consistent
2118database interface, independent of the actual database being used.
2119
2120It is important to remember that the DBI is just an interface.
2121The DBI is a layer
2122of "glue" between an application and one or more database I<driver>
2123modules. It is the driver modules which do most of the real work. The DBI
2124provides a standard interface and framework for the drivers to operate
2125within.
2126
2127
2128=head2 Architecture of a DBI Application
2129
2130 |<- Scope of DBI ->|
2131 .-. .--------------. .-------------.
2132 .-------. | |---| XYZ Driver |---| XYZ Engine |
2133 | Perl | | | `--------------' `-------------'
2134 | script| |A| |D| .--------------. .-------------.
2135 | using |--|P|--|B|---|Oracle Driver |---|Oracle Engine|
2136 | DBI | |I| |I| `--------------' `-------------'
2137 | API | | |...
2138 |methods| | |... Other drivers
2139 `-------' | |...
2140 `-'
2141
2142The API, or Application Programming Interface, defines the
2143call interface and variables for Perl scripts to use. The API
2144is implemented by the Perl DBI extension.
2145
2146The DBI "dispatches" the method calls to the appropriate driver for
2147actual execution. The DBI is also responsible for the dynamic loading
2148of drivers, error checking and handling, providing default
2149implementations for methods, and many other non-database specific duties.
2150
2151Each driver
2152contains implementations of the DBI methods using the
2153private interface functions of the corresponding database engine. Only authors
2154of sophisticated/multi-database applications or generic library
2155functions need be concerned with drivers.
2156
2157=head2 Notation and Conventions
2158
2159The following conventions are used in this document:
2160
2161 $dbh Database handle object
2162 $sth Statement handle object
2163 $drh Driver handle object (rarely seen or used in applications)
2164 $h Any of the handle types above ($dbh, $sth, or $drh)
2165 $rc General Return Code (boolean: true=ok, false=error)
2166 $rv General Return Value (typically an integer)
2167 @ary List of values returned from the database, typically a row of data
2168 $rows Number of rows processed (if available, else -1)
2169 $fh A filehandle
2170 undef NULL values are represented by undefined values in Perl
2171 \%attr Reference to a hash of attribute values passed to methods
2172
2173Note that Perl will automatically destroy database and statement handle objects
2174if all references to them are deleted.
2175
2176
2177=head2 Outline Usage
2178
2179To use DBI,
2180first you need to load the DBI module:
2181
2182 use DBI;
2183 use strict;
2184
2185(The C<use strict;> isn't required but is strongly recommended.)
2186
2187Then you need to L</connect> to your data source and get a I<handle> for that
2188connection:
2189
2190 $dbh = DBI->connect($dsn, $user, $password,
2191 { RaiseError => 1, AutoCommit => 0 });
2192
2193Since connecting can be expensive, you generally just connect at the
2194start of your program and disconnect at the end.
2195
2196Explicitly defining the required C<AutoCommit> behaviour is strongly
2197recommended and may become mandatory in a later version. This
2198determines whether changes are automatically committed to the
2199database when executed, or need to be explicitly committed later.
2200
2201The DBI allows an application to "prepare" statements for later
2202execution. A prepared statement is identified by a statement handle
2203held in a Perl variable.
2204We'll call the Perl variable C<$sth> in our examples.
2205
2206The typical method call sequence for a C<SELECT> statement is:
2207
2208 prepare,
2209 execute, fetch, fetch, ...
2210 execute, fetch, fetch, ...
2211 execute, fetch, fetch, ...
2212
2213for example:
2214
2215 $sth = $dbh->prepare("SELECT foo, bar FROM table WHERE baz=?");
2216
2217 $sth->execute( $baz );
2218
2219 while ( @row = $sth->fetchrow_array ) {
2220 print "@row\n";
2221 }
2222
2223The typical method call sequence for a I<non>-C<SELECT> statement is:
2224
2225 prepare,
2226 execute,
2227 execute,
2228 execute.
2229
2230for example:
2231
2232 $sth = $dbh->prepare("INSERT INTO table(foo,bar,baz) VALUES (?,?,?)");
2233
2234 while(<CSV>) {
2235 chomp;
2236 my ($foo,$bar,$baz) = split /,/;
2237 $sth->execute( $foo, $bar, $baz );
2238 }
2239
2240The C<do()> method can be used for non repeated I<non>-C<SELECT> statement
2241(or with drivers that don't support placeholders):
2242
2243 $rows_affected = $dbh->do("UPDATE your_table SET foo = foo + 1");
2244
2245To commit your changes to the database (when L</AutoCommit> is off):
2246
2247 $dbh->commit; # or call $dbh->rollback; to undo changes
2248
2249Finally, when you have finished working with the data source, you should
2250L</disconnect> from it:
2251
2252 $dbh->disconnect;
2253
2254
2255=head2 General Interface Rules & Caveats
2256
2257The DBI does not have a concept of a "current session". Every session
2258has a handle object (i.e., a C<$dbh>) returned from the C<connect> method.
2259That handle object is used to invoke database related methods.
2260
2261Most data is returned to the Perl script as strings. (Null values are
2262returned as C<undef>.) This allows arbitrary precision numeric data to be
2263handled without loss of accuracy. Beware that Perl may not preserve
2264the same accuracy when the string is used as a number.
2265
2266Dates and times are returned as character strings in the current
2267default format of the corresponding database engine. Time zone effects
2268are database/driver dependent.
2269
2270Perl supports binary data in Perl strings, and the DBI will pass binary
2271data to and from the driver without change. It is up to the driver
2272implementors to decide how they wish to handle such binary data.
2273
2274Perl supports two kinds of strings: Unicode (utf8 internally) and non-Unicode
2275(defaults to iso-8859-1 if forced to assume an encoding). Drivers should
2276accept both kinds of strings and, if required, convert them to the character
2277set of the database being used. Similarly, when fetching from the database
2278character data that isn't iso-8859-1 the driver should convert it into utf8.
2279
2280Multiple SQL statements may not be combined in a single statement
2281handle (C<$sth>), although some databases and drivers do support this
2282(notably Sybase and SQL Server).
2283
2284Non-sequential record reads are not supported in this version of the DBI.
2285In other words, records can only be fetched in the order that the
2286database returned them, and once fetched they are forgotten.
2287
2288Positioned updates and deletes are not directly supported by the DBI.
2289See the description of the C<CursorName> attribute for an alternative.
2290
2291Individual driver implementors are free to provide any private
2292functions and/or handle attributes that they feel are useful.
2293Private driver functions can be invoked using the DBI C<func()> method.
2294Private driver attributes are accessed just like standard attributes.
2295
2296Many methods have an optional C<\%attr> parameter which can be used to
2297pass information to the driver implementing the method. Except where
2298specifically documented, the C<\%attr> parameter can only be used to pass
2299driver specific hints. In general, you can ignore C<\%attr> parameters
2300or pass it as C<undef>.
2301
2302
2303=head2 Naming Conventions and Name Space
2304
2305The DBI package and all packages below it (C<DBI::*>) are reserved for
2306use by the DBI. Extensions and related modules use the C<DBIx::>
2307namespace (see L<http://www.perl.com/CPAN/modules/by-module/DBIx/>).
2308Package names beginning with C<DBD::> are reserved for use
2309by DBI database drivers. All environment variables used by the DBI
2310or by individual DBDs begin with "C<DBI_>" or "C<DBD_>".
2311
2312The letter case used for attribute names is significant and plays an
2313important part in the portability of DBI scripts. The case of the
2314attribute name is used to signify who defined the meaning of that name
2315and its values.
2316
2317 Case of name Has a meaning defined by
2318 ------------ ------------------------
2319 UPPER_CASE Standards, e.g., X/Open, ISO SQL92 etc (portable)
2320 MixedCase DBI API (portable), underscores are not used.
2321 lower_case Driver or database engine specific (non-portable)
2322
2323It is of the utmost importance that Driver developers only use
2324lowercase attribute names when defining private attributes. Private
2325attribute names must be prefixed with the driver name or suitable
2326abbreviation (e.g., "C<ora_>" for Oracle, "C<ing_>" for Ingres, etc).
2327
2328
2329=head2 SQL - A Query Language
2330
2331Most DBI drivers require applications to use a dialect of SQL
2332(Structured Query Language) to interact with the database engine.
2333The L</"Standards Reference Information"> section provides links
2334to useful information about SQL.
2335
2336The DBI itself does not mandate or require any particular language to
2337be used; it is language independent. In ODBC terms, the DBI is in
2338"pass-thru" mode, although individual drivers might not be. The only requirement
2339is that queries and other statements must be expressed as a single
2340string of characters passed as the first argument to the L</prepare> or
2341L</do> methods.
2342
2343For an interesting diversion on the I<real> history of RDBMS and SQL,
2344from the people who made it happen, see:
2345
2346 http://ftp.digital.com/pub/DEC/SRC/technical-notes/SRC-1997-018-html/sqlr95.html
2347
2348Follow the "Full Contents" then "Intergalactic dataspeak" links for the
2349SQL history.
2350
2351=head2 Placeholders and Bind Values
2352
2353Some drivers support placeholders and bind values.
2354I<Placeholders>, also called parameter markers, are used to indicate
2355values in a database statement that will be supplied later,
2356before the prepared statement is executed. For example, an application
2357might use the following to insert a row of data into the SALES table:
2358
2359 INSERT INTO sales (product_code, qty, price) VALUES (?, ?, ?)
2360
2361or the following, to select the description for a product:
2362
2363 SELECT description FROM products WHERE product_code = ?
2364
2365The C<?> characters are the placeholders. The association of actual
2366values with placeholders is known as I<binding>, and the values are
2367referred to as I<bind values>.
2368Note that the C<?> is not enclosed in quotation marks, even when the
2369placeholder represents a string.
2370
2371Some drivers also allow placeholders like C<:>I<name> and C<:>I<N> (e.g.,
2372C<:1>, C<:2>, and so on) in addition to C<?>, but their use is not portable.
2373
2374If the C<:>I<N> form of placeholder is supported by the driver you're using,
2375then you should be able to use either L</bind_param> or L</execute> to bind
2376values. Check your driver documentation.
2377
2378With most drivers, placeholders can't be used for any element of a
2379statement that would prevent the database server from validating the
2380statement and creating a query execution plan for it. For example:
2381
2382 "SELECT name, age FROM ?" # wrong (will probably fail)
2383 "SELECT name, ? FROM people" # wrong (but may not 'fail')
2384
2385Also, placeholders can only represent single scalar values.
2386For example, the following
2387statement won't work as expected for more than one value:
2388
2389 "SELECT name, age FROM people WHERE name IN (?)" # wrong
2390 "SELECT name, age FROM people WHERE name IN (?,?)" # two names
2391
2392When using placeholders with the SQL C<LIKE> qualifier, you must
2393remember that the placeholder substitutes for the whole string.
2394So you should use "C<... LIKE ? ...>" and include any wildcard
2395characters in the value that you bind to the placeholder.
2396
2397B<NULL Values>
2398
2399Undefined values, or C<undef>, are used to indicate NULL values.
2400You can insert and update columns with a NULL value as you would a
2401non-NULL value. These examples insert and update the column
2402C<age> with a NULL value:
2403
2404 $sth = $dbh->prepare(qq{
2405 INSERT INTO people (fullname, age) VALUES (?, ?)
2406 });
2407 $sth->execute("Joe Bloggs", undef);
2408
2409 $sth = $dbh->prepare(qq{
2410 UPDATE people SET age = ? WHERE fullname = ?
2411 });
2412 $sth->execute(undef, "Joe Bloggs");
2413
2414However, care must be taken when trying to use NULL values in a
2415C<WHERE> clause. Consider:
2416
2417 SELECT fullname FROM people WHERE age = ?
2418
2419Binding an C<undef> (NULL) to the placeholder will I<not> select rows
2420which have a NULL C<age>! At least for database engines that
2421conform to the SQL standard. Refer to the SQL manual for your database
2422engine or any SQL book for the reasons for this. To explicitly select
2423NULLs you have to say "C<WHERE age IS NULL>".
2424
2425A common issue is to have a code fragment handle a value that could be
2426either C<defined> or C<undef> (non-NULL or NULL) at runtime.
2427A simple technique is to prepare the appropriate statement as needed,
2428and substitute the placeholder for non-NULL cases:
2429
2430 $sql_clause = defined $age? "age = ?" : "age IS NULL";
2431 $sth = $dbh->prepare(qq{
2432 SELECT fullname FROM people WHERE $sql_clause
2433 });
2434 $sth->execute(defined $age ? $age : ());
2435
2436The following technique illustrates qualifying a C<WHERE> clause with
2437several columns, whose associated values (C<defined> or C<undef>) are
2438in a hash %h:
2439
2440 for my $col ("age", "phone", "email") {
2441 if (defined $h{$col}) {
2442 push @sql_qual, "$col = ?";
2443 push @sql_bind, $h{$col};
2444 }
2445 else {
2446 push @sql_qual, "$col IS NULL";
2447 }
2448 }
2449 $sql_clause = join(" AND ", @sql_qual);
2450 $sth = $dbh->prepare(qq{
2451 SELECT fullname FROM people WHERE $sql_clause
2452 });
2453 $sth->execute(@sql_bind);
2454
2455The techniques above call prepare for the SQL statement with each call to
2456execute. Because calls to prepare() can be expensive, performance
2457can suffer when an application iterates many times over statements
2458like the above.
2459
2460A better solution is a single C<WHERE> clause that supports both
2461NULL and non-NULL comparisons. Its SQL statement would need to be
2462prepared only once for all cases, thus improving performance.
2463Several examples of C<WHERE> clauses that support this are presented
2464below. But each example lacks portability, robustness, or simplicity.
2465Whether an example is supported on your database engine depends on
2466what SQL extensions it provides, and where it supports the C<?>
2467placeholder in a statement.
2468
2469 0) age = ?
2470 1) NVL(age, xx) = NVL(?, xx)
2471 2) ISNULL(age, xx) = ISNULL(?, xx)
2472 3) DECODE(age, ?, 1, 0) = 1
2473 4) age = ? OR (age IS NULL AND ? IS NULL)
2474 5) age = ? OR (age IS NULL AND SP_ISNULL(?) = 1)
2475 6) age = ? OR (age IS NULL AND ? = 1)
2476
2477Statements formed with the above C<WHERE> clauses require execute
2478statements as follows. The arguments are required, whether their
2479values are C<defined> or C<undef>.
2480
2481 0,1,2,3) $sth->execute($age);
2482 4,5) $sth->execute($age, $age);
2483 6) $sth->execute($age, defined($age) ? 0 : 1);
2484
2485Example 0 should not work (as mentioned earlier), but may work on
2486a few database engines anyway (e.g. Sybase). Example 0 is part
2487of examples 4, 5, and 6, so if example 0 works, these other
2488examples may work, even if the engine does not properly support
2489the right hand side of the C<OR> expression.
2490
2491Examples 1 and 2 are not robust: they require that you provide a
2492valid column value xx (e.g. '~') which is not present in any row.
2493That means you must have some notion of what data won't be stored
2494in the column, and expect clients to adhere to that.
2495
2496Example 5 requires that you provide a stored procedure (SP_ISNULL
2497in this example) that acts as a function: it checks whether a value
2498is null, and returns 1 if it is, or 0 if not.
2499
2500Example 6, the least simple, is probably the most portable, i.e., it
2501should work with with most, if not all, database engines.
2502
2503Here is a table that indicates which examples above are known to
2504work on various database engines:
2505
2506 -----Examples------
2507 0 1 2 3 4 5 6
2508 - - - - - - -
2509 Oracle 9 N Y N Y Y ? Y
2510 Informix IDS 9 N N N Y N Y Y
2511 MS SQL N N Y N Y ? Y
2512 Sybase Y N N N N N Y
2513 AnyData,DBM,CSV Y N N N Y Y* Y
2514 SQLite 3.3 N N N N Y N N
2515 MSAccess N N N N Y N Y
2516
2517* Works only because Example 0 works.
2518
2519DBI provides a sample perl script that will test the examples above
2520on your database engine and tell you which ones work. It is located
2521in the F<ex/> subdirectory of the DBI source distribution, or here:
2522L<http://svn.perl.org/modules/dbi/trunk/ex/perl_dbi_nulls_test.pl>
2523Please use the script to help us fill-in and maintain this table.
2524
2525B<Performance>
2526
2527Without using placeholders, the insert statement shown previously would have to
2528contain the literal values to be inserted and would have to be
2529re-prepared and re-executed for each row. With placeholders, the insert
2530statement only needs to be prepared once. The bind values for each row
2531can be given to the C<execute> method each time it's called. By avoiding
2532the need to re-prepare the statement for each row, the application
2533typically runs many times faster. Here's an example:
2534
2535 my $sth = $dbh->prepare(q{
2536 INSERT INTO sales (product_code, qty, price) VALUES (?, ?, ?)
2537 }) or die $dbh->errstr;
2538 while (<>) {
2539 chomp;
2540 my ($product_code, $qty, $price) = split /,/;
2541 $sth->execute($product_code, $qty, $price) or die $dbh->errstr;
2542 }
2543 $dbh->commit or die $dbh->errstr;
2544
2545See L</execute> and L</bind_param> for more details.
2546
2547The C<q{...}> style quoting used in this example avoids clashing with
2548quotes that may be used in the SQL statement. Use the double-quote like
2549C<qq{...}> operator if you want to interpolate variables into the string.
2550See L<perlop/"Quote and Quote-like Operators"> for more details.
2551
2552See also the L</bind_columns> method, which is used to associate Perl
