2553variables with the output columns of a C<SELECT> statement.
2554
2555=head1 THE DBI PACKAGE AND CLASS
2556
2557In this section, we cover the DBI class methods, utility functions,
2558and the dynamic attributes associated with generic DBI handles.
2559
2560=head2 DBI Constants
2561
2562Constants representing the values of the SQL standard types can be
2563imported individually by name, or all together by importing the
2564special C<:sql_types> tag.
2565
2566The names and values of all the defined SQL standard types can be
2567produced like this:
2568
2569 foreach (@{ $DBI::EXPORT_TAGS{sql_types} }) {
2570 printf "%s=%d\n", $_, &{"DBI::$_"};
2571 }
2572
2573These constants are defined by SQL/CLI, ODBC or both.
2574C<SQL_BIGINT> is (currently) omitted, because SQL/CLI and ODBC provide
2575conflicting codes.
2576
2577See the L</type_info>, L</type_info_all>, and L</bind_param> methods
2578for possible uses.
2579
2580Note that just because the DBI defines a named constant for a given
2581data type doesn't mean that drivers will support that data type.
2582
2583
2584=head2 DBI Class Methods
2585
2586The following methods are provided by the DBI class:
2587
2588=head3 C<parse_dsn>
2589
2590 ($scheme, $driver, $attr_string, $attr_hash, $driver_dsn) = DBI->parse_dsn($dsn)
2591 or die "Can't parse DBI DSN '$dsn'";
2592
2593Breaks apart a DBI Data Source Name (DSN) and returns the individual
2594parts. If $dsn doesn't contain a valid DSN then parse_dsn() returns
2595an empty list.
2596
2597$scheme is the first part of the DSN and is currently always 'dbi'.
2598$driver is the driver name, possibly defaulted to $ENV{DBI_DRIVER},
2599and may be undefined. $attr_string is the contents of the optional attribute
2600string, which may be undefined. If $attr_string is not empty then $attr_hash
2601is a reference to a hash containing the parsed attribute names and values.
2602$driver_dsn is the last part of the DBI DSN string. For example:
2603
2604 ($scheme, $driver, $attr_string, $attr_hash, $driver_dsn)
2605 = DBI->parse_dsn("DBI:MyDriver(RaiseError=>1):db=test;port=42");
2606 $scheme = 'dbi';
2607 $driver = 'MyDriver';
2608 $attr_string = 'RaiseError=>1';
2609 $attr_hash = { 'RaiseError' => '1' };
2610 $driver_dsn = 'db=test;port=42';
2611
2612The parse_dsn() method was added in DBI 1.43.
2613
2614=head3 C<connect>
2615
2616 $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $username, $password)
2617 or die $DBI::errstr;
2618 $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $username, $password, \%attr)
2619 or die $DBI::errstr;
2620
2621Establishes a database connection, or session, to the requested C<$data_source>.
2622Returns a database handle object if the connection succeeds. Use
2623C<$dbh-E<gt>disconnect> to terminate the connection.
2624
2625If the connect fails (see below), it returns C<undef> and sets both C<$DBI::err>
2626and C<$DBI::errstr>. (It does I<not> explicitly set C<$!>.) You should generally
2627test the return status of C<connect> and C<print $DBI::errstr> if it has failed.
2628
2629Multiple simultaneous connections to multiple databases through multiple
2630drivers can be made via the DBI. Simply make one C<connect> call for each
2631database and keep a copy of each returned database handle.
2632
2633The C<$data_source> value must begin with "C<dbi:>I<driver_name>C<:>".
2634The I<driver_name> specifies the driver that will be used to make the
2635connection. (Letter case is significant.)
2636
2637As a convenience, if the C<$data_source> parameter is undefined or empty,
2638the DBI will substitute the value of the environment variable C<DBI_DSN>.
2639If just the I<driver_name> part is empty (i.e., the C<$data_source>
2640prefix is "C<dbi::>"), the environment variable C<DBI_DRIVER> is
2641used. If neither variable is set, then C<connect> dies.
2642
2643Examples of C<$data_source> values are:
2644
2645 dbi:DriverName:database_name
2646 dbi:DriverName:database_name@hostname:port
2647 dbi:DriverName:database=database_name;host=hostname;port=port
2648
2649There is I<no standard> for the text following the driver name. Each
2650driver is free to use whatever syntax it wants. The only requirement the
2651DBI makes is that all the information is supplied in a single string.
2652You must consult the documentation for the drivers you are using for a
2653description of the syntax they require.
2654
2655It is recommended that drivers support the ODBC style, shown in the
2656last example above. It is also recommended that that they support the
2657three common names 'C<host>', 'C<port>', and 'C<database>' (plus 'C<db>'
2658as an alias for C<database>). This simplifies automatic construction
2659of basic DSNs: C<"dbi:$driver:database=$db;host=$host;port=$port">.
2660Drivers should aim to 'do something reasonable' when given a DSN
2661in this form, but if any part is meaningless for that driver (such
2662as 'port' for Informix) it should generate an error if that part
2663is not empty.
2664
2665If the environment variable C<DBI_AUTOPROXY> is defined (and the
2666driver in C<$data_source> is not "C<Proxy>") then the connect request
2667will automatically be changed to:
2668
2669 $ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY};dsn=$data_source
2670
2671C<DBI_AUTOPROXY> is typically set as "C<dbi:Proxy:hostname=...;port=...>".
2672If $ENV{DBI_AUTOPROXY} doesn't begin with 'C<dbi:>' then "dbi:Proxy:"
2673will be prepended to it first. See the DBD::Proxy documentation
2674for more details.
2675
2676If C<$username> or C<$password> are undefined (rather than just empty),
2677then the DBI will substitute the values of the C<DBI_USER> and C<DBI_PASS>
2678environment variables, respectively. The DBI will warn if the
2679environment variables are not defined. However, the everyday use
2680of these environment variables is not recommended for security
2681reasons. The mechanism is primarily intended to simplify testing.
2682See below for alternative way to specify the username and password.
2683
2684C<DBI-E<gt>connect> automatically installs the driver if it has not been
2685installed yet. Driver installation either returns a valid driver
2686handle, or it I<dies> with an error message that includes the string
2687"C<install_driver>" and the underlying problem. So C<DBI-E<gt>connect>
2688will die
2689on a driver installation failure and will only return C<undef> on a
2690connect failure, in which case C<$DBI::errstr> will hold the error message.
2691Use C<eval { ... }> if you need to catch the "C<install_driver>" error.
2692
2693The C<$data_source> argument (with the "C<dbi:...:>" prefix removed) and the
2694C<$username> and C<$password> arguments are then passed to the driver for
2695processing. The DBI does not define any interpretation for the
2696contents of these fields. The driver is free to interpret the
2697C<$data_source>, C<$username>, and C<$password> fields in any way, and supply
2698whatever defaults are appropriate for the engine being accessed.
2699(Oracle, for example, uses the ORACLE_SID and TWO_TASK environment
2700variables if no C<$data_source> is specified.)
2701
2702The C<AutoCommit> and C<PrintError> attributes for each connection
2703default to "on". (See L</AutoCommit> and L</PrintError> for more information.)
2704However, it is strongly recommended that you explicitly define C<AutoCommit>
2705rather than rely on the default. The C<PrintWarn> attribute defaults to
2706on if $^W is true, i.e., perl is running with warnings enabled.
2707
2708The C<\%attr> parameter can be used to alter the default settings of
2709C<PrintError>, C<RaiseError>, C<AutoCommit>, and other attributes. For example:
2710
2711 $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $user, $pass, {
2712 PrintError => 0,
2713 AutoCommit => 0
2714 });
2715
2716The username and password can also be specified using the attributes
2717C<Username> and C<Password>, in which case they take precedence
2718over the C<$username> and C<$password> parameters.
2719
2720You can also define connection attribute values within the C<$data_source>
2721parameter. For example:
2722
2723 dbi:DriverName(PrintWarn=>1,PrintError=>0,Taint=>1):...
2724
2725Individual attributes values specified in this way take precedence over
2726any conflicting values specified via the C<\%attr> parameter to C<connect>.
2727
2728The C<dbi_connect_method> attribute can be used to specify which driver
2729method should be called to establish the connection. The only useful
2730values are 'connect', 'connect_cached', or some specialized case like
2731'Apache::DBI::connect' (which is automatically the default when running
2732within Apache).
2733
2734Where possible, each session (C<$dbh>) is independent from the transactions
2735in other sessions. This is useful when you need to hold cursors open
2736across transactions--for example, if you use one session for your long lifespan
2737cursors (typically read-only) and another for your short update
2738transactions.
2739
2740For compatibility with old DBI scripts, the driver can be specified by
2741passing its name as the fourth argument to C<connect> (instead of C<\%attr>):
2742
2743 $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $user, $pass, $driver);
2744
2745In this "old-style" form of C<connect>, the C<$data_source> should not start
2746with "C<dbi:driver_name:>". (If it does, the embedded driver_name
2747will be ignored). Also note that in this older form of C<connect>,
2748the C<$dbh-E<gt>{AutoCommit}> attribute is I<undefined>, the
2749C<$dbh-E<gt>{PrintError}> attribute is off, and the old C<DBI_DBNAME>
2750environment variable is
2751checked if C<DBI_DSN> is not defined. Beware that this "old-style"
2752C<connect> will soon be withdrawn in a future version of DBI.
2753
2754=head3 C<connect_cached>
2755
2756 $dbh = DBI->connect_cached($data_source, $username, $password)
2757 or die $DBI::errstr;
2758 $dbh = DBI->connect_cached($data_source, $username, $password, \%attr)
2759 or die $DBI::errstr;
2760
2761C<connect_cached> is like L</connect>, except that the database handle
2762returned is also
2763stored in a hash associated with the given parameters. If another call
2764is made to C<connect_cached> with the same parameter values, then the
2765corresponding cached C<$dbh> will be returned if it is still valid.
2766The cached database handle is replaced with a new connection if it
2767has been disconnected or if the C<ping> method fails.
2768
2769Note that the behaviour of this method differs in several respects from the
2770behaviour of persistent connections implemented by Apache::DBI.
2771However, if Apache::DBI is loaded then C<connect_cached> will use it.
2772
2773Caching connections can be useful in some applications, but it can
2774also cause problems, such as too many connections, and so should
2775be used with care. In particular, avoid changing the attributes of
2776a database handle created via connect_cached() because it will affect
2777other code that may be using the same handle. When connect_cached()
2778returns a handle the attributes will be reset to their initial values.
2779This can cause problems, especially with the C<AutoCommit> attribute.
2780
2781Where multiple separate parts of a program are using connect_cached()
2782to connect to the same database with the same (initial) attributes
2783it is a good idea to add a private attribute to the connect_cached()
2784call to effectively limit the scope of the caching. For example:
2785
2786 DBI->connect_cached(..., { private_foo_cachekey => "Bar", ... });
2787
2788Handles returned from that connect_cached() call will only be returned
2789by other connect_cached() call elsewhere in the code if those other
2790calls also pass in the same attribute values, including the private one.
2791(I've used C<private_foo_cachekey> here as an example, you can use
2792any attribute name with a C<private_> prefix.)
2793
2794Taking that one step further, you can limit a particular connect_cached()
2795call to return handles unique to that one place in the code by setting the
2796private attribute to a unique value for that place:
2797
2798 DBI->connect_cached(..., { private_foo_cachekey => __FILE__.__LINE__, ... });
2799
2800By using a private attribute you still get connection caching for
2801the individual calls to connect_cached() but, by making separate
2802database connections for separate parts of the code, the database
2803handles are isolated from any attribute changes made to other handles.
2804
2805The cache can be accessed (and cleared) via the L</CachedKids> attribute:
2806
2807 my $CachedKids_hashref = $dbh->{Driver}->{CachedKids};
2808 %$CachedKids_hashref = () if $CachedKids_hashref;
2809
2810
2811=head3 C<available_drivers>
2812
2813 @ary = DBI->available_drivers;
2814 @ary = DBI->available_drivers($quiet);
2815
2816Returns a list of all available drivers by searching for C<DBD::*> modules
2817through the directories in C<@INC>. By default, a warning is given if
2818some drivers are hidden by others of the same name in earlier
2819directories. Passing a true value for C<$quiet> will inhibit the warning.
2820
2821=head3 C<installed_drivers>
2822
2823 %drivers = DBI->installed_drivers();
2824
2825Returns a list of driver name and driver handle pairs for all drivers
2826'installed' (loaded) into the current process. The driver name does not
2827include the 'DBD::' prefix.
2828
2829To get a list of all drivers available in your perl installation you can use
2830L</available_drivers>.
2831
2832Added in DBI 1.49.
2833
2834=head3 C<installed_versions>
2835
2836 DBI->installed_versions;
2837 @ary = DBI->installed_versions;
2838 %hash = DBI->installed_versions;
2839
2840Calls available_drivers() and attempts to load each of them in turn
2841using install_driver(). For each load that succeeds the driver
2842name and version number are added to a hash. When running under
2843L<DBI::PurePerl> drivers which appear not be pure-perl are ignored.
2844
2845When called in array context the list of successfully loaded drivers
2846is returned (without the 'DBD::' prefix).
2847
2848When called in scalar context a reference to the hash is returned
2849and the hash will also contain other entries for the C<DBI> version,
2850C<OS> name, etc.
2851
2852When called in a void context the installed_versions() method will
2853print out a formatted list of the hash contents, one per line.
2854
2855Due to the potentially high memory cost and unknown risks of loading
2856in an unknown number of drivers that just happen to be installed
2857on the system, this method is not recommended for general use.
2858Use available_drivers() instead.
2859
2860The installed_versions() method is primarily intended as a quick
2861way to see from the command line what's installed. For example:
2862
2863 perl -MDBI -e 'DBI->installed_versions'
2864
2865The installed_versions() method was added in DBI 1.38.
2866
2867=head3 C<data_sources>
2868
2869 @ary = DBI->data_sources($driver);
2870 @ary = DBI->data_sources($driver, \%attr);
2871
2872Returns a list of data sources (databases) available via the named
2873driver. If C<$driver> is empty or C<undef>, then the value of the
2874C<DBI_DRIVER> environment variable is used.
2875
2876The driver will be loaded if it hasn't been already. Note that if the
2877driver loading fails then data_sources() I<dies> with an error message
2878that includes the string "C<install_driver>" and the underlying problem.
2879
2880Data sources are returned in a form suitable for passing to the
2881L</connect> method (that is, they will include the "C<dbi:$driver:>" prefix).
2882
2883Note that many drivers have no way of knowing what data sources might
2884be available for it. These drivers return an empty or incomplete list
2885or may require driver-specific attributes.
2886
2887There is also a data_sources() method defined for database handles.
2888
2889
2890=head3 C<trace>
2891
2892 DBI->trace($trace_setting)
2893 DBI->trace($trace_setting, $trace_filename)
2894 DBI->trace($trace_setting, $trace_filehandle)
2895 $trace_setting = DBI->trace;
2896
2897The C<DBI-E<gt>trace> method sets the I<global default> trace
2898settings and returns the I<previous> trace settings. It can also
2899be used to change where the trace output is sent.
2900
2901There's a similar method, C<$h-E<gt>trace>, which sets the trace
2902settings for the specific handle it's called on.
2903
2904See the L</TRACING> section for full details about the DBI's powerful
2905tracing facilities.
2906
2907
2908=head3 C<visit_handles>
2909
2910 DBI->visit_handles( $coderef );
2911 DBI->visit_handles( $coderef, $info );
2912
2913Where $coderef is a reference to a subroutine and $info is an arbitrary value
2914which, if undefined, defaults to a reference to an empty hash. Returns $info.
2915
2916For each installed driver handle, if any, $coderef is invoked as:
2917
2918 $coderef->($driver_handle, $info);
2919
2920If the execution of $coderef returns a true value then L</visit_child_handles>
2921is called on that child handle and passed the returned value as $info.
2922
2923For example:
2924
2925 my $info = $dbh->{Driver}->visit_child_handles(sub {
2926 my ($h, $info) = @_;
2927 ++$info->{ $h->{Type} }; # count types of handles (dr/db/st)
2928 return $info; # visit kids
2929 });
2930
2931See also L</visit_child_handles>.
2932
2933=head2 DBI Utility Functions
2934
2935In addition to the DBI methods listed in the previous section,
2936the DBI package also provides several utility functions.
2937
2938These can be imported into your code by listing them in
2939the C<use> statement. For example:
2940
2941 use DBI qw(neat data_diff);
2942
2943Alternatively, all these utility functions (except hash) can be
2944imported using the C<:utils> import tag. For example:
2945
2946 use DBI qw(:utils);
2947
2948=head3 C<data_string_desc>
2949
2950 $description = data_string_desc($string);
2951
2952Returns an informal description of the string. For example:
2953
2954 UTF8 off, ASCII, 42 characters 42 bytes
2955 UTF8 off, non-ASCII, 42 characters 42 bytes
2956 UTF8 on, non-ASCII, 4 characters 6 bytes
2957 UTF8 on but INVALID encoding, non-ASCII, 4 characters 6 bytes
2958 UTF8 off, undef
2959
2960The initial C<UTF8> on/off refers to Perl's internal SvUTF8 flag.
2961If $string has the SvUTF8 flag set but the sequence of bytes it
2962contains are not a valid UTF-8 encoding then data_string_desc()
2963will report C<UTF8 on but INVALID encoding>.
2964
2965The C<ASCII> vs C<non-ASCII> portion shows C<ASCII> if I<all> the
2966characters in the string are ASCII (have code points <= 127).
2967
2968The data_string_desc() function was added in DBI 1.46.
2969
2970=head3 C<data_string_diff>
2971
2972 $diff = data_string_diff($a, $b);
2973
2974Returns an informal description of the first character difference
2975between the strings. If both $a and $b contain the same sequence
2976of characters then data_string_diff() returns an empty string.
2977For example:
2978
2979 Params a & b Result
2980 ------------ ------
2981 'aaa', 'aaa' ''
2982 'aaa', 'abc' 'Strings differ at index 2: a[2]=a, b[2]=b'
2983 'aaa', undef 'String b is undef, string a has 3 characters'
2984 'aaa', 'aa' 'String b truncated after 2 characters'
2985
2986Unicode characters are reported in C<\x{XXXX}> format. Unicode
2987code points in the range U+0800 to U+08FF are unassigned and most
2988likely to occur due to double-encoding. Characters in this range
2989are reported as C<\x{08XX}='C'> where C<C> is the corresponding
2990latin-1 character.
2991
2992The data_string_diff() function only considers logical I<characters>
2993and not the underlying encoding. See L</data_diff> for an alternative.
2994
2995The data_string_diff() function was added in DBI 1.46.
2996
2997=head3 C<data_diff>
2998
2999 $diff = data_diff($a, $b);
3000 $diff = data_diff($a, $b, $logical);
3001
3002Returns an informal description of the difference between two strings.
3003It calls L</data_string_desc> and L</data_string_diff>
3004and returns the combined results as a multi-line string.
3005
3006For example, C<data_diff("abc", "ab\x{263a}")> will return:
3007
3008 a: UTF8 off, ASCII, 3 characters 3 bytes
3009 b: UTF8 on, non-ASCII, 3 characters 5 bytes
3010 Strings differ at index 2: a[2]=c, b[2]=\x{263A}
3011
3012If $a and $b are identical in both the characters they contain I<and>
3013their physical encoding then data_diff() returns an empty string.
3014If $logical is true then physical encoding differences are ignored
3015(but are still reported if there is a difference in the characters).
3016
3017The data_diff() function was added in DBI 1.46.
3018
3019=head3 C<neat>
3020
3021 $str = neat($value);
3022 $str = neat($value, $maxlen);
3023
3024Return a string containing a neat (and tidy) representation of the
3025supplied value.
3026
3027Strings will be quoted, although internal quotes will I<not> be escaped.
3028Values known to be numeric will be unquoted. Undefined (NULL) values
3029will be shown as C<undef> (without quotes).
3030
3031If the string is flagged internally as utf8 then double quotes will
3032be used, otherwise single quotes are used and unprintable characters
3033will be replaced by dot (.).
3034
3035For result strings longer than C<$maxlen> the result string will be
3036truncated to C<$maxlen-4> and "C<...'>" will be appended. If C<$maxlen> is 0
3037or C<undef>, it defaults to C<$DBI::neat_maxlen> which, in turn, defaults to 400.
3038
3039This function is designed to format values for human consumption.
3040It is used internally by the DBI for L</trace> output. It should
3041typically I<not> be used for formatting values for database use.
3042(See also L</quote>.)
3043
3044=head3 C<neat_list>
3045
3046 $str = neat_list(\@listref, $maxlen, $field_sep);
3047
3048Calls C<neat> on each element of the list and returns a string
3049containing the results joined with C<$field_sep>. C<$field_sep> defaults
3050to C<", ">.
3051
3052=head3 C<looks_like_number>
3053
3054 @bool = looks_like_number(@array);
3055
3056Returns true for each element that looks like a number.
3057Returns false for each element that does not look like a number.
3058Returns C<undef> for each element that is undefined or empty.
3059
3060=head3 C<hash>
3061
3062 $hash_value = DBI::hash($buffer, $type);
3063
3064Return a 32-bit integer 'hash' value corresponding to the contents of $buffer.
3065The $type parameter selects which kind of hash algorithm should be used.
3066
3067For the technically curious, type 0 (which is the default if $type
3068isn't specified) is based on the Perl 5.1 hash except that the value
3069is forced to be negative (for obscure historical reasons).
3070Type 1 is the better "Fowler / Noll / Vo" (FNV) hash. See
3071L<http://www.isthe.com/chongo/tech/comp/fnv/> for more information.
3072Both types are implemented in C and are very fast.
3073
3074This function doesn't have much to do with databases, except that
3075it can be handy to store hash values in a database.
3076
3077=head3 C<sql_type_cast>
3078
3079 $sts = DBI->sql_type_cast($sv, $sql_type, $flags);
3080
3081sql_type_cast attempts to cast C<$sv> to the SQL type (see L<DBI
3082Constants>) specified in C<$sql_type>. At present only the SQL types
3083C<SQL_INTEGER>, C<SQL_DOUBLE> and C<SQL_NUMERIC> are supported.
3084
3085For C<SQL_INTEGER> the effect is similar to using the value in an expression
3086that requires an integer. It gives the perl scalar an 'integer aspect'.
3087(Technically the value gains an IV, or possibly a UV or NV if the value is too
3088large for an IV.)
3089
3090For C<SQL_DOUBLE> the effect is similar to using the value in an expression
3091that requires a general numeric value. It gives the perl scalar a 'numeric
3092aspect'. (Technically the value gains an NV.)
3093
3094C<SQL_NUMERIC> is similar to C<SQL_INTEGER> or C<SQL_DOUBLE> but more
3095general and more cautious. It will look at the string first and if it
3096looks like an integer (that will fit in an IV or UV) it will act like
3097C<SQL_INTEGER>, if it looks like a floating point value it will act
3098like C<SQL_DOUBLE>, if it looks like neither then it will do nothing -
3099and thereby avoid the warnings that would be generated by
3100C<SQL_INTEGER> and C<SQL_DOUBLE> when given non-numeric data.
3101
3102C<$flags> may be:
3103
3104=over 4
3105
3106=item C<DBIstcf_DISCARD_STRING>
3107
3108If this flag is specified then when the driver successfully casts the
3109bound perl scalar to a non-string type then the string portion of the
3110scalar will be discarded.
3111
3112=item C<DBIstcf_STRICT>
3113
3114If C<$sv> cannot be cast to the requested C<$sql_type> then by default
3115it is left untouched and no error is generated. If you specify
3116C<DBIstcf_STRICT> and the cast fails, this will generate an error.
3117
3118=back
3119
3120The returned C<$sts> value is:
3121
3122 -2 sql_type is not handled
3123 -1 sv is undef so unchanged
3124 0 sv could not be cast cleanly and DBIstcf_STRICT was used
3125 1 sv could not be case and DBIstcf_STRICT was not used
3126 2 sv was cast successfully
3127
3128This method is exported by the :utils tag and was introduced in DBI
31291.611.
3130
3131=head2 DBI Dynamic Attributes
3132
3133Dynamic attributes are always associated with the I<last handle used>
3134(that handle is represented by C<$h> in the descriptions below).
3135
3136Where an attribute is equivalent to a method call, then refer to
3137the method call for all related documentation.
3138
3139Warning: these attributes are provided as a convenience but they
3140do have limitations. Specifically, they have a short lifespan:
3141because they are associated with
3142the last handle used, they should only be used I<immediately> after
3143calling the method that "sets" them.
3144If in any doubt, use the corresponding method call.
3145
3146=head3 C<$DBI::err>
3147
3148Equivalent to C<$h-E<gt>err>.
3149
3150=head3 C<$DBI::errstr>
3151
3152Equivalent to C<$h-E<gt>errstr>.
3153
3154=head3 C<$DBI::state>
3155
3156Equivalent to C<$h-E<gt>state>.
3157
3158=head3 C<$DBI::rows>
3159
3160Equivalent to C<$h-E<gt>rows>. Please refer to the documentation
3161for the L</rows> method.
3162
3163=head3 C<$DBI::lasth>
3164
3165Returns the DBI object handle used for the most recent DBI method call.
3166If the last DBI method call was a DESTROY then $DBI::lasth will return
3167the handle of the parent of the destroyed handle, if there is one.
3168
3169
3170=head1 METHODS COMMON TO ALL HANDLES
3171
3172The following methods can be used by all types of DBI handles.
3173
3174=head3 C<err>
3175
3176 $rv = $h->err;
3177
3178Returns the I<native> database engine error code from the last driver
3179method called. The code is typically an integer but you should not
3180assume that.
3181
3182The DBI resets $h->err to undef before almost all DBI method calls, so the
3183value only has a short lifespan. Also, for most drivers, the statement
3184handles share the same error variable as the parent database handle,
3185so calling a method on one handle may reset the error on the
3186related handles.
3187
3188(Methods which don't reset err before being called include err() and errstr(),
3189obviously, state(), rows(), func(), trace(), trace_msg(), ping(), and the
3190tied hash attribute FETCH() and STORE() methods.)
3191
3192If you need to test for specific error conditions I<and> have your program be
3193portable to different database engines, then you'll need to determine what the
3194corresponding error codes are for all those engines and test for all of them.
3195
3196The DBI uses the value of $DBI::stderr as the C<err> value for internal errors.
3197Drivers should also do likewise. The default value for $DBI::stderr is 2000000000.
3198
3199A driver may return C<0> from err() to indicate a warning condition
3200after a method call. Similarly, a driver may return an empty string
3201to indicate a 'success with information' condition. In both these
3202cases the value is false but not undef. The errstr() and state()
3203methods may be used to retrieve extra information in these cases.
3204
3205See L</set_err> for more information.
3206
3207=head3 C<errstr>
3208
3209 $str = $h->errstr;
3210
3211Returns the native database engine error message from the last DBI
3212method called. This has the same lifespan issues as the L</err> method
3213described above.
3214
3215The returned string may contain multiple messages separated by
3216newline characters.
3217
3218The errstr() method should not be used to test for errors, use err()
3219for that, because drivers may return 'success with information' or
3220warning messages via errstr() for methods that have not 'failed'.
3221
3222See L</set_err> for more information.
3223
3224=head3 C<state>
3225
3226 $str = $h->state;
3227
3228Returns a state code in the standard SQLSTATE five character format.
3229Note that the specific success code C<00000> is translated to any empty string
3230(false). If the driver does not support SQLSTATE (and most don't),
3231then state() will return C<S1000> (General Error) for all errors.
3232
3233The driver is free to return any value via C<state>, e.g., warning
3234codes, even if it has not declared an error by returning a true value
3235via the L</err> method described above.
3236
3237The state() method should not be used to test for errors, use err()
3238for that, because drivers may return a 'success with information' or
3239warning state code via state() for methods that have not 'failed'.
3240
3241=head3 C<set_err>
3242
3243 $rv = $h->set_err($err, $errstr);
3244 $rv = $h->set_err($err, $errstr, $state);
3245 $rv = $h->set_err($err, $errstr, $state, $method);
3246 $rv = $h->set_err($err, $errstr, $state, $method, $rv);
3247
3248Set the C<err>, C<errstr>, and C<state> values for the handle.
3249This method is typically only used by DBI drivers and DBI subclasses.
3250
3251If the L</HandleSetErr> attribute holds a reference to a subroutine
3252it is called first. The subroutine can alter the $err, $errstr, $state,
3253and $method values. See L</HandleSetErr> for full details.
3254If the subroutine returns a true value then the handle C<err>,
3255C<errstr>, and C<state> values are not altered and set_err() returns
3256an empty list (it normally returns $rv which defaults to undef, see below).
3257
3258Setting C<err> to a I<true> value indicates an error and will trigger
3259the normal DBI error handling mechanisms, such as C<RaiseError> and
3260C<HandleError>, if they are enabled, when execution returns from
3261the DBI back to the application.
3262
3263Setting C<err> to C<""> indicates an 'information' state, and setting
3264it to C<"0"> indicates a 'warning' state. Setting C<err> to C<undef>
3265also sets C<errstr> to undef, and C<state> to C<"">, irrespective
3266of the values of the $errstr and $state parameters.
3267
3268The $method parameter provides an alternate method name for the
3269C<RaiseError>/C<PrintError>/C<PrintWarn> error string instead of
3270the fairly unhelpful 'C<set_err>'.
3271
3272The C<set_err> method normally returns undef. The $rv parameter
3273provides an alternate return value.
3274
3275Some special rules apply if the C<err> or C<errstr>
3276values for the handle are I<already> set...
3277
3278If C<errstr> is true then: "C< [err was %s now %s]>" is appended if $err is
3279true and C<err> is already true and the new err value differs from the original
3280one. Similarly "C< [state was %s now %s]>" is appended if $state is true and C<state> is
3281already true and the new state value differs from the original one. Finally
3282"C<\n>" and the new $errstr are appended if $errstr differs from the existing
3283errstr value. Obviously the C<%s>'s above are replaced by the corresponding values.
3284
3285The handle C<err> value is set to $err if: $err is true; or handle
3286C<err> value is undef; or $err is defined and the length is greater
3287than the handle C<err> length. The effect is that an 'information'
3288state only overrides undef; a 'warning' overrides undef or 'information',
3289and an 'error' state overrides anything.
3290
3291The handle C<state> value is set to $state if $state is true and
3292the handle C<err> value was set (by the rules above).
3293
3294Support for warning and information states was added in DBI 1.41.
3295
3296=head3 C<trace>
3297
3298 $h->trace($trace_settings);
3299 $h->trace($trace_settings, $trace_filename);
3300 $trace_settings = $h->trace;
3301
3302The trace() method is used to alter the trace settings for a handle
3303(and any future children of that handle). It can also be used to
3304change where the trace output is sent.
3305
3306There's a similar method, C<DBI-E<gt>trace>, which sets the global
3307default trace settings.
3308
3309See the L</TRACING> section for full details about the DBI's powerful
3310tracing facilities.
3311
3312=head3 C<trace_msg>
3313
3314 $h->trace_msg($message_text);
3315 $h->trace_msg($message_text, $min_level);
3316
3317Writes C<$message_text> to the trace file if the trace level is
3318greater than or equal to $min_level (which defaults to 1).
3319Can also be called as C<DBI-E<gt>trace_msg($msg)>.
3320
3321See L</TRACING> for more details.
3322
3323=head3 C<func>
3324
3325 $h->func(@func_arguments, $func_name) or die ...;
3326
3327The C<func> method can be used to call private non-standard and
3328non-portable methods implemented by the driver. Note that the function
3329name is given as the I<last> argument.
3330
3331It's also important to note that the func() method does not clear
3332a previous error ($DBI::err etc.) and it does not trigger automatic
3333error detection (RaiseError etc.) so you must check the return
3334status and/or $h->err to detect errors.
3335
3336(This method is not directly related to calling stored procedures.
3337Calling stored procedures is currently not defined by the DBI.
3338Some drivers, such as DBD::Oracle, support it in non-portable ways.
3339See driver documentation for more details.)
3340
3341See also install_method() in L<DBI::DBD> for how you can avoid needing to
3342use func() and gain direct access to driver-private methods.
3343
3344=head3 C<can>
3345
3346 $is_implemented = $h->can($method_name);
3347
3348Returns true if $method_name is implemented by the driver or a
3349default method is provided by the DBI.
3350It returns false where a driver hasn't implemented a method and the
3351default method is provided by the DBI is just an empty stub.
3352
3353=head3 C<parse_trace_flags>
3354
3355 $trace_settings_integer = $h->parse_trace_flags($trace_settings);
3356
3357Parses a string containing trace settings and returns the corresponding
3358integer value used internally by the DBI and drivers.
3359
3360The $trace_settings argument is a string containing a trace level
3361between 0 and 15 and/or trace flag names separated by vertical bar
3362("C<|>") or comma ("C<,>") characters. For example: C<"SQL|3|foo">.
3363
3364It uses the parse_trace_flag() method, described below, to process
3365the individual trace flag names.
3366
3367The parse_trace_flags() method was added in DBI 1.42.
3368
3369=head3 C<parse_trace_flag>
3370
3371 $bit_flag = $h->parse_trace_flag($trace_flag_name);
3372
3373Returns the bit flag corresponding to the trace flag name in
3374$trace_flag_name. Drivers are expected to override this method and
3375check if $trace_flag_name is a driver specific trace flags and, if
3376not, then call the DBI's default parse_trace_flag().
3377
3378The parse_trace_flag() method was added in DBI 1.42.
3379
3380=head3 C<private_attribute_info>
3381
3382 $hash_ref = $h->private_attribute_info();
3383
3384Returns a reference to a hash whose keys are the names of driver-private
3385handle attributes available for the kind of handle (driver, database, statement)
3386that the method was called on.
3387
3388For example, the return value when called with a DBD::Sybase $dbh could look like this:
3389
3390 {
3391 syb_dynamic_supported => undef,
3392 syb_oc_version => undef,
3393 syb_server_version => undef,
3394 syb_server_version_string => undef,
3395 }
3396
3397and when called with a DBD::Sybase $sth they could look like this:
3398
3399 {
3400 syb_types => undef,
3401 syb_proc_status => undef,
3402 syb_result_type => undef,
3403 }
3404
3405The values should be undef. Meanings may be assigned to particular values in future.
3406
3407=head3 C<swap_inner_handle>
3408
3409 $rc = $h1->swap_inner_handle( $h2 );
3410 $rc = $h1->swap_inner_handle( $h2, $allow_reparent );
3411
3412Brain transplants for handles. You don't need to know about this
3413unless you want to become a handle surgeon.
3414
3415A DBI handle is a reference to a tied hash. A tied hash has an
3416I<inner> hash that actually holds the contents. The swap_inner_handle()
3417method swaps the inner hashes between two handles. The $h1 and $h2
3418handles still point to the same tied hashes, but what those hashes
3419are tied to has been swapped. In effect $h1 I<becomes> $h2 and
3420vice-versa. This is powerful stuff, expect problems. Use with care.
3421
3422As a small safety measure, the two handles, $h1 and $h2, have to
3423share the same parent unless $allow_reparent is true.
3424
3425The swap_inner_handle() method was added in DBI 1.44.
3426
3427Here's a quick kind of 'diagram' as a worked example to help think about what's
3428happening:
3429
3430 Original state:
3431 dbh1o -> dbh1i
3432 sthAo -> sthAi(dbh1i)
3433 dbh2o -> dbh2i
3434
3435 swap_inner_handle dbh1o with dbh2o:
3436 dbh2o -> dbh1i
3437 sthAo -> sthAi(dbh1i)
3438 dbh1o -> dbh2i
3439
3440 create new sth from dbh1o:
3441 dbh2o -> dbh1i
3442 sthAo -> sthAi(dbh1i)
3443 dbh1o -> dbh2i
3444 sthBo -> sthBi(dbh2i)
3445
3446 swap_inner_handle sthAo with sthBo:
3447 dbh2o -> dbh1i
3448 sthBo -> sthAi(dbh1i)
3449 dbh1o -> dbh2i
3450 sthAo -> sthBi(dbh2i)
3451
3452=head3 C<visit_child_handles>
3453
3454 $h->visit_child_handles( $coderef );
3455 $h->visit_child_handles( $coderef, $info );
3456
3457Where $coderef is a reference to a subroutine and $info is an arbitrary value
3458which, if undefined, defaults to a reference to an empty hash. Returns $info.
3459
3460For each child handle of $h, if any, $coderef is invoked as:
3461
3462 $coderef->($child_handle, $info);
3463
3464If the execution of $coderef returns a true value then C<visit_child_handles>
3465is called on that child handle and passed the returned value as $info.
3466
3467For example:
3468
3469 # count database connections with names (DSN) matching a pattern
3470 my $connections = 0;
3471 $dbh->{Driver}->visit_child_handles(sub {
3472 my ($h, $info) = @_;
3473 ++$connections if $h->{Name} =~ /foo/;
3474 return 0; # don't visit kids
3475 })
3476
3477See also L</visit_handles>.
3478
3479=head1 ATTRIBUTES COMMON TO ALL HANDLES
3480
3481These attributes are common to all types of DBI handles.
3482
3483Some attributes are inherited by child handles. That is, the value
3484of an inherited attribute in a newly created statement handle is the
3485same as the value in the parent database handle. Changes to attributes
3486in the new statement handle do not affect the parent database handle
3487and changes to the database handle do not affect existing statement
3488handles, only future ones.
3489
3490Attempting to set or get the value of an unknown attribute generates a warning,
3491except for private driver specific attributes (which all have names
3492starting with a lowercase letter).
3493
3494Example:
3495
3496 $h->{AttributeName} = ...; # set/write
3497 ... = $h->{AttributeName}; # get/read
3498
3499=head3 C<Warn>
3500
3501Type: boolean, inherited
3502
3503The C<Warn> attribute enables useful warnings for certain bad
3504practices. It is enabled by default and should only be disabled in
3505rare circumstances. Since warnings are generated using the Perl
3506C<warn> function, they can be intercepted using the Perl C<$SIG{__WARN__}>
3507hook.
3508
3509The C<Warn> attribute is not related to the C<PrintWarn> attribute.
3510
3511=head3 C<Active>
3512
3513Type: boolean, read-only
3514
3515The C<Active> attribute is true if the handle object is "active". This is rarely used in
3516applications. The exact meaning of active is somewhat vague at the
3517moment. For a database handle it typically means that the handle is
3518connected to a database (C<$dbh-E<gt>disconnect> sets C<Active> off). For
3519a statement handle it typically means that the handle is a C<SELECT>
3520that may have more data to fetch. (Fetching all the data or calling C<$sth-E<gt>finish>
3521sets C<Active> off.)
3522
3523=head3 C<Executed>
3524
3525Type: boolean
3526
3527The C<Executed> attribute is true if the handle object has been "executed".
3528Currently only the $dbh do() method and the $sth execute(), execute_array(),
3529and execute_for_fetch() methods set the C<Executed> attribute.
3530
3531When it's set on a handle it is also set on the parent handle at the
3532same time. So calling execute() on a $sth also sets the C<Executed>
3533attribute on the parent $dbh.
3534
3535The C<Executed> attribute for a database handle is cleared by the commit() and
3536rollback() methods (even if they fail). The C<Executed> attribute of a
3537statement handle is not cleared by the DBI under any circumstances and so acts
3538as a permanent record of whether the statement handle was ever used.
3539
3540The C<Executed> attribute was added in DBI 1.41.
3541
3542=head3 C<Kids>
3543
3544Type: integer, read-only
3545
3546For a driver handle, C<Kids> is the number of currently existing database
3547handles that were created from that driver handle. For a database
3548handle, C<Kids> is the number of currently existing statement handles that
3549were created from that database handle.
3550For a statement handle, the value is zero.
3551
3552=head3 C<ActiveKids>
3553
3554Type: integer, read-only
3555
3556Like C<Kids>, but only counting those that are C<Active> (as above).
3557
3558=head3 C<CachedKids>
3559
3560Type: hash ref
3561
3562For a database handle, C<CachedKids> returns a reference to the cache (hash) of
3563statement handles created by the L</prepare_cached> method. For a
3564driver handle, returns a reference to the cache (hash) of
3565database handles created by the L</connect_cached> method.
3566
3567=head3 C<Type>
3568
3569Type: scalar, read-only
3570
3571The C<Type> attribute identifies the type of a DBI handle. Returns
3572"dr" for driver handles, "db" for database handles and "st" for
3573statement handles.
3574
3575=head3 C<ChildHandles>
3576
3577Type: array ref
3578
3579The ChildHandles attribute contains a reference to an array of all the
3580handles created by this handle which are still accessible. The
3581contents of the array are weak-refs and will become undef when the
3582handle goes out of scope.
3583
3584C<ChildHandles> returns undef if your perl version does not support weak
3585references (check the L<Scalar::Util|Scalar::Util> module). The referenced
3586array returned should be treated as read-only.
3587
3588For example, to enumerate all driver handles, database handles and
3589statement handles:
3590
3591 sub show_child_handles {
3592 my ($h, $level) = @_;
3593 printf "%sh %s %s\n", $h->{Type}, "\t" x $level, $h;
3594 show_child_handles($_, $level + 1)
3595 for (grep { defined } @{$h->{ChildHandles}});
3596 }
3597
3598 my %drivers = DBI->installed_drivers();
3599 show_child_handles($_, 0) for (values %drivers);
3600
3601=head3 C<CompatMode>
3602
3603Type: boolean, inherited
3604
3605The C<CompatMode> attribute is used by emulation layers (such as
3606Oraperl) to enable compatible behaviour in the underlying driver
3607(e.g., DBD::Oracle) for this handle. Not normally set by application code.
3608
3609It also has the effect of disabling the 'quick FETCH' of attribute
3610values from the handles attribute cache. So all attribute values
3611are handled by the drivers own FETCH method. This makes them slightly
3612slower but is useful for special-purpose drivers like DBD::Multiplex.
3613
3614=head3 C<InactiveDestroy>
3615
3616Type: boolean
3617
3618The default value, false, means a handle will be fully destroyed
3619as normal when the last reference to it is removed, just as you'd expect.
3620
3621If set true then the handle will be treated by the DESTROY as if it was no
3622longer Active, and so the I<database engine> related effects of DESTROYing a
3623handle will be skipped. Think of the name as meaning 'treat the handle as
3624not-Active in the DESTROY method'.
3625
3626For a database handle, this attribute does not disable an I<explicit>
3627call to the disconnect method, only the implicit call from DESTROY
3628that happens if the handle is still marked as C<Active>.
3629
3630This attribute is specifically designed for use in Unix applications
3631that "fork" child processes. For some drivers, when the child process exits
3632the destruction of inherited handles cause the corresponding handles in the
3633parent process to cease working.
3634
3635Either the parent or the child process, but not both, should set
3636C<InactiveDestroy> true on all their shared handles. Alternatively the
3637L</AutoInactiveDestroy> can be set in the parent on connect.
3638
3639To help tracing applications using fork the process id is shown in
3640the trace log whenever a DBI or handle trace() method is called.
3641The process id also shown for I<every> method call if the DBI trace
3642level (not handle trace level) is set high enough to show the trace
3643from the DBI's method dispatcher, e.g. >= 9.
3644
3645=head3 C<AutoInactiveDestroy>
3646
3647Type: boolean, inherited
3648
3649The L</InactiveDestroy> attribute, described above, needs to be explicitly set
3650in the child process after a fork(). This is a problem if the code that performs
3651the fork() is not under your control, perhaps in a third-party module.
3652Use C<AutoInactiveDestroy> to get around this situation.
3653
3654If set true, the DESTROY method will check the process id of the handle and, if
3655different from the current process id, it will set the I<InactiveDestroy> attribute.
3656
3657This is the example it's designed to deal with:
3658
3659 my $dbh = DBI->connect(...);
3660 some_code_that_forks(); # Perhaps without your knowledge
3661 # Child process dies, destroying the inherited dbh
3662 $dbh->do(...); # Breaks because parent $dbh is now broken
3663
3664The C<AutoInactiveDestroy> attribute was added in DBI 1.614.
3665
3666=head3 C<PrintWarn>
3667
3668Type: boolean, inherited
3669
3670The C<PrintWarn> attribute controls the printing of warnings recorded
3671by the driver. When set to a true value the DBI will check method
3672calls to see if a warning condition has been set. If so, the DBI
3673will effectively do a C<warn("$class $method warning: $DBI::errstr")>
3674where C<$class> is the driver class and C<$method> is the name of
3675the method which failed. E.g.,
3676
3677 DBD::Oracle::db execute warning: ... warning text here ...
3678
3679By default, C<DBI-E<gt>connect> sets C<PrintWarn> "on" if $^W is true,
3680i.e., perl is running with warnings enabled.
3681
3682If desired, the warnings can be caught and processed using a C<$SIG{__WARN__}>
3683handler or modules like CGI::Carp and CGI::ErrorWrap.
3684
3685See also L</set_err> for how warnings are recorded and L</HandleSetErr>
3686for how to influence it.
3687
3688Fetching the full details of warnings can require an extra round-trip
3689to the database server for some drivers. In which case the driver
3690may opt to only fetch the full details of warnings if the C<PrintWarn>
3691attribute is true. If C<PrintWarn> is false then these drivers should
3692still indicate the fact that there were warnings by setting the
3693warning string to, for example: "3 warnings".
3694
3695=head3 C<PrintError>
3696
3697Type: boolean, inherited
3698
3699The C<PrintError> attribute can be used to force errors to generate warnings (using
3700C<warn>) in addition to returning error codes in the normal way. When set
3701"on", any method which results in an error occurring will cause the DBI to
3702effectively do a C<warn("$class $method failed: $DBI::errstr")> where C<$class>
3703is the driver class and C<$method> is the name of the method which failed. E.g.,
3704
3705 DBD::Oracle::db prepare failed: ... error text here ...
3706
3707By default, C<DBI-E<gt>connect> sets C<PrintError> "on".
3708
3709If desired, the warnings can be caught and processed using a C<$SIG{__WARN__}>
3710handler or modules like CGI::Carp and CGI::ErrorWrap.
3711
3712=head3 C<RaiseError>
3713
3714Type: boolean, inherited
3715
3716The C<RaiseError> attribute can be used to force errors to raise exceptions rather
3717than simply return error codes in the normal way. It is "off" by default.
3718When set "on", any method which results in an error will cause
3719the DBI to effectively do a C<die("$class $method failed: $DBI::errstr")>,
3720where C<$class> is the driver class and C<$method> is the name of the method
3721that failed. E.g.,
3722
3723 DBD::Oracle::db prepare failed: ... error text here ...
3724
3725If you turn C<RaiseError> on then you'd normally turn C<PrintError> off.
3726If C<PrintError> is also on, then the C<PrintError> is done first (naturally).
3727
3728Typically C<RaiseError> is used in conjunction with C<eval { ... }>
3729to catch the exception that's been thrown and followed by an
3730C<if ($@) { ... }> block to handle the caught exception.
3731For example:
3732
3733 eval {
3734 ...
3735 $sth->execute();
3736 ...
3737 };
3738 if ($@) {
3739 # $sth->err and $DBI::err will be true if error was from DBI
3740 warn $@; # print the error
3741 ... # do whatever you need to deal with the error
3742 }
3743
3744In that eval block the $DBI::lasth variable can be useful for
3745diagnosis and reporting if you can't be sure which handle triggered
3746the error. For example, $DBI::lasth->{Type} and $DBI::lasth->{Statement}.
3747
3748See also L</Transactions>.
3749
3750If you want to temporarily turn C<RaiseError> off (inside a library function
3751that is likely to fail, for example), the recommended way is like this:
3752
3753 {
3754 local $h->{RaiseError}; # localize and turn off for this block
3755 ...
3756 }
3757
3758The original value will automatically and reliably be restored by Perl,
3759regardless of how the block is exited.
3760The same logic applies to other attributes, including C<PrintError>.
3761
3762=head3 C<HandleError>
3763
3764Type: code ref, inherited
3765
3766The C<HandleError> attribute can be used to provide your own alternative behaviour
3767in case of errors. If set to a reference to a subroutine then that
3768subroutine is called when an error is detected (at the same point that
3769C<RaiseError> and C<PrintError> are handled).
3770
3771The subroutine is called with three parameters: the error message
3772string that C<RaiseError> and C<PrintError> would use,
3773the DBI handle being used, and the first value being returned by
3774the method that failed (typically undef).
3775
3776If the subroutine returns a false value then the C<RaiseError>
3777and/or C<PrintError> attributes are checked and acted upon as normal.
3778
3779For example, to C<die> with a full stack trace for any error:
3780
3781 use Carp;
3782 $h->{HandleError} = sub { confess(shift) };
3783
3784Or to turn errors into exceptions:
3785
3786 use Exception; # or your own favourite exception module
3787 $h->{HandleError} = sub { Exception->new('DBI')->raise($_[0]) };
3788
3789It is possible to 'stack' multiple HandleError handlers by using
3790closures:
3791
3792 sub your_subroutine {
3793 my $previous_handler = $h->{HandleError};
3794 $h->{HandleError} = sub {
3795 return 1 if $previous_handler and &$previous_handler(@_);
3796 ... your code here ...
3797 };
3798 }
3799
3800Using a C<my> inside a subroutine to store the previous C<HandleError>
3801value is important. See L<perlsub> and L<perlref> for more information
3802about I<closures>.
3803
3804It is possible for C<HandleError> to alter the error message that
3805will be used by C<RaiseError> and C<PrintError> if it returns false.
3806It can do that by altering the value of $_[0]. This example appends
3807a stack trace to all errors and, unlike the previous example using
3808Carp::confess, this will work C<PrintError> as well as C<RaiseError>:
3809
3810 $h->{HandleError} = sub { $_[0]=Carp::longmess($_[0]); 0; };
3811
3812It is also possible for C<HandleError> to hide an error, to a limited
3813degree, by using L</set_err> to reset $DBI::err and $DBI::errstr,
3814and altering the return value of the failed method. For example:
3815
3816 $h->{HandleError} = sub {
3817 return 0 unless $_[0] =~ /^\S+ fetchrow_arrayref failed:/;
3818 return 0 unless $_[1]->err == 1234; # the error to 'hide'
3819 $h->set_err(undef,undef); # turn off the error
3820 $_[2] = [ ... ]; # supply alternative return value
3821 return 1;
3822 };
3823
3824This only works for methods which return a single value and is hard
3825to make reliable (avoiding infinite loops, for example) and so isn't
3826recommended for general use! If you find a I<good> use for it then
3827please let me know.
3828
3829=head3 C<HandleSetErr>
3830
3831Type: code ref, inherited
3832
3833The C<HandleSetErr> attribute can be used to intercept
3834the setting of handle C<err>, C<errstr>, and C<state> values.
3835If set to a reference to a subroutine then that subroutine is called
3836whenever set_err() is called, typically by the driver or a subclass.
3837
3838The subroutine is called with five arguments, the first five that
3839were passed to set_err(): the handle, the C<err>, C<errstr>, and
3840C<state> values being set, and the method name. These can be altered
3841by changing the values in the @_ array. The return value affects
3842set_err() behaviour, see L</set_err> for details.
3843
3844It is possible to 'stack' multiple HandleSetErr handlers by using
3845closures. See L</HandleError> for an example.
3846
3847The C<HandleSetErr> and C<HandleError> subroutines differ in subtle
3848but significant ways. HandleError is only invoked at the point where
3849the DBI is about to return to the application with C<err> set true.
3850It's not invoked by the failure of a method that's been called by
3851another DBI method. HandleSetErr, on the other hand, is called
3852whenever set_err() is called with a defined C<err> value, even if false.
3853So it's not just for errors, despite the name, but also warn and info states.
3854The set_err() method, and thus HandleSetErr, may be called multiple
3855times within a method and is usually invoked from deep within driver code.
3856
3857In theory a driver can use the return value from HandleSetErr via
3858set_err() to decide whether to continue or not. If set_err() returns
3859an empty list, indicating that the HandleSetErr code has 'handled'
3860the 'error', the driver could then continue instead of failing (if
3861that's a reasonable thing to do). This isn't excepted to be
3862common and any such cases should be clearly marked in the driver
3863documentation and discussed on the dbi-dev mailing list.
3864
3865The C<HandleSetErr> attribute was added in DBI 1.41.
3866
3867=head3 C<ErrCount>
3868
3869Type: unsigned integer
3870
3871The C<ErrCount> attribute is incremented whenever the set_err()
3872method records an error. It isn't incremented by warnings or
3873information states. It is not reset by the DBI at any time.
3874
3875The C<ErrCount> attribute was added in DBI 1.41. Older drivers may
3876not have been updated to use set_err() to record errors and so this
3877attribute may not be incremented when using them.
3878
3879
3880=head3 C<ShowErrorStatement>
3881
3882Type: boolean, inherited
3883
3884The C<ShowErrorStatement> attribute can be used to cause the relevant
3885Statement text to be appended to the error messages generated by
3886the C<RaiseError>, C<PrintError>, and C<PrintWarn> attributes.
3887Only applies to errors on statement handles
3888plus the prepare(), do(), and the various C<select*()> database handle methods.
3889(The exact format of the appended text is subject to change.)
3890
3891If C<$h-E<gt>{ParamValues}> returns a hash reference of parameter
3892(placeholder) values then those are formatted and appended to the
3893end of the Statement text in the error message.
3894
3895=head3 C<TraceLevel>
3896
3897Type: integer, inherited
3898
3899The C<TraceLevel> attribute can be used as an alternative to the
3900L</trace> method to set the DBI trace level and trace flags for a
3901specific handle. See L</TRACING> for more details.
3902
3903The C<TraceLevel> attribute is especially useful combined with
3904C<local> to alter the trace settings for just a single block of code.
3905
3906=head3 C<FetchHashKeyName>
3907
3908Type: string, inherited
3909
3910The C<FetchHashKeyName> attribute is used to specify whether the fetchrow_hashref()
3911method should perform case conversion on the field names used for
3912the hash keys. For historical reasons it defaults to 'C<NAME>' but
3913it is recommended to set it to 'C<NAME_lc>' (convert to lower case)
3914or 'C<NAME_uc>' (convert to upper case) according to your preference.
3915It can only be set for driver and database handles. For statement
3916handles the value is frozen when prepare() is called.
3917
3918
3919=head3 C<ChopBlanks>
3920
3921Type: boolean, inherited
3922
3923The C<ChopBlanks> attribute can be used to control the trimming of trailing space
3924characters from fixed width character (CHAR) fields. No other field
3925types are affected, even where field values have trailing spaces.
3926
3927The default is false (although it is possible that the default may change).
3928Applications that need specific behaviour should set the attribute as
3929needed.
3930
3931Drivers are not required to support this attribute, but any driver which
3932does not support it must arrange to return C<undef> as the attribute value.
3933
3934
3935=head3 C<LongReadLen>
3936
3937Type: unsigned integer, inherited
3938
3939The C<LongReadLen> attribute may be used to control the maximum
3940length of 'long' type fields (LONG, BLOB, CLOB, MEMO, etc.) which the driver will
3941read from the database automatically when it fetches each row of data.
3942
3943The C<LongReadLen> attribute only relates to fetching and reading
3944long values; it is not involved in inserting or updating them.
3945
3946A value of 0 means not to automatically fetch any long data.
3947Drivers may return undef or an empty string for long fields when
3948C<LongReadLen> is 0.
3949
3950The default is typically 0 (zero) or 80 bytes but may vary between drivers.
3951Applications fetching long fields should set this value to slightly
3952larger than the longest long field value to be fetched.
3953
3954Some databases return some long types encoded as pairs of hex digits.
3955For these types, C<LongReadLen> relates to the underlying data
3956length and not the doubled-up length of the encoded string.
3957
3958Changing the value of C<LongReadLen> for a statement handle after it
3959has been C<prepare>'d will typically have no effect, so it's common to
3960set C<LongReadLen> on the C<$dbh> before calling C<prepare>.
3961
3962For most drivers the value used here has a direct effect on the
3963memory used by the statement handle while it's active, so don't be
3964too generous. If you can't be sure what value to use you could
3965execute an extra select statement to determine the longest value.
3966For example:
3967
3968 $dbh->{LongReadLen} = $dbh->selectrow_array(qq{
3969 SELECT MAX(OCTET_LENGTH(long_column_name))
3970 FROM table WHERE ...
3971 });
3972 $sth = $dbh->prepare(qq{
3973 SELECT long_column_name, ... FROM table WHERE ...
3974 });
3975
3976You may need to take extra care if the table can be modified between
3977the first select and the second being executed. You may also need to
3978use a different function if OCTET_LENGTH() does not work for long
3979types in your database. For example, for Sybase use DATALENGTH() and
3980for Oracle use LENGTHB().
3981
3982See also L</LongTruncOk> for information on truncation of long types.
3983
3984=head3 C<LongTruncOk>
3985
3986Type: boolean, inherited
3987
3988The C<LongTruncOk> attribute may be used to control the effect of
3989fetching a long field value which has been truncated (typically
3990because it's longer than the value of the C<LongReadLen> attribute).
3991
3992By default, C<LongTruncOk> is false and so fetching a long value that
3993needs to be truncated will cause the fetch to fail.
3994(Applications should always be sure to
3995check for errors after a fetch loop in case an error, such as a divide
3996by zero or long field truncation, caused the fetch to terminate
3997prematurely.)
3998
3999If a fetch fails due to a long field truncation when C<LongTruncOk> is
4000false, many drivers will allow you to continue fetching further rows.
4001
4002See also L</LongReadLen>.
4003
4004=head3 C<TaintIn>
4005
4006Type: boolean, inherited
4007
4008If the C<TaintIn> attribute is set to a true value I<and> Perl is running in
4009taint mode (e.g., started with the C<-T> option), then all the arguments
4010to most DBI method calls are checked for being tainted. I<This may change.>
4011
4012The attribute defaults to off, even if Perl is in taint mode.
4013See L<perlsec> for more about taint mode. If Perl is not
4014running in taint mode, this attribute has no effect.
4015
4016When fetching data that you trust you can turn off the TaintIn attribute,
4017for that statement handle, for the duration of the fetch loop.
4018
4019The C<TaintIn> attribute was added in DBI 1.31.
4020
4021=head3 C<TaintOut>
4022
4023Type: boolean, inherited
4024
4025If the C<TaintOut> attribute is set to a true value I<and> Perl is running in
4026taint mode (e.g., started with the C<-T> option), then most data fetched
4027from the database is considered tainted. I<This may change.>
4028
4029The attribute defaults to off, even if Perl is in taint mode.
4030See L<perlsec> for more about taint mode. If Perl is not
4031running in taint mode, this attribute has no effect.
4032
4033When fetching data that you trust you can turn off the TaintOut attribute,
4034for that statement handle, for the duration of the fetch loop.
4035
4036Currently only fetched data is tainted. It is possible that the results
4037of other DBI method calls, and the value of fetched attributes, may
4038also be tainted in future versions. That change may well break your
4039applications unless you take great care now. If you use DBI Taint mode,
4040please report your experience and any suggestions for changes.
4041
4042The C<TaintOut> attribute was added in DBI 1.31.
4043
4044=head3 C<Taint>
4045
4046Type: boolean, inherited
4047
4048The C<Taint> attribute is a shortcut for L</TaintIn> and L</TaintOut> (it is also present
4049for backwards compatibility).
4050
4051Setting this attribute sets both L</TaintIn> and L</TaintOut>, and retrieving
4052it returns a true value if and only if L</TaintIn> and L</TaintOut> are
4053both set to true values.
4054
4055=head3 C<Profile>
4056
4057Type: inherited
4058
4059The C<Profile> attribute enables the collection and reporting of
4060method call timing statistics. See the L<DBI::Profile> module
4061documentation for I<much> more detail.
4062
4063The C<Profile> attribute was added in DBI 1.24.
4064
4065=head3 C<ReadOnly>
4066
4067Type: boolean, inherited
4068
4069An application can set the C<ReadOnly> attribute of a handle to a true value to
4070indicate that it will not be attempting to make any changes using that handle
4071or any children of it.
4072
4073Note that the exact definition of 'read only' is rather fuzzy.
4074For more details see the documentation for the driver you're using.
4075
4076If the driver can make the handle truly read-only then it should
4077(unless doing so would have unpleasant side effect, like changing the
4078consistency level from per-statement to per-session).
4079Otherwise the attribute is simply advisory.
4080
4081A driver can set the C<ReadOnly> attribute itself to indicate that the data it
4082is connected to cannot be changed for some reason.
4083
4084Library modules and proxy drivers can use the attribute to influence
4085their behavior. For example, the DBD::Gofer driver considers the
4086C<ReadOnly> attribute when making a decision about whether to retry an
4087operation that failed.
4088
4089The attribute should be set to 1 or 0 (or undef). Other values are reserved.
4090
4091=head3 C<Callbacks>
4092
4093Type: hash ref
4094
4095The DBI callback mechanism lets you intercept, and optionally replace, any
4096method call on a DBI handle. At the extreme, it lets you become a puppet
4097master, deceiving the application in any way you want.
4098
4099The C<Callbacks> attribute is a hash reference where the keys are DBI method
4100names and the values are code references. For each key naming a method, the
4101DBI will execute the associated code reference before executing the method.
4102
4103The arguments to the code reference will be the same as to the method,
4104including the invocant (a database handle or statement handle). For example,
4105say that to callback to some code on a call to C<prepare()>:
4106
4107 $dbh->{Callbacks} = {
4108 prepare => sub {
4109 my ($dbh, $query, $attrs) = @_;
4110 print "Preparing q{$query}\n"
4111 },
4112 };
4113
4114The callback would then be executed when you called the C<prepare()> method:
4115
4116 $dbh->prepare('SELECT 1');
4117
4118And the output of course would be:
4119
4120 Preparing q{SELECT 1}
4121
4122Because callbacks are executed I<before> the methods
4123they're associated with, you can modify the arguments before they're passed on
4124to the method call. For example, to make sure that all calls to C<prepare()>
4125are immediately prepared by L<DBD::Pg>, add a callback that makes sure that
4126the C<pg_prepare_now> attribute is always set:
4127
4128 my $dbh = DBI->connect($dsn, $username, $auth, {
4129 Callbacks => {
4130 prepare => sub {
4131 $_[2] ||= {};
4132 $_[2]->{pg_prepare_now} = 1;
4133 return; # must return nothing
4134 },
4135 }
4136 });
4137
4138Note that we are editing the contents of C<@_> directly. In this case we've
4139created the attributes hash if it's not passed to the C<prepare> call.
4140
4141You can also prevent the associated method from ever executing. While a
4142callback executes, C<$_> holds the method name. (This allows multiple callbacks
4143to share the same code reference and still know what method was called.)
4144To prevent the method from
4145executing, simply C<undef $_>. For example, if you wanted to disable calls to
4146C<ping()>, you could do this:
4147
4148 $dbh->{Callbacks} = {
4149 ping => sub {
4150 # tell dispatch to not call the method:
4151 undef $_;
4152 # return this value instead:
4153 return "42 bells";
4154 }
4155 };
4156
4157As with other attributes, Callbacks can be specified on a handle or via the
4158attributes to C<connect()>. Callbacks can also be applied to a statement
4159methods on a statement handle. For example:
4160
4161 $sth->{Callbacks} = {
4162 execute => sub {
4163 print "Executing ", shift->{Statement}, "\n";
4164 }
4165 };
4166
4167The C<Callbacks> attribute of a database handle isn't copied to any statement
4168handles it creates. So setting callbacks for a statement handle requires you to
4169set the C<Callbacks> attribute on the statement handle yourself, as in the
4170example above, or use the special C<ChildCallbacks> key described below.
4171
4172B<Special Keys in Callbacks Attribute>
4173
4174In addition to DBI handle method names, the C<Callbacks> hash reference
4175supports three additional keys.
4176
4177The first is the C<ChildCallbacks> key. When a statement handle is created from
4178a database handle the C<ChildCallbacks> key of the database handle's
4179C<Callbacks> attribute, if any, becomes the new C<Callbacks> attribute of the
4180statement handle.
4181This allows you to define callbacks for all statement handles created from a
4182database handle. For example, if you wanted to count how many times C<execute>
4183was called in your application, you could write:
4184
4185 my $exec_count = 0;
4186 my $dbh = DBI->connect( $dsn, $username, $auth, {
4187 Callbacks => {
4188 ChildCallbacks => {
4189 execute => sub { $exec_count++; return; }
4190 }
4191 }
4192 });
4193
4194 END {
4195 print "The execute method was called $exec_count times\n";
4196 }
4197
4198The other two special keys are C<connect_cached.new> and
4199C<connect_cached.reused>. These keys define callbacks that are called when
4200C<connect_cached()> is called, but allow different behaviors depending on
4201whether a new handle is created or a handle is returned. The callback is
4202invoked with these arguments: C<$dbh, $dsn, $user, $auth, $attr>.
4203
4204For example, some applications uses C<connect_cached()> to connect with
4205C<AutoCommit> enabled and then disable C<AutoCommit> temporarily for
4206transactions. If C<connect_cached()> is called during a transaction, perhaps in
4207a utility method, then it might select the same cached handle and then force
4208C<AutoCommit> on, forcing a commit of the transaction. See the L</connect_cached>
4209documentation for one way to deal with that. Here we'll describe an alternative
4210approach using a callback.
4211
4212Because the C<connect_cached.*> callbacks are invoked before connect_cached()
4213has applied the connect attributes you can use a callback to edit the attributes
4214that will be applied. To prevent a cached handle from having its transactions
4215committed before it's returned, you can eliminate the C<AutoCommit> attribute
4216in a C<connect_cached.reused> callback, like so:
4217
4218 my $cb = {
4219 âconnect_cached.reusedâ => sub { delete $_[4]->{AutoCommit} },
4220 };
4221
4222 sub dbh {
4223 my $self = shift;
4224 DBI->connect_cached( $dsn, $username, $auth, {
4225 PrintError => 0,
4226 RaiseError => 1,
4227 AutoCommit => 1,
4228 Callbacks => $cb,
4229 });
4230 }
4231
4232The upshot is that new database handles are created with C<AutoCommit>
4233enabled, while cached database handles are left in whatever transaction state
4234they happened to be in when retrieved from the cache.
4235
4236A more common application for callbacks is setting connection state only when a
4237new connection is made (by connect() or connect_cached()). Adding a callback to
4238the connected method makes this easy.
4239This method is a no-op by default (unless you subclass the DBI and change it).
4240The DBI calls it to indicate that a new connection has been made and the connection
4241attributes have all been set. You can
4242give it a bit of added functionality by applying a callback to it. For
4243example, to make sure that MySQL understands your application's ANSI-compliant
4244SQL, set it up like so:
4245
4246 my $dbh = DBI->connect($dsn, $username, $auth, {
4247 Callbacks => {
4248 connected => sub {
4249 shift->do(q{
4250 SET SESSION sql_mode='ansi,strict_trans_tables,no_auto_value_on_zero';
4251 });
4252 return;
4253 },
4254 }
4255 });
4256
4257One significant limitation with callbacks is that there can only be one per
4258method per handle. This means it's easy for one use of callbacks to interfere
4259with, or typically simply overwrite, another use of callbacks. For this reason
4260modules using callbacks should document the fact clearly so application authors
4261can tell if use of callbacks by the module will clash with use of callbacks by
4262the application.
4263
4264You might be able to work around this issue by taking a copy of the original
4265callback and calling it within your own. For example:
4266
4267 my $prev_cb = $h->{Callbacks}{method_name};
4268 $h->{Callbacks}{method_name} = sub {
4269 if ($prev_cb) {
4270 my @result = $prev_cb->(@_);
4271 return @result if not $_; # $prev_cb vetoed call
4272 }
4273 ... your callback logic here ...
4274 };
4275
4276=head3 C<private_your_module_name_*>
4277
4278The DBI provides a way to store extra information in a DBI handle as
4279"private" attributes. The DBI will allow you to store and retrieve any
4280attribute which has a name starting with "C<private_>".
4281
4282It is I<strongly> recommended that you use just I<one> private
4283attribute (e.g., use a hash ref) I<and> give it a long and unambiguous
4284name that includes the module or application name that the attribute
4285relates to (e.g., "C<private_YourFullModuleName_thingy>").
4286
4287Because of the way the Perl tie mechanism works you cannot reliably
4288use the C<||=> operator directly to initialise the attribute, like this:
4289
4290 my $foo = $dbh->{private_yourmodname_foo} ||= { ... }; # WRONG
4291
4292you should use a two step approach like this:
4293
4294 my $foo = $dbh->{private_yourmodname_foo};
4295 $foo ||= $dbh->{private_yourmodname_foo} = { ... };
4296
4297This attribute is primarily of interest to people sub-classing DBI,
4298or for applications to piggy-back extra information onto DBI handles.
4299
4300=head1 DBI DATABASE HANDLE OBJECTS
4301
4302This section covers the methods and attributes associated with
4303database handles.
4304
4305=head2 Database Handle Methods
4306
4307The following methods are specified for DBI database handles:
4308
4309=head3 C<clone>
4310
4311 $new_dbh = $dbh->clone();
4312 $new_dbh = $dbh->clone(\%attr);
4313
4314The C<clone> method duplicates the $dbh connection by connecting
4315with the same parameters ($dsn, $user, $password) as originally used.
4316
4317The attributes for the cloned connect are the same as those used
4318for the original connect, with some other attributes merged over
4319them depending on the \%attr parameter.
4320
4321If \%attr is given then the attributes it contains are merged into
4322the original attributes and override any with the same names.
4323Effectively the same as doing:
4324
4325 %attribues_used = ( %original_attributes, %attr );
4326
4327If \%attr is not given then it defaults to a hash containing all
4328the attributes in the attribute cache of $dbh excluding any non-code
4329references, plus the main boolean attributes (RaiseError, PrintError,
4330AutoCommit, etc.). This behaviour is subject to change.
4331
4332The clone method can be used even if the database handle is disconnected.
4333
4334The C<clone> method was added in DBI 1.33. It is very new and likely
4335to change.
4336
4337=head3 C<data_sources>
4338
4339 @ary = $dbh->data_sources();
4340 @ary = $dbh->data_sources(\%attr);
4341
4342Returns a list of data sources (databases) available via the $dbh
4343driver's data_sources() method, plus any extra data sources that
4344the driver can discover via the connected $dbh. Typically the extra
4345data sources are other databases managed by the same server process
4346that the $dbh is connected to.
4347
4348Data sources are returned in a form suitable for passing to the
4349L</connect> method (that is, they will include the "C<dbi:$driver:>" prefix).
4350
4351The data_sources() method, for a $dbh, was added in DBI 1.38.
4352
4353=head3 C<do>
4354
4355 $rows = $dbh->do($statement) or die $dbh->errstr;
4356 $rows = $dbh->do($statement, \%attr) or die $dbh->errstr;
4357 $rows = $dbh->do($statement, \%attr, @bind_values) or die ...
4358
4359Prepare and execute a single statement. Returns the number of rows
4360affected or C<undef> on error. A return value of C<-1> means the
4361number of rows is not known, not applicable, or not available.
4362
4363This method is typically most useful for I<non>-C<SELECT> statements that
4364either cannot be prepared in advance (due to a limitation of the
4365driver) or do not need to be executed repeatedly. It should not
4366be used for C<SELECT> statements because it does not return a statement
4367handle (so you can't fetch any data).
4368
4369The default C<do> method is logically similar to:
4370
4371 sub do {
4372 my($dbh, $statement, $attr, @bind_values) = @_;
4373 my $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement, $attr) or return undef;
4374 $sth->execute(@bind_values) or return undef;
4375 my $rows = $sth->rows;
4376 ($rows == 0) ? "0E0" : $rows; # always return true if no error
4377 }
4378
4379For example:
4380
4381 my $rows_deleted = $dbh->do(q{
4382 DELETE FROM table
4383 WHERE status = ?
4384 }, undef, 'DONE') or die $dbh->errstr;
4385
4386Using placeholders and C<@bind_values> with the C<do> method can be
4387useful because it avoids the need to correctly quote any variables
4388in the C<$statement>. But if you'll be executing the statement many
4389times then it's more efficient to C<prepare> it once and call
4390C<execute> many times instead.
4391
4392The C<q{...}> style quoting used in this example avoids clashing with
4393quotes that may be used in the SQL statement. Use the double-quote-like
4394C<qq{...}> operator if you want to interpolate variables into the string.
4395See L<perlop/"Quote and Quote-like Operators"> for more details.
4396
4397Note drivers are free to avoid the overhead of creating an DBI
4398statement handle for do(), especially if there are no parameters. In
4399this case error handlers, if invoked during do(), will be passed the
4400database handle.
4401
4402=head3 C<last_insert_id>
4403
4404 $rv = $dbh->last_insert_id($catalog, $schema, $table, $field);
4405 $rv = $dbh->last_insert_id($catalog, $schema, $table, $field, \%attr);
4406
4407Returns a value 'identifying' the row just inserted, if possible.
4408Typically this would be a value assigned by the database server
4409to a column with an I<auto_increment> or I<serial> type.
4410Returns undef if the driver does not support the method or can't
4411determine the value.
4412
4413The $catalog, $schema, $table, and $field parameters may be required
4414for some drivers (see below). If you don't know the parameter values
4415and your driver does not need them, then use C<undef> for each.
4416
4417There are several caveats to be aware of with this method if you want
4418to use it for portable applications:
4419
4420B<*> For some drivers the value may only available immediately after
4421the insert statement has executed (e.g., mysql, Informix).
4422
4423B<*> For some drivers the $catalog, $schema, $table, and $field parameters
4424are required, for others they are ignored (e.g., mysql).
4425
4426B<*> Drivers may return an indeterminate value if no insert has
4427been performed yet.
4428
4429B<*> For some drivers the value may only be available if placeholders
4430have I<not> been used (e.g., Sybase, MS SQL). In this case the value
4431returned would be from the last non-placeholder insert statement.
4432
4433B<*> Some drivers may need driver-specific hints about how to get
4434the value. For example, being told the name of the database 'sequence'
4435object that holds the value. Any such hints are passed as driver-specific
4436attributes in the \%attr parameter.
4437
4438B<*> If the underlying database offers nothing better, then some
4439drivers may attempt to implement this method by executing
4440"C<select max($field) from $table>". Drivers using any approach
4441like this should issue a warning if C<AutoCommit> is true because
4442it is generally unsafe - another process may have modified the table
4443between your insert and the select. For situations where you know
4444it is safe, such as when you have locked the table, you can silence
4445the warning by passing C<Warn> => 0 in \%attr.
4446
4447B<*> If no insert has been performed yet, or the last insert failed,
4448then the value is implementation defined.
4449
4450Given all the caveats above, it's clear that this method must be
4451used with care.
4452
4453The C<last_insert_id> method was added in DBI 1.38.
4454
4455=head3 C<selectrow_array>
4456
4457 @row_ary = $dbh->selectrow_array($statement);
4458 @row_ary = $dbh->selectrow_array($statement, \%attr);
4459 @row_ary = $dbh->selectrow_array($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
4460
