4461This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute> and
4462L</fetchrow_array> into a single call. If called in a list context, it
4463returns the first row of data from the statement. The C<$statement>
4464parameter can be a previously prepared statement handle, in which case
4465the C<prepare> is skipped.
4466
4467If any method fails, and L</RaiseError> is not set, C<selectrow_array>
4468will return an empty list.
4469
4470If called in a scalar context for a statement handle that has more
4471than one column, it is undefined whether the driver will return
4472the value of the first column or the last. So don't do that.
4473Also, in a scalar context, an C<undef> is returned if there are no
4474more rows or if an error occurred. That C<undef> can't be distinguished
4475from an C<undef> returned because the first field value was NULL.
4476For these reasons you should exercise some caution if you use
4477C<selectrow_array> in a scalar context, or just don't do that.
4478
4479
4480=head3 C<selectrow_arrayref>
4481
4482 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectrow_arrayref($statement);
4483 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectrow_arrayref($statement, \%attr);
4484 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectrow_arrayref($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
4485
4486This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute> and
4487L</fetchrow_arrayref> into a single call. It returns the first row of
4488data from the statement. The C<$statement> parameter can be a previously
4489prepared statement handle, in which case the C<prepare> is skipped.
4490
4491If any method fails, and L</RaiseError> is not set, C<selectrow_array>
4492will return undef.
4493
4494
4495=head3 C<selectrow_hashref>
4496
4497 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectrow_hashref($statement);
4498 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectrow_hashref($statement, \%attr);
4499 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectrow_hashref($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
4500
4501This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute> and
4502L</fetchrow_hashref> into a single call. It returns the first row of
4503data from the statement. The C<$statement> parameter can be a previously
4504prepared statement handle, in which case the C<prepare> is skipped.
4505
4506If any method fails, and L</RaiseError> is not set, C<selectrow_hashref>
4507will return undef.
4508
4509
4510=head3 C<selectall_arrayref>
4511
4512 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectall_arrayref($statement);
4513 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectall_arrayref($statement, \%attr);
4514 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectall_arrayref($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
4515
4516This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute> and
4517L</fetchall_arrayref> into a single call. It returns a reference to an
4518array containing a reference to an array (or hash, see below) for each row of
4519data fetched.
4520
4521The C<$statement> parameter can be a previously prepared statement handle,
4522in which case the C<prepare> is skipped. This is recommended if the
4523statement is going to be executed many times.
4524
4525If L</RaiseError> is not set and any method except C<fetchall_arrayref>
4526fails then C<selectall_arrayref> will return C<undef>; if
4527C<fetchall_arrayref> fails then it will return with whatever data
4528has been fetched thus far. You should check C<$sth-E<gt>err>
4529afterwards (or use the C<RaiseError> attribute) to discover if the data is
4530complete or was truncated due to an error.
4531
4532The L</fetchall_arrayref> method called by C<selectall_arrayref>
4533supports a $max_rows parameter. You can specify a value for $max_rows
4534by including a 'C<MaxRows>' attribute in \%attr. In which case finish()
4535is called for you after fetchall_arrayref() returns.
4536
4537The L</fetchall_arrayref> method called by C<selectall_arrayref>
4538also supports a $slice parameter. You can specify a value for $slice by
4539including a 'C<Slice>' or 'C<Columns>' attribute in \%attr. The only
4540difference between the two is that if C<Slice> is not defined and
4541C<Columns> is an array ref, then the array is assumed to contain column
4542index values (which count from 1), rather than perl array index values.
4543In which case the array is copied and each value decremented before
4544passing to C</fetchall_arrayref>.
4545
4546You may often want to fetch an array of rows where each row is stored as a
4547hash. That can be done simple using:
4548
4549 my $emps = $dbh->selectall_arrayref(
4550 "SELECT ename FROM emp ORDER BY ename",
4551 { Slice => {} }
4552 );
4553 foreach my $emp ( @$emps ) {
4554 print "Employee: $emp->{ename}\n";
4555 }
4556
4557Or, to fetch into an array instead of an array ref:
4558
4559 @result = @{ $dbh->selectall_arrayref($sql, { Slice => {} }) };
4560
4561See L</fetchall_arrayref> method for more details.
4562
4563=head3 C<selectall_hashref>
4564
4565 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectall_hashref($statement, $key_field);
4566 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectall_hashref($statement, $key_field, \%attr);
4567 $hash_ref = $dbh->selectall_hashref($statement, $key_field, \%attr, @bind_values);
4568
4569This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute> and
4570L</fetchall_hashref> into a single call. It returns a reference to a
4571hash containing one entry, at most, for each row, as returned by fetchall_hashref().
4572
4573The C<$statement> parameter can be a previously prepared statement handle,
4574in which case the C<prepare> is skipped. This is recommended if the
4575statement is going to be executed many times.
4576
4577The C<$key_field> parameter defines which column, or columns, are used as keys
4578in the returned hash. It can either be the name of a single field, or a
4579reference to an array containing multiple field names. Using multiple names
4580yields a tree of nested hashes.
4581
4582If a row has the same key as an earlier row then it replaces the earlier row.
4583
4584If any method except C<fetchrow_hashref> fails, and L</RaiseError> is not set,
4585C<selectall_hashref> will return C<undef>. If C<fetchrow_hashref> fails and
4586L</RaiseError> is not set, then it will return with whatever data it
4587has fetched thus far. $DBI::err should be checked to catch that.
4588
4589See fetchall_hashref() for more details.
4590
4591=head3 C<selectcol_arrayref>
4592
4593 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref($statement);
4594 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref($statement, \%attr);
4595 $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref($statement, \%attr, @bind_values);
4596
4597This utility method combines L</prepare>, L</execute>, and fetching one
4598column from all the rows, into a single call. It returns a reference to
4599an array containing the values of the first column from each row.
4600
4601The C<$statement> parameter can be a previously prepared statement handle,
4602in which case the C<prepare> is skipped. This is recommended if the
4603statement is going to be executed many times.
4604
4605If any method except C<fetch> fails, and L</RaiseError> is not set,
4606C<selectcol_arrayref> will return C<undef>. If C<fetch> fails and
4607L</RaiseError> is not set, then it will return with whatever data it
4608has fetched thus far. $DBI::err should be checked to catch that.
4609
4610The C<selectcol_arrayref> method defaults to pushing a single column
4611value (the first) from each row into the result array. However, it can
4612also push another column, or even multiple columns per row, into the
4613result array. This behaviour can be specified via a 'C<Columns>'
4614attribute which must be a ref to an array containing the column number
4615or numbers to use. For example:
4616
4617 # get array of id and name pairs:
4618 my $ary_ref = $dbh->selectcol_arrayref("select id, name from table", { Columns=>[1,2] });
4619 my %hash = @$ary_ref; # build hash from key-value pairs so $hash{$id} => name
4620
4621You can specify a maximum number of rows to fetch by including a
4622'C<MaxRows>' attribute in \%attr.
4623
4624=head3 C<prepare>
4625
4626 $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement) or die $dbh->errstr;
4627 $sth = $dbh->prepare($statement, \%attr) or die $dbh->errstr;
4628
4629Prepares a statement for later execution by the database
4630engine and returns a reference to a statement handle object.
4631
4632The returned statement handle can be used to get attributes of the
4633statement and invoke the L</execute> method. See L</Statement Handle Methods>.
4634
4635Drivers for engines without the concept of preparing a
4636statement will typically just store the statement in the returned
4637handle and process it when C<$sth-E<gt>execute> is called. Such drivers are
4638unlikely to give much useful information about the
4639statement, such as C<$sth-E<gt>{NUM_OF_FIELDS}>, until after C<$sth-E<gt>execute>
4640has been called. Portable applications should take this into account.
4641
4642In general, DBI drivers do not parse the contents of the statement
4643(other than simply counting any L</Placeholders>). The statement is
4644passed directly to the database engine, sometimes known as pass-thru
4645mode. This has advantages and disadvantages. On the plus side, you can
4646access all the functionality of the engine being used. On the downside,
4647you're limited if you're using a simple engine, and you need to take extra care if
4648writing applications intended to be portable between engines.
4649
4650Portable applications should not assume that a new statement can be
4651prepared and/or executed while still fetching results from a previous
4652statement.
4653
4654Some command-line SQL tools use statement terminators, like a semicolon,
4655to indicate the end of a statement. Such terminators should not normally
4656be used with the DBI.
4657
4658
4659=head3 C<prepare_cached>
4660
4661 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached($statement)
4662 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached($statement, \%attr)
4663 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached($statement, \%attr, $if_active)
4664
4665Like L</prepare> except that the statement handle returned will be
4666stored in a hash associated with the C<$dbh>. If another call is made to
4667C<prepare_cached> with the same C<$statement> and C<%attr> parameter values,
4668then the corresponding cached C<$sth> will be returned without contacting the
4669database server.
4670
4671The C<$if_active> parameter lets you adjust the behaviour if an
4672already cached statement handle is still Active. There are several
4673alternatives:
4674
4675=over 4
4676
4677=item B<0>: A warning will be generated, and finish() will be called on
4678the statement handle before it is returned. This is the default
4679behaviour if $if_active is not passed.
4680
4681=item B<1>: finish() will be called on the statement handle, but the
4682warning is suppressed.
4683
4684=item B<2>: Disables any checking.
4685
4686=item B<3>: The existing active statement handle will be removed from the
4687cache and a new statement handle prepared and cached in its place.
4688This is the safest option because it doesn't affect the state of the
4689old handle, it just removes it from the cache. [Added in DBI 1.40]
4690
4691=back
4692
4693Here are some examples of C<prepare_cached>:
4694
4695 sub insert_hash {
4696 my ($table, $field_values) = @_;
4697 # sort to keep field order, and thus sql, stable for prepare_cached
4698 my @fields = sort keys %$field_values;
4699 my @values = @{$field_values}{@fields};
4700 my $sql = sprintf "insert into %s (%s) values (%s)",
4701 $table, join(",", @fields), join(",", ("?")x@fields);
4702 my $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached($sql);
4703 return $sth->execute(@values);
4704 }
4705
4706 sub search_hash {
4707 my ($table, $field_values) = @_;
4708 # sort to keep field order, and thus sql, stable for prepare_cached
4709 my @fields = sort keys %$field_values;
4710 my @values = @{$field_values}{@fields};
4711 my $qualifier = "";
4712 $qualifier = "where ".join(" and ", map { "$_=?" } @fields) if @fields;
4713 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached("SELECT * FROM $table $qualifier");
4714 return $dbh->selectall_arrayref($sth, {}, @values);
4715 }
4716
4717I<Caveat emptor:> This caching can be useful in some applications,
4718but it can also cause problems and should be used with care. Here
4719is a contrived case where caching would cause a significant problem:
4720
4721 my $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached('SELECT * FROM foo WHERE bar=?');
4722 $sth->execute(...);
4723 while (my $data = $sth->fetchrow_hashref) {
4724
4725 # later, in some other code called within the loop...
4726 my $sth2 = $dbh->prepare_cached('SELECT * FROM foo WHERE bar=?');
4727 $sth2->execute(...);
4728 while (my $data2 = $sth2->fetchrow_arrayref) {
4729 do_stuff(...);
4730 }
4731 }
4732
4733In this example, since both handles are preparing the exact same statement,
4734C<$sth2> will not be its own statement handle, but a duplicate of C<$sth>
4735returned from the cache. The results will certainly not be what you expect.
4736Typically the inner fetch loop will work normally, fetching all
4737the records and terminating when there are no more, but now that $sth
4738is the same as $sth2 the outer fetch loop will also terminate.
4739
4740You'll know if you run into this problem because prepare_cached()
4741will generate a warning by default (when $if_active is false).
4742
4743The cache used by prepare_cached() is keyed by both the statement
4744and any attributes so you can also avoid this issue by doing something
4745like:
4746
4747 $sth = $dbh->prepare_cached("...", { dbi_dummy => __FILE__.__LINE__ });
4748
4749which will ensure that prepare_cached only returns statements cached
4750by that line of code in that source file.
4751
4752If you'd like the cache to managed intelligently, you can tie the
4753hashref returned by C<CachedKids> to an appropriate caching module,
4754such as L<Tie::Cache::LRU>:
4755
4756 my $cache;
4757 tie %$cache, 'Tie::Cache::LRU', 500;
4758 $dbh->{CachedKids} = $cache;
4759
4760=head3 C<commit>
4761
4762 $rc = $dbh->commit or die $dbh->errstr;
4763
4764Commit (make permanent) the most recent series of database changes
4765if the database supports transactions and AutoCommit is off.
4766
4767If C<AutoCommit> is on, then calling
4768C<commit> will issue a "commit ineffective with AutoCommit" warning.
4769
4770See also L</Transactions> in the L</FURTHER INFORMATION> section below.
4771
4772=head3 C<rollback>
4773
4774 $rc = $dbh->rollback or die $dbh->errstr;
4775
4776Rollback (undo) the most recent series of uncommitted database
4777changes if the database supports transactions and AutoCommit is off.
4778
4779If C<AutoCommit> is on, then calling
4780C<rollback> will issue a "rollback ineffective with AutoCommit" warning.
4781
4782See also L</Transactions> in the L</FURTHER INFORMATION> section below.
4783
4784=head3 C<begin_work>
4785
4786 $rc = $dbh->begin_work or die $dbh->errstr;
4787
4788Enable transactions (by turning C<AutoCommit> off) until the next call
4789to C<commit> or C<rollback>. After the next C<commit> or C<rollback>,
4790C<AutoCommit> will automatically be turned on again.
4791
4792If C<AutoCommit> is already off when C<begin_work> is called then
4793it does nothing except return an error. If the driver does not support
4794transactions then when C<begin_work> attempts to set C<AutoCommit> off
4795the driver will trigger a fatal error.
4796
4797See also L</Transactions> in the L</FURTHER INFORMATION> section below.
4798
4799
4800=head3 C<disconnect>
4801
4802 $rc = $dbh->disconnect or warn $dbh->errstr;
4803
4804Disconnects the database from the database handle. C<disconnect> is typically only used
4805before exiting the program. The handle is of little use after disconnecting.
4806
4807The transaction behaviour of the C<disconnect> method is, sadly,
4808undefined. Some database systems (such as Oracle and Ingres) will
4809automatically commit any outstanding changes, but others (such as
4810Informix) will rollback any outstanding changes. Applications not
4811using C<AutoCommit> should explicitly call C<commit> or C<rollback> before
4812calling C<disconnect>.
4813
4814The database is automatically disconnected by the C<DESTROY> method if
4815still connected when there are no longer any references to the handle.
4816The C<DESTROY> method for each driver should implicitly call C<rollback> to
4817undo any uncommitted changes. This is vital behaviour to ensure that
4818incomplete transactions don't get committed simply because Perl calls
4819C<DESTROY> on every object before exiting. Also, do not rely on the order
4820of object destruction during "global destruction", as it is undefined.
4821
4822Generally, if you want your changes to be committed or rolled back when
4823you disconnect, then you should explicitly call L</commit> or L</rollback>
4824before disconnecting.
4825
4826If you disconnect from a database while you still have active
4827statement handles (e.g., SELECT statement handles that may have
4828more data to fetch), you will get a warning. The warning may indicate
4829that a fetch loop terminated early, perhaps due to an uncaught error.
4830To avoid the warning call the C<finish> method on the active handles.
4831
4832
4833=head3 C<ping>
4834
4835 $rc = $dbh->ping;
4836
4837Attempts to determine, in a reasonably efficient way, if the database
4838server is still running and the connection to it is still working.
4839Individual drivers should implement this function in the most suitable
4840manner for their database engine.
4841
4842The current I<default> implementation always returns true without
4843actually doing anything. Actually, it returns "C<0 but true>" which is
4844true but zero. That way you can tell if the return value is genuine or
4845just the default. Drivers should override this method with one that
4846does the right thing for their type of database.
4847
4848Few applications would have direct use for this method. See the specialized
4849Apache::DBI module for one example usage.
4850
4851
4852=head3 C<get_info>
4853
4854 $value = $dbh->get_info( $info_type );
4855
4856Returns information about the implementation, i.e. driver and data
4857source capabilities, restrictions etc. It returns C<undef> for
4858unknown or unimplemented information types. For example:
4859
4860 $database_version = $dbh->get_info( 18 ); # SQL_DBMS_VER
4861 $max_select_tables = $dbh->get_info( 106 ); # SQL_MAXIMUM_TABLES_IN_SELECT
4862
4863See L</"Standards Reference Information"> for more detailed information
4864about the information types and their meanings and possible return values.
4865
4866The DBI::Const::GetInfoType module exports a %GetInfoType hash that
4867can be used to map info type names to numbers. For example:
4868
4869 $database_version = $dbh->get_info( $GetInfoType{SQL_DBMS_VER} );
4870
4871The names are a merging of the ANSI and ODBC standards (which differ
4872in some cases). See L<DBI::Const::GetInfoType> for more details.
4873
4874Because some DBI methods make use of get_info(), drivers are strongly
4875encouraged to support I<at least> the following very minimal set
4876of information types to ensure the DBI itself works properly:
4877
4878 Type Name Example A Example B
4879 ---- -------------------------- ------------ ----------------
4880 17 SQL_DBMS_NAME 'ACCESS' 'Oracle'
4881 18 SQL_DBMS_VER '03.50.0000' '08.01.0721 ...'
4882 29 SQL_IDENTIFIER_QUOTE_CHAR '`' '"'
4883 41 SQL_CATALOG_NAME_SEPARATOR '.' '@'
4884 114 SQL_CATALOG_LOCATION 1 2
4885
4886=head3 C<table_info>
4887
4888 $sth = $dbh->table_info( $catalog, $schema, $table, $type );
4889 $sth = $dbh->table_info( $catalog, $schema, $table, $type, \%attr );
4890
4891 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
4892
4893Returns an active statement handle that can be used to fetch
4894information about tables and views that exist in the database.
4895
4896The arguments $catalog, $schema and $table may accept search patterns
4897according to the database/driver, for example: $table = '%FOO%';
4898Remember that the underscore character ('C<_>') is a search pattern
4899that means match any character, so 'FOO_%' is the same as 'FOO%'
4900and 'FOO_BAR%' will match names like 'FOO1BAR'.
4901
4902The value of $type is a comma-separated list of one or more types of
4903tables to be returned in the result set. Each value may optionally be
4904quoted, e.g.:
4905
4906 $type = "TABLE";
4907 $type = "'TABLE','VIEW'";
4908
4909In addition the following special cases may also be supported by some drivers:
4910
4911=over 4
4912
4913=item *
4914If the value of $catalog is '%' and $schema and $table name
4915are empty strings, the result set contains a list of catalog names.
4916For example:
4917
4918 $sth = $dbh->table_info('%', '', '');
4919
4920=item *
4921If the value of $schema is '%' and $catalog and $table are empty
4922strings, the result set contains a list of schema names.
4923
4924=item *
4925If the value of $type is '%' and $catalog, $schema, and $table are all
4926empty strings, the result set contains a list of table types.
4927
4928=back
4929
4930If your driver doesn't support one or more of the selection filter
4931parameters then you may get back more than you asked for and can
4932do the filtering yourself.
4933
4934This method can be expensive, and can return a large amount of data.
4935(For example, small Oracle installation returns over 2000 rows.)
4936So it's a good idea to use the filters to limit the data as much as possible.
4937
4938The statement handle returned has at least the following fields in the
4939order show below. Other fields, after these, may also be present.
4940
4941B<TABLE_CAT>: Table catalog identifier. This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not
4942applicable to the data source, which is usually the case. This field
4943is empty if not applicable to the table.
4944
4945B<TABLE_SCHEM>: The name of the schema containing the TABLE_NAME value.
4946This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to data source, and
4947empty if not applicable to the table.
4948
4949B<TABLE_NAME>: Name of the table (or view, synonym, etc).
4950
4951B<TABLE_TYPE>: One of the following: "TABLE", "VIEW", "SYSTEM TABLE",
4952"GLOBAL TEMPORARY", "LOCAL TEMPORARY", "ALIAS", "SYNONYM" or a type
4953identifier that is specific to the data
4954source.
4955
4956B<REMARKS>: A description of the table. May be NULL (C<undef>).
4957
4958Note that C<table_info> might not return records for all tables.
4959Applications can use any valid table regardless of whether it's
4960returned by C<table_info>.
4961
4962See also L</tables>, L</"Catalog Methods"> and
4963L</"Standards Reference Information">.
4964
4965=head3 C<column_info>
4966
4967 $sth = $dbh->column_info( $catalog, $schema, $table, $column );
4968
4969 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
4970
4971Returns an active statement handle that can be used to fetch
4972information about columns in specified tables.
4973
4974The arguments $schema, $table and $column may accept search patterns
4975according to the database/driver, for example: $table = '%FOO%';
4976
4977Note: The support for the selection criteria is driver specific. If the
4978driver doesn't support one or more of them then you may get back more
4979than you asked for and can do the filtering yourself.
4980
4981Note: If your driver does not support column_info an undef is
4982returned. This is distinct from asking for something which does not
4983exist in a driver which supports column_info as a valid statement
4984handle to an empty result-set will be returned in this case.
4985
4986If the arguments don't match any tables then you'll still get a statement
4987handle, it'll just return no rows.
4988
4989The statement handle returned has at least the following fields in the
4990order shown below. Other fields, after these, may also be present.
4991
4992B<TABLE_CAT>: The catalog identifier.
4993This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
4994which is often the case. This field is empty if not applicable to the
4995table.
4996
4997B<TABLE_SCHEM>: The schema identifier.
4998This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
4999and empty if not applicable to the table.
5000
5001B<TABLE_NAME>: The table identifier.
5002Note: A driver may provide column metadata not only for base tables, but
5003also for derived objects like SYNONYMS etc.
5004
5005B<COLUMN_NAME>: The column identifier.
5006
5007B<DATA_TYPE>: The concise data type code.
5008
5009B<TYPE_NAME>: A data source dependent data type name.
5010
5011B<COLUMN_SIZE>: The column size.
5012This is the maximum length in characters for character data types,
5013the number of digits or bits for numeric data types or the length
5014in the representation of temporal types.
5015See the relevant specifications for detailed information.
5016
5017B<BUFFER_LENGTH>: The length in bytes of transferred data.
5018
5019B<DECIMAL_DIGITS>: The total number of significant digits to the right of
5020the decimal point.
5021
5022B<NUM_PREC_RADIX>: The radix for numeric precision.
5023The value is 10 or 2 for numeric data types and NULL (C<undef>) if not
5024applicable.
5025
5026B<NULLABLE>: Indicates if a column can accept NULLs.
5027The following values are defined:
5028
5029 SQL_NO_NULLS 0
5030 SQL_NULLABLE 1
5031 SQL_NULLABLE_UNKNOWN 2
5032
5033B<REMARKS>: A description of the column.
5034
5035B<COLUMN_DEF>: The default value of the column, in a format that can be used
5036directly in an SQL statement.
5037
5038Note that this may be an expression and not simply the text used for the
5039default value in the original CREATE TABLE statement. For example, given:
5040
5041 col1 char(30) default current_user -- a 'function'
5042 col2 char(30) default 'string' -- a string literal
5043
5044where "current_user" is the name of a function, the corresponding C<COLUMN_DEF>
5045values would be:
5046
5047 Database col1 col2
5048 -------- ---- ----
5049 Oracle: current_user 'string'
5050 Postgres: "current_user"() 'string'::text
5051 MS SQL: (user_name()) ('string')
5052
5053B<SQL_DATA_TYPE>: The SQL data type.
5054
5055B<SQL_DATETIME_SUB>: The subtype code for datetime and interval data types.
5056
5057B<CHAR_OCTET_LENGTH>: The maximum length in bytes of a character or binary
5058data type column.
5059
5060B<ORDINAL_POSITION>: The column sequence number (starting with 1).
5061
5062B<IS_NULLABLE>: Indicates if the column can accept NULLs.
5063Possible values are: 'NO', 'YES' and ''.
5064
5065SQL/CLI defines the following additional columns:
5066
5067 CHAR_SET_CAT
5068 CHAR_SET_SCHEM
5069 CHAR_SET_NAME
5070 COLLATION_CAT
5071 COLLATION_SCHEM
5072 COLLATION_NAME
5073 UDT_CAT
5074 UDT_SCHEM
5075 UDT_NAME
5076 DOMAIN_CAT
5077 DOMAIN_SCHEM
5078 DOMAIN_NAME
5079 SCOPE_CAT
5080 SCOPE_SCHEM
5081 SCOPE_NAME
5082 MAX_CARDINALITY
5083 DTD_IDENTIFIER
5084 IS_SELF_REF
5085
5086Drivers capable of supplying any of those values should do so in
5087the corresponding column and supply undef values for the others.
5088
5089Drivers wishing to provide extra database/driver specific information
5090should do so in extra columns beyond all those listed above, and
5091use lowercase field names with the driver-specific prefix (i.e.,
5092'ora_...'). Applications accessing such fields should do so by name
5093and not by column number.
5094
5095The result set is ordered by TABLE_CAT, TABLE_SCHEM, TABLE_NAME
5096and ORDINAL_POSITION.
5097
5098Note: There is some overlap with statement handle attributes (in perl) and
5099SQLDescribeCol (in ODBC). However, SQLColumns provides more metadata.
5100
5101See also L</"Catalog Methods"> and L</"Standards Reference Information">.
5102
5103=head3 C<primary_key_info>
5104
5105 $sth = $dbh->primary_key_info( $catalog, $schema, $table );
5106
5107 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
5108
5109Returns an active statement handle that can be used to fetch information
5110about columns that make up the primary key for a table.
5111The arguments don't accept search patterns (unlike table_info()).
5112
5113The statement handle will return one row per column, ordered by
5114TABLE_CAT, TABLE_SCHEM, TABLE_NAME, and KEY_SEQ.
5115If there is no primary key then the statement handle will fetch no rows.
5116
5117Note: The support for the selection criteria, such as $catalog, is
5118driver specific. If the driver doesn't support catalogs and/or
5119schemas, it may ignore these criteria.
5120
5121The statement handle returned has at least the following fields in the
5122order shown below. Other fields, after these, may also be present.
5123
5124B<TABLE_CAT>: The catalog identifier.
5125This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5126which is often the case. This field is empty if not applicable to the
5127table.
5128
5129B<TABLE_SCHEM>: The schema identifier.
5130This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5131and empty if not applicable to the table.
5132
5133B<TABLE_NAME>: The table identifier.
5134
5135B<COLUMN_NAME>: The column identifier.
5136
5137B<KEY_SEQ>: The column sequence number (starting with 1).
5138Note: This field is named B<ORDINAL_POSITION> in SQL/CLI.
5139
5140B<PK_NAME>: The primary key constraint identifier.
5141This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source.
5142
5143See also L</"Catalog Methods"> and L</"Standards Reference Information">.
5144
5145=head3 C<primary_key>
5146
5147 @key_column_names = $dbh->primary_key( $catalog, $schema, $table );
5148
5149Simple interface to the primary_key_info() method. Returns a list of
5150the column names that comprise the primary key of the specified table.
5151The list is in primary key column sequence order.
5152If there is no primary key then an empty list is returned.
5153
5154=head3 C<foreign_key_info>
5155
5156 $sth = $dbh->foreign_key_info( $pk_catalog, $pk_schema, $pk_table
5157 , $fk_catalog, $fk_schema, $fk_table );
5158
5159 $sth = $dbh->foreign_key_info( $pk_catalog, $pk_schema, $pk_table
5160 , $fk_catalog, $fk_schema, $fk_table
5161 , \%attr );
5162
5163 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
5164
5165Returns an active statement handle that can be used to fetch information
5166about foreign keys in and/or referencing the specified table(s).
5167The arguments don't accept search patterns (unlike table_info()).
5168
5169C<$pk_catalog>, C<$pk_schema>, C<$pk_table>
5170identify the primary (unique) key table (B<PKT>).
5171
5172C<$fk_catalog>, C<$fk_schema>, C<$fk_table>
5173identify the foreign key table (B<FKT>).
5174
5175If both B<PKT> and B<FKT> are given, the function returns the foreign key, if
5176any, in table B<FKT> that refers to the primary (unique) key of table B<PKT>.
5177(Note: In SQL/CLI, the result is implementation-defined.)
5178
5179If only B<PKT> is given, then the result set contains the primary key
5180of that table and all foreign keys that refer to it.
5181
5182If only B<FKT> is given, then the result set contains all foreign keys
5183in that table and the primary keys to which they refer.
5184(Note: In SQL/CLI, the result includes unique keys too.)
5185
5186For example:
5187
5188 $sth = $dbh->foreign_key_info( undef, $user, 'master');
5189 $sth = $dbh->foreign_key_info( undef, undef, undef , undef, $user, 'detail');
5190 $sth = $dbh->foreign_key_info( undef, $user, 'master', undef, $user, 'detail');
5191
5192 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
5193
5194Note: The support for the selection criteria, such as C<$catalog>, is
5195driver specific. If the driver doesn't support catalogs and/or
5196schemas, it may ignore these criteria.
5197
5198The statement handle returned has the following fields in the order shown below.
5199Because ODBC never includes unique keys, they define different columns in the
5200result set than SQL/CLI. SQL/CLI column names are shown in parentheses.
5201
5202B<PKTABLE_CAT ( UK_TABLE_CAT )>:
5203The primary (unique) key table catalog identifier.
5204This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5205which is often the case. This field is empty if not applicable to the
5206table.
5207
5208B<PKTABLE_SCHEM ( UK_TABLE_SCHEM )>:
5209The primary (unique) key table schema identifier.
5210This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5211and empty if not applicable to the table.
5212
5213B<PKTABLE_NAME ( UK_TABLE_NAME )>:
5214The primary (unique) key table identifier.
5215
5216B<PKCOLUMN_NAME (UK_COLUMN_NAME )>:
5217The primary (unique) key column identifier.
5218
5219B<FKTABLE_CAT ( FK_TABLE_CAT )>:
5220The foreign key table catalog identifier.
5221This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5222which is often the case. This field is empty if not applicable to the
5223table.
5224
5225B<FKTABLE_SCHEM ( FK_TABLE_SCHEM )>:
5226The foreign key table schema identifier.
5227This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5228and empty if not applicable to the table.
5229
5230B<FKTABLE_NAME ( FK_TABLE_NAME )>:
5231The foreign key table identifier.
5232
5233B<FKCOLUMN_NAME ( FK_COLUMN_NAME )>:
5234The foreign key column identifier.
5235
5236B<KEY_SEQ ( ORDINAL_POSITION )>:
5237The column sequence number (starting with 1).
5238
5239B<UPDATE_RULE ( UPDATE_RULE )>:
5240The referential action for the UPDATE rule.
5241The following codes are defined:
5242
5243 CASCADE 0
5244 RESTRICT 1
5245 SET NULL 2
5246 NO ACTION 3
5247 SET DEFAULT 4
5248
5249B<DELETE_RULE ( DELETE_RULE )>:
5250The referential action for the DELETE rule.
5251The codes are the same as for UPDATE_RULE.
5252
5253B<FK_NAME ( FK_NAME )>:
5254The foreign key name.
5255
5256B<PK_NAME ( UK_NAME )>:
5257The primary (unique) key name.
5258
5259B<DEFERRABILITY ( DEFERABILITY )>:
5260The deferrability of the foreign key constraint.
5261The following codes are defined:
5262
5263 INITIALLY DEFERRED 5
5264 INITIALLY IMMEDIATE 6
5265 NOT DEFERRABLE 7
5266
5267B< ( UNIQUE_OR_PRIMARY )>:
5268This column is necessary if a driver includes all candidate (i.e. primary and
5269alternate) keys in the result set (as specified by SQL/CLI).
5270The value of this column is UNIQUE if the foreign key references an alternate
5271key and PRIMARY if the foreign key references a primary key, or it
5272may be undefined if the driver doesn't have access to the information.
5273
5274See also L</"Catalog Methods"> and L</"Standards Reference Information">.
5275
5276=head3 C<statistics_info>
5277
5278B<Warning:> This method is experimental and may change.
5279
5280 $sth = $dbh->statistics_info( $catalog, $schema, $table, $unique_only, $quick );
5281
5282 # then $sth->fetchall_arrayref or $sth->fetchall_hashref etc
5283
5284Returns an active statement handle that can be used to fetch statistical
5285information about a table and its indexes.
5286
5287The arguments don't accept search patterns (unlike L</table_info>).
5288
5289If the boolean argument $unique_only is true, only UNIQUE indexes will be
5290returned in the result set, otherwise all indexes will be returned.
5291
5292If the boolean argument $quick is set, the actual statistical information
5293columns (CARDINALITY and PAGES) will only be returned if they are readily
5294available from the server, and might not be current. Some databases may
5295return stale statistics or no statistics at all with this flag set.
5296
5297The statement handle will return at most one row per column name per index,
5298plus at most one row for the entire table itself, ordered by NON_UNIQUE, TYPE,
5299INDEX_QUALIFIER, INDEX_NAME, and ORDINAL_POSITION.
5300
5301Note: The support for the selection criteria, such as $catalog, is
5302driver specific. If the driver doesn't support catalogs and/or
5303schemas, it may ignore these criteria.
5304
5305The statement handle returned has at least the following fields in the
5306order shown below. Other fields, after these, may also be present.
5307
5308B<TABLE_CAT>: The catalog identifier.
5309This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5310which is often the case. This field is empty if not applicable to the
5311table.
5312
5313B<TABLE_SCHEM>: The schema identifier.
5314This field is NULL (C<undef>) if not applicable to the data source,
5315and empty if not applicable to the table.
5316
5317B<TABLE_NAME>: The table identifier.
5318
5319B<NON_UNIQUE>: Unique index indicator.
5320Returns 0 for unique indexes, 1 for non-unique indexes
5321
5322B<INDEX_QUALIFIER>: Index qualifier identifier.
5323The identifier that is used to qualify the index name when doing a
5324C<DROP INDEX>; NULL (C<undef>) is returned if an index qualifier is not
5325supported by the data source.
5326If a non-NULL (defined) value is returned in this column, it must be used
5327to qualify the index name on a C<DROP INDEX> statement; otherwise,
5328the TABLE_SCHEM should be used to qualify the index name.
5329
5330B<INDEX_NAME>: The index identifier.
5331
5332B<TYPE>: The type of information being returned. Can be any of the
5333following values: 'table', 'btree', 'clustered', 'content', 'hashed',
5334or 'other'.
5335
5336In the case that this field is 'table', all fields
5337other than TABLE_CAT, TABLE_SCHEM, TABLE_NAME, TYPE,
5338CARDINALITY, and PAGES will be NULL (C<undef>).
5339
5340B<ORDINAL_POSITION>: Column sequence number (starting with 1).
5341
5342B<COLUMN_NAME>: The column identifier.
5343
5344B<ASC_OR_DESC>: Column sort sequence.
5345C<A> for Ascending, C<D> for Descending, or NULL (C<undef>) if
5346not supported for this index.
5347
5348B<CARDINALITY>: Cardinality of the table or index.
5349For indexes, this is the number of unique values in the index.
5350For tables, this is the number of rows in the table.
5351If not supported, the value will be NULL (C<undef>).
5352
5353B<PAGES>: Number of storage pages used by this table or index.
5354If not supported, the value will be NULL (C<undef>).
5355
5356B<FILTER_CONDITION>: The index filter condition as a string.
5357If the index is not a filtered index, or it cannot be determined
5358whether the index is a filtered index, this value is NULL (C<undef>).
5359If the index is a filtered index, but the filter condition
5360cannot be determined, this value is the empty string C<''>.
5361Otherwise it will be the literal filter condition as a string,
5362such as C<SALARY <= 4500>.
5363
5364See also L</"Catalog Methods"> and L</"Standards Reference Information">.
5365
5366=head3 C<tables>
5367
5368 @names = $dbh->tables( $catalog, $schema, $table, $type );
5369 @names = $dbh->tables; # deprecated
5370
5371Simple interface to table_info(). Returns a list of matching
5372table names, possibly including a catalog/schema prefix.
5373
5374See L</table_info> for a description of the parameters.
5375
5376If C<$dbh-E<gt>get_info(29)> returns true (29 is SQL_IDENTIFIER_QUOTE_CHAR)
5377then the table names are constructed and quoted by L</quote_identifier>
5378to ensure they are usable even if they contain whitespace or reserved
5379words etc. This means that the table names returned will include
5380quote characters.
5381
5382=head3 C<type_info_all>
5383
5384 $type_info_all = $dbh->type_info_all;
5385
5386Returns a reference to an array which holds information about each data
5387type variant supported by the database and driver. The array and its
5388contents should be treated as read-only.
5389
5390The first item is a reference to an 'index' hash of C<Name =>E<gt> C<Index> pairs.
5391The items following that are references to arrays, one per supported data
5392type variant. The leading index hash defines the names and order of the
5393fields within the arrays that follow it.
5394For example:
5395
5396 $type_info_all = [
5397 { TYPE_NAME => 0,
5398 DATA_TYPE => 1,
5399 COLUMN_SIZE => 2, # was PRECISION originally
5400 LITERAL_PREFIX => 3,
5401 LITERAL_SUFFIX => 4,
5402 CREATE_PARAMS => 5,
5403 NULLABLE => 6,
5404 CASE_SENSITIVE => 7,
5405 SEARCHABLE => 8,
5406 UNSIGNED_ATTRIBUTE=> 9,
5407 FIXED_PREC_SCALE => 10, # was MONEY originally
5408 AUTO_UNIQUE_VALUE => 11, # was AUTO_INCREMENT originally
5409 LOCAL_TYPE_NAME => 12,
5410 MINIMUM_SCALE => 13,
5411 MAXIMUM_SCALE => 14,
5412 SQL_DATA_TYPE => 15,
5413 SQL_DATETIME_SUB => 16,
5414 NUM_PREC_RADIX => 17,
5415 INTERVAL_PRECISION=> 18,
5416 },
5417 [ 'VARCHAR', SQL_VARCHAR,
5418 undef, "'","'", undef,0, 1,1,0,0,0,undef,1,255, undef
5419 ],
5420 [ 'INTEGER', SQL_INTEGER,
5421 undef, "", "", undef,0, 0,1,0,0,0,undef,0, 0, 10
5422 ],
5423 ];
5424
5425More than one row may have the same value in the C<DATA_TYPE>
5426field if there are different ways to spell the type name and/or there
5427are variants of the type with different attributes (e.g., with and
5428without C<AUTO_UNIQUE_VALUE> set, with and without C<UNSIGNED_ATTRIBUTE>, etc).
5429
5430The rows are ordered by C<DATA_TYPE> first and then by how closely each
5431type maps to the corresponding ODBC SQL data type, closest first.
5432
5433The meaning of the fields is described in the documentation for
5434the L</type_info> method.
5435
5436An 'index' hash is provided so you don't need to rely on index
5437values defined above. However, using DBD::ODBC with some old ODBC
5438drivers may return older names, shown as comments in the example above.
5439Another issue with the index hash is that the lettercase of the
5440keys is not defined. It is usually uppercase, as show here, but
5441drivers may return names with any lettercase.
5442
5443Drivers are also free to return extra driver-specific columns of
5444information - though it's recommended that they start at column
5445index 50 to leave room for expansion of the DBI/ODBC specification.
5446
5447The type_info_all() method is not normally used directly.
5448The L</type_info> method provides a more usable and useful interface
5449to the data.
5450
5451=head3 C<type_info>
5452
5453 @type_info = $dbh->type_info($data_type);
5454
5455Returns a list of hash references holding information about one or more
5456variants of $data_type. The list is ordered by C<DATA_TYPE> first and
5457then by how closely each type maps to the corresponding ODBC SQL data
5458type, closest first. If called in a scalar context then only the first
5459(best) element is returned.
5460
5461If $data_type is undefined or C<SQL_ALL_TYPES>, then the list will
5462contain hashes for all data type variants supported by the database and driver.
5463
5464If $data_type is an array reference then C<type_info> returns the
5465information for the I<first> type in the array that has any matches.
5466
5467The keys of the hash follow the same letter case conventions as the
5468rest of the DBI (see L</Naming Conventions and Name Space>). The
5469following uppercase items should always exist, though may be undef:
5470
5471=over 4
5472
5473=item TYPE_NAME (string)
5474
5475Data type name for use in CREATE TABLE statements etc.
5476
5477=item DATA_TYPE (integer)
5478
5479SQL data type number.
5480
5481=item COLUMN_SIZE (integer)
5482
5483For numeric types, this is either the total number of digits (if the
5484NUM_PREC_RADIX value is 10) or the total number of bits allowed in the
5485column (if NUM_PREC_RADIX is 2).
5486
5487For string types, this is the maximum size of the string in characters.
5488
5489For date and interval types, this is the maximum number of characters
5490needed to display the value.
5491
5492=item LITERAL_PREFIX (string)
5493
5494Characters used to prefix a literal. A typical prefix is "C<'>" for characters,
5495or possibly "C<0x>" for binary values passed as hexadecimal. NULL (C<undef>) is
5496returned for data types for which this is not applicable.
5497
5498
5499=item LITERAL_SUFFIX (string)
5500
5501Characters used to suffix a literal. Typically "C<'>" for characters.
5502NULL (C<undef>) is returned for data types where this is not applicable.
5503
5504=item CREATE_PARAMS (string)
5505
5506Parameter names for data type definition. For example, C<CREATE_PARAMS> for a
5507C<DECIMAL> would be "C<precision,scale>" if the DECIMAL type should be
5508declared as C<DECIMAL(>I<precision,scale>C<)> where I<precision> and I<scale>
5509are integer values. For a C<VARCHAR> it would be "C<max length>".
5510NULL (C<undef>) is returned for data types for which this is not applicable.
5511
5512=item NULLABLE (integer)
5513
5514Indicates whether the data type accepts a NULL value:
5515C<0> or an empty string = no, C<1> = yes, C<2> = unknown.
5516
5517=item CASE_SENSITIVE (boolean)
5518
5519Indicates whether the data type is case sensitive in collations and
5520comparisons.
5521
5522=item SEARCHABLE (integer)
5523
5524Indicates how the data type can be used in a WHERE clause, as
5525follows:
5526
5527 0 - Cannot be used in a WHERE clause
5528 1 - Only with a LIKE predicate
5529 2 - All comparison operators except LIKE
5530 3 - Can be used in a WHERE clause with any comparison operator
5531
5532=item UNSIGNED_ATTRIBUTE (boolean)
5533
5534Indicates whether the data type is unsigned. NULL (C<undef>) is returned
5535for data types for which this is not applicable.
5536
5537=item FIXED_PREC_SCALE (boolean)
5538
5539Indicates whether the data type always has the same precision and scale
5540(such as a money type). NULL (C<undef>) is returned for data types
5541for which
5542this is not applicable.
5543
5544=item AUTO_UNIQUE_VALUE (boolean)
5545
5546Indicates whether a column of this data type is automatically set to a
5547unique value whenever a new row is inserted. NULL (C<undef>) is returned
5548for data types for which this is not applicable.
5549
5550=item LOCAL_TYPE_NAME (string)
5551
5552Localized version of the C<TYPE_NAME> for use in dialog with users.
5553NULL (C<undef>) is returned if a localized name is not available (in which
5554case C<TYPE_NAME> should be used).
5555
5556=item MINIMUM_SCALE (integer)
5557
5558The minimum scale of the data type. If a data type has a fixed scale,
5559then C<MAXIMUM_SCALE> holds the same value. NULL (C<undef>) is returned for
5560data types for which this is not applicable.
5561
5562=item MAXIMUM_SCALE (integer)
5563
5564The maximum scale of the data type. If a data type has a fixed scale,
5565then C<MINIMUM_SCALE> holds the same value. NULL (C<undef>) is returned for
5566data types for which this is not applicable.
5567
5568=item SQL_DATA_TYPE (integer)
5569
5570This column is the same as the C<DATA_TYPE> column, except for interval
5571and datetime data types. For interval and datetime data types, the
5572C<SQL_DATA_TYPE> field will return C<SQL_INTERVAL> or C<SQL_DATETIME>, and the
5573C<SQL_DATETIME_SUB> field below will return the subcode for the specific
5574interval or datetime data type. If this field is NULL, then the driver
5575does not support or report on interval or datetime subtypes.
5576
5577=item SQL_DATETIME_SUB (integer)
5578
5579For interval or datetime data types, where the C<SQL_DATA_TYPE>
5580field above is C<SQL_INTERVAL> or C<SQL_DATETIME>, this field will
5581hold the I<subcode> for the specific interval or datetime data type.
5582Otherwise it will be NULL (C<undef>).
5583
5584Although not mentioned explicitly in the standards, it seems there
5585is a simple relationship between these values:
5586
5587 DATA_TYPE == (10 * SQL_DATA_TYPE) + SQL_DATETIME_SUB
5588
5589=item NUM_PREC_RADIX (integer)
5590
5591The radix value of the data type. For approximate numeric types,
5592C<NUM_PREC_RADIX>
5593contains the value 2 and C<COLUMN_SIZE> holds the number of bits. For
5594exact numeric types, C<NUM_PREC_RADIX> contains the value 10 and C<COLUMN_SIZE> holds
5595the number of decimal digits. NULL (C<undef>) is returned either for data types
5596for which this is not applicable or if the driver cannot report this information.
5597
5598=item INTERVAL_PRECISION (integer)
5599
5600The interval leading precision for interval types. NULL is returned
5601either for data types for which this is not applicable or if the driver
5602cannot report this information.
5603
5604=back
5605
5606For example, to find the type name for the fields in a select statement
5607you can do:
5608
5609 @names = map { scalar $dbh->type_info($_)->{TYPE_NAME} } @{ $sth->{TYPE} }
5610
5611Since DBI and ODBC drivers vary in how they map their types into the
5612ISO standard types you may need to search for more than one type.
5613Here's an example looking for a usable type to store a date:
5614
5615 $my_date_type = $dbh->type_info( [ SQL_DATE, SQL_TIMESTAMP ] );
5616
5617Similarly, to more reliably find a type to store small integers, you could
5618use a list starting with C<SQL_SMALLINT>, C<SQL_INTEGER>, C<SQL_DECIMAL>, etc.
5619
5620See also L</"Standards Reference Information">.
5621
5622
5623=head3 C<quote>
5624
5625 $sql = $dbh->quote($value);
5626 $sql = $dbh->quote($value, $data_type);
5627
5628Quote a string literal for use as a literal value in an SQL statement,
5629by escaping any special characters (such as quotation marks)
5630contained within the string and adding the required type of outer
5631quotation marks.
5632
5633 $sql = sprintf "SELECT foo FROM bar WHERE baz = %s",
5634 $dbh->quote("Don't");
5635
5636For most database types, at least those that conform to SQL standards, quote
5637would return C<'Don''t'> (including the outer quotation marks). For others it
5638may return something like C<'Don\'t'>
5639
5640An undefined C<$value> value will be returned as the string C<NULL> (without
5641single quotation marks) to match how NULLs are represented in SQL.
5642
5643If C<$data_type> is supplied, it is used to try to determine the required
5644quoting behaviour by using the information returned by L</type_info>.
5645As a special case, the standard numeric types are optimized to return
5646C<$value> without calling C<type_info>.
5647
5648Quote will probably I<not> be able to deal with all possible input
5649(such as binary data or data containing newlines), and is not related in
5650any way with escaping or quoting shell meta-characters.
5651
5652It is valid for the quote() method to return an SQL expression that
5653evaluates to the desired string. For example:
5654
5655 $quoted = $dbh->quote("one\ntwo\0three")
5656
5657may return something like:
5658
5659 CONCAT('one', CHAR(12), 'two', CHAR(0), 'three')
5660
5661The quote() method should I<not> be used with L</"Placeholders and
5662Bind Values">.
5663
5664=head3 C<quote_identifier>
5665
5666 $sql = $dbh->quote_identifier( $name );
5667 $sql = $dbh->quote_identifier( $catalog, $schema, $table, \%attr );
5668
5669Quote an identifier (table name etc.) for use in an SQL statement,
5670by escaping any special characters (such as double quotation marks)
5671it contains and adding the required type of outer quotation marks.
5672
5673Undefined names are ignored and the remainder are quoted and then
5674joined together, typically with a dot (C<.>) character. For example:
5675
5676 $id = $dbh->quote_identifier( undef, 'Her schema', 'My table' );
5677
5678would, for most database types, return C<"Her schema"."My table">
5679(including all the double quotation marks).
5680
5681If three names are supplied then the first is assumed to be a
5682catalog name and special rules may be applied based on what L</get_info>
5683returns for SQL_CATALOG_NAME_SEPARATOR (41) and SQL_CATALOG_LOCATION (114).
5684For example, for Oracle:
5685
5686 $id = $dbh->quote_identifier( 'link', 'schema', 'table' );
5687
5688would return C<"schema"."table"@"link">.
5689
5690=head3 C<take_imp_data>
5691
5692 $imp_data = $dbh->take_imp_data;
5693
5694Leaves the $dbh in an almost dead, zombie-like, state and returns
5695a binary string of raw implementation data from the driver which
5696describes the current database connection. Effectively it detaches
5697the underlying database API connection data from the DBI handle.
5698After calling take_imp_data(), all other methods except C<DESTROY>
5699will generate a warning and return undef.
5700
5701Why would you want to do this? You don't, forget I even mentioned it.
5702Unless, that is, you're implementing something advanced like a
5703multi-threaded connection pool. See L<DBI::Pool>.
5704
5705The returned $imp_data can be passed as a C<dbi_imp_data> attribute
5706to a later connect() call, even in a separate thread in the same
5707process, where the driver can use it to 'adopt' the existing
5708connection that the implementation data was taken from.
5709
5710Some things to keep in mind...
5711
5712B<*> the $imp_data holds the only reference to the underlying
5713database API connection data. That connection is still 'live' and
5714won't be cleaned up properly unless the $imp_data is used to create
5715a new $dbh which is then allowed to disconnect() normally.
5716
5717B<*> using the same $imp_data to create more than one other new
5718$dbh at a time may well lead to unpleasant problems. Don't do that.
5719
5720Any child statement handles are effectively destroyed when take_imp_data() is
5721called.
5722
5723The C<take_imp_data> method was added in DBI 1.36 but wasn't useful till 1.49.
5724
5725
5726=head2 Database Handle Attributes
5727
5728This section describes attributes specific to database handles.
5729
5730Changes to these database handle attributes do not affect any other
5731existing or future database handles.
5732
5733Attempting to set or get the value of an unknown attribute generates a warning,
5734except for private driver-specific attributes (which all have names
5735starting with a lowercase letter).
5736
5737Example:
5738
5739 $h->{AutoCommit} = ...; # set/write
5740 ... = $h->{AutoCommit}; # get/read
5741
5742=head3 C<AutoCommit>
5743
5744Type: boolean
5745
5746If true, then database changes cannot be rolled-back (undone). If false,
5747then database changes automatically occur within a "transaction", which
5748must either be committed or rolled back using the C<commit> or C<rollback>
5749methods.
5750
5751Drivers should always default to C<AutoCommit> mode (an unfortunate
5752choice largely forced on the DBI by ODBC and JDBC conventions.)
5753
5754Attempting to set C<AutoCommit> to an unsupported value is a fatal error.
5755This is an important feature of the DBI. Applications that need
5756full transaction behaviour can set C<$dbh-E<gt>{AutoCommit} = 0> (or
5757set C<AutoCommit> to 0 via L</connect>)
5758without having to check that the value was assigned successfully.
5759
5760For the purposes of this description, we can divide databases into three
5761categories:
5762
5763 Databases which don't support transactions at all.
5764 Databases in which a transaction is always active.
5765 Databases in which a transaction must be explicitly started (C<'BEGIN WORK'>).
5766
5767B<* Databases which don't support transactions at all>
5768
5769For these databases, attempting to turn C<AutoCommit> off is a fatal error.
5770C<commit> and C<rollback> both issue warnings about being ineffective while
5771C<AutoCommit> is in effect.
5772
5773B<* Databases in which a transaction is always active>
5774
5775These are typically mainstream commercial relational databases with
5776"ANSI standard" transaction behaviour.
5777If C<AutoCommit> is off, then changes to the database won't have any
5778lasting effect unless L</commit> is called (but see also
5779L</disconnect>). If L</rollback> is called then any changes since the
5780last commit are undone.
5781
5782If C<AutoCommit> is on, then the effect is the same as if the DBI
5783called C<commit> automatically after every successful database
5784operation. So calling C<commit> or C<rollback> explicitly while
5785C<AutoCommit> is on would be ineffective because the changes would
5786have already been committed.
5787
5788Changing C<AutoCommit> from off to on will trigger a L</commit>.
5789
5790For databases which don't support a specific auto-commit mode, the
5791driver has to commit each statement automatically using an explicit
5792C<COMMIT> after it completes successfully (and roll it back using an
5793explicit C<ROLLBACK> if it fails). The error information reported to the
5794application will correspond to the statement which was executed, unless
5795it succeeded and the commit or rollback failed.
5796
5797B<* Databases in which a transaction must be explicitly started>
5798
5799For these databases, the intention is to have them act like databases in
5800which a transaction is always active (as described above).
5801
5802To do this, the driver will automatically begin an explicit transaction
5803when C<AutoCommit> is turned off, or after a L</commit> or
5804L</rollback> (or when the application issues the next database
5805operation after one of those events).
5806
5807In this way, the application does not have to treat these databases
5808as a special case.
5809
5810See L</commit>, L</disconnect> and L</Transactions> for other important
5811notes about transactions.
5812
5813
5814=head3 C<Driver>
5815
5816Type: handle
5817
5818Holds the handle of the parent driver. The only recommended use for this
5819is to find the name of the driver using:
5820
5821 $dbh->{Driver}->{Name}
5822
5823
5824=head3 C<Name>
5825
5826Type: string
5827
5828Holds the "name" of the database. Usually (and recommended to be) the
5829same as the "C<dbi:DriverName:...>" string used to connect to the database,
5830but with the leading "C<dbi:DriverName:>" removed.
5831
5832
5833=head3 C<Statement>
5834
5835Type: string, read-only
5836
5837Returns the statement string passed to the most recent L</prepare> or
5838L</do> method called in this database handle, even if that method
5839failed. This is especially useful where C<RaiseError> is enabled and
5840the exception handler checks $@ and sees that a 'prepare' method call
5841failed.
5842
5843
5844=head3 C<RowCacheSize>
5845
5846Type: integer
5847
5848A hint to the driver indicating the size of the local row cache that the
5849application would like the driver to use for future C<SELECT> statements.
5850If a row cache is not implemented, then setting C<RowCacheSize> is ignored
5851and getting the value returns C<undef>.
5852
5853Some C<RowCacheSize> values have special meaning, as follows:
5854
5855 0 - Automatically determine a reasonable cache size for each C<SELECT>
5856 1 - Disable the local row cache
5857 >1 - Cache this many rows
5858 <0 - Cache as many rows that will fit into this much memory for each C<SELECT>.
5859
5860Note that large cache sizes may require a very large amount of memory
5861(I<cached rows * maximum size of row>). Also, a large cache will cause
5862a longer delay not only for the first fetch, but also whenever the
5863cache needs refilling.
5864
5865See also the L</RowsInCache> statement handle attribute.
5866
5867=head3 C<Username>
5868
5869Type: string
5870
5871Returns the username used to connect to the database.
5872
5873
5874=head1 DBI STATEMENT HANDLE OBJECTS
5875
5876This section lists the methods and attributes associated with DBI
5877statement handles.
5878
5879=head2 Statement Handle Methods
5880
5881The DBI defines the following methods for use on DBI statement handles:
5882
5883=head3 C<bind_param>
5884
5885 $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value)
5886 $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value, \%attr)
5887 $sth->bind_param($p_num, $bind_value, $bind_type)
5888
5889The C<bind_param> method takes a copy of $bind_value and associates it
5890(binds it) with a placeholder, identified by $p_num, embedded in
5891the prepared statement. Placeholders are indicated with question
5892mark character (C<?>). For example:
5893
5894 $dbh->{RaiseError} = 1; # save having to check each method call
5895 $sth = $dbh->prepare("SELECT name, age FROM people WHERE name LIKE ?");
5896 $sth->bind_param(1, "John%"); # placeholders are numbered from 1
5897 $sth->execute;
5898 DBI::dump_results($sth);
5899
5900See L</"Placeholders and Bind Values"> for more information.
5901
5902
5903B<Data Types for Placeholders>
5904
5905The C<\%attr> parameter can be used to hint at the data type the
5906placeholder should have. This is rarely needed. Typically, the driver is only
5907interested in knowing if the placeholder should be bound as a number or a string.
5908
5909 $sth->bind_param(1, $value, { TYPE => SQL_INTEGER });
5910
5911As a short-cut for the common case, the data type can be passed
5912directly, in place of the C<\%attr> hash reference. This example is
5913equivalent to the one above:
5914
5915 $sth->bind_param(1, $value, SQL_INTEGER);
5916
5917The C<TYPE> value indicates the standard (non-driver-specific) type for
5918this parameter. To specify the driver-specific type, the driver may
5919support a driver-specific attribute, such as C<{ ora_type =E<gt> 97 }>.
5920
5921The SQL_INTEGER and other related constants can be imported using
5922
5923 use DBI qw(:sql_types);
5924
5925See L</"DBI Constants"> for more information.
5926
5927The data type is 'sticky' in that bind values passed to execute() are bound
5928with the data type specified by earlier bind_param() calls, if any.
5929Portable applications should not rely on being able to change the data type
5930after the first C<bind_param> call.
5931
5932Perl only has string and number scalar data types. All database types
5933that aren't numbers are bound as strings and must be in a format the
5934database will understand except where the bind_param() TYPE attribute
5935specifies a type that implies a particular format. For example, given:
5936
5937 $sth->bind_param(1, $value, SQL_DATETIME);
5938
5939the driver should expect $value to be in the ODBC standard SQL_DATETIME
5940format, which is 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'. Similarly for SQL_DATE, SQL_TIME etc.
5941
5942As an alternative to specifying the data type in the C<bind_param> call,
5943you can let the driver pass the value as the default type (C<VARCHAR>).
5944You can then use an SQL function to convert the type within the statement.
5945For example:
5946
5947 INSERT INTO price(code, price) VALUES (?, CONVERT(MONEY,?))
5948
5949The C<CONVERT> function used here is just an example. The actual function
5950and syntax will vary between different databases and is non-portable.
5951
5952See also L</"Placeholders and Bind Values"> for more information.
5953
5954
5955=head3 C<bind_param_inout>
5956
5957 $rc = $sth->bind_param_inout($p_num, \$bind_value, $max_len) or die $sth->errstr;
5958 $rv = $sth->bind_param_inout($p_num, \$bind_value, $max_len, \%attr) or ...
5959 $rv = $sth->bind_param_inout($p_num, \$bind_value, $max_len, $bind_type) or ...
5960
5961This method acts like L</bind_param>, but also enables values to be
5962updated by the statement. The statement is typically
5963a call to a stored procedure. The C<$bind_value> must be passed as a
5964reference to the actual value to be used.
5965
5966Note that unlike L</bind_param>, the C<$bind_value> variable is not
5967copied when C<bind_param_inout> is called. Instead, the value in the
5968variable is read at the time L</execute> is called.
5969
5970The additional C<$max_len> parameter specifies the minimum amount of
5971memory to allocate to C<$bind_value> for the new value. If the value
5972returned from the database is too
5973big to fit, then the execution should fail. If unsure what value to use,
5974pick a generous length, i.e., a length larger than the longest value that would ever be
5975returned. The only cost of using a larger value than needed is wasted memory.
5976
5977Undefined values or C<undef> are used to indicate null values.
5978See also L</"Placeholders and Bind Values"> for more information.
5979
5980
5981=head3 C<bind_param_array>
5982
5983 $rc = $sth->bind_param_array($p_num, $array_ref_or_value)
5984 $rc = $sth->bind_param_array($p_num, $array_ref_or_value, \%attr)
5985 $rc = $sth->bind_param_array($p_num, $array_ref_or_value, $bind_type)
5986
5987The C<bind_param_array> method is used to bind an array of values
5988to a placeholder embedded in the prepared statement which is to be executed
5989with L</execute_array>. For example:
5990
5991 $dbh->{RaiseError} = 1; # save having to check each method call
5992 $sth = $dbh->prepare("INSERT INTO staff (first_name, last_name, dept) VALUES(?, ?, ?)");
5993 $sth->bind_param_array(1, [ 'John', 'Mary', 'Tim' ]);
5994 $sth->bind_param_array(2, [ 'Booth', 'Todd', 'Robinson' ]);
5995 $sth->bind_param_array(3, "SALES"); # scalar will be reused for each row
5996 $sth->execute_array( { ArrayTupleStatus => \my @tuple_status } );
5997
5998The C<%attr> ($bind_type) argument is the same as defined for L</bind_param>.
5999Refer to L</bind_param> for general details on using placeholders.
6000
6001(Note that bind_param_array() can I<not> be used to expand a
6002placeholder into a list of values for a statement like "SELECT foo
6003WHERE bar IN (?)". A placeholder can only ever represent one value
6004per execution.)
6005
6006Scalar values, including C<undef>, may also be bound by
6007C<bind_param_array>. In which case the same value will be used for each
6008L</execute> call. Driver-specific implementations may behave
6009differently, e.g., when binding to a stored procedure call, some
6010databases may permit mixing scalars and arrays as arguments.
6011
6012The default implementation provided by DBI (for drivers that have
6013not implemented array binding) is to iteratively call L</execute> for
6014each parameter tuple provided in the bound arrays. Drivers may
6015provide more optimized implementations using whatever bulk operation
6016support the database API provides. The default driver behaviour should
6017match the default DBI behaviour, but always consult your driver
6018documentation as there may be driver specific issues to consider.
6019
6020Note that the default implementation currently only supports non-data
6021returning statements (INSERT, UPDATE, but not SELECT). Also,
6022C<bind_param_array> and L</bind_param> cannot be mixed in the same
6023statement execution, and C<bind_param_array> must be used with
6024L</execute_array>; using C<bind_param_array> will have no effect
6025for L</execute>.
6026
6027The C<bind_param_array> method was added in DBI 1.22.
6028
6029=head3 C<execute>
6030
6031 $rv = $sth->execute or die $sth->errstr;
6032 $rv = $sth->execute(@bind_values) or die $sth->errstr;
6033
6034Perform whatever processing is necessary to execute the prepared
6035statement. An C<undef> is returned if an error occurs. A successful
6036C<execute> always returns true regardless of the number of rows affected,
6037even if it's zero (see below). It is always important to check the
6038return status of C<execute> (and most other DBI methods) for errors
6039if you're not using L</RaiseError>.
6040
6041For a I<non>-C<SELECT> statement, C<execute> returns the number of rows
6042affected, if known. If no rows were affected, then C<execute> returns
6043"C<0E0>", which Perl will treat as 0 but will regard as true. Note that it
6044is I<not> an error for no rows to be affected by a statement. If the
6045number of rows affected is not known, then C<execute> returns -1.
6046
6047For C<SELECT> statements, execute simply "starts" the query within the
6048database engine. Use one of the fetch methods to retrieve the data after
6049calling C<execute>. The C<execute> method does I<not> return the number of
6050rows that will be returned by the query (because most databases can't
6051tell in advance), it simply returns a true value.
6052
6053You can tell if the statement was a C<SELECT> statement by checking if
6054C<$sth-E<gt>{NUM_OF_FIELDS}> is greater than zero after calling C<execute>.
6055
6056If any arguments are given, then C<execute> will effectively call
6057L</bind_param> for each value before executing the statement. Values
6058bound in this way are usually treated as C<SQL_VARCHAR> types unless
6059the driver can determine the correct type (which is rare), or unless
6060C<bind_param> (or C<bind_param_inout>) has already been used to
6061specify the type.
6062
6063Note that passing C<execute> an empty array is the same as passing no arguments
6064at all, which will execute the statement with previously bound values.
6065That's probably not what you want.
6066
6067If execute() is called on a statement handle that's still active
6068($sth->{Active} is true) then it should effectively call finish()
6069to tidy up the previous execution results before starting this new
6070execution.
6071
6072=head3 C<execute_array>
6073
6074 $tuples = $sth->execute_array(\%attr) or die $sth->errstr;
6075 $tuples = $sth->execute_array(\%attr, @bind_values) or die $sth->errstr;
6076
6077 ($tuples, $rows) = $sth->execute_array(\%attr) or die $sth->errstr;
6078 ($tuples, $rows) = $sth->execute_array(\%attr, @bind_values) or die $sth->errstr;
6079
6080Execute the prepared statement once for each parameter tuple
6081(group of values) provided either in the @bind_values, or by prior
6082calls to L</bind_param_array>, or via a reference passed in \%attr.
6083
6084When called in scalar context the execute_array() method returns the
6085number of tuples executed, or C<undef> if an error occurred. Like
6086execute(), a successful execute_array() always returns true regardless
6087of the number of tuples executed, even if it's zero. If there were any
6088errors the ArrayTupleStatus array can be used to discover which tuples
6089failed and with what errors.
6090
6091When called in list context the execute_array() method returns two scalars;
6092$tuples is the same as calling execute_array() in scalar context and $rows is
6093the sum of the number of rows affected for each tuple, if available or
6094-1 if the driver cannot determine this.
6095If you are doing an update operation the returned rows affected may not be what
6096you expect if, for instance, one or more of the tuples affected the same row
6097multiple times. Some drivers may not yet support list context, in which case
6098$rows will be undef, or may not be able to provide the number of rows affected
6099when performing this batch operation, in which case $rows will be -1.
6100
6101Bind values for the tuples to be executed may be supplied row-wise
6102by an C<ArrayTupleFetch> attribute, or else column-wise in the
6103C<@bind_values> argument, or else column-wise by prior calls to
6104L</bind_param_array>.
6105
6106Where column-wise binding is used (via the C<@bind_values> argument
6107or calls to bind_param_array()) the maximum number of elements in
6108any one of the bound value arrays determines the number of tuples
6109executed. Placeholders with fewer values in their parameter arrays
6110are treated as if padded with undef (NULL) values.
6111
6112If a scalar value is bound, instead of an array reference, it is
6113treated as a I<variable> length array with all elements having the
6114same value. It does not influence the number of tuples executed,
6115so if all bound arrays have zero elements then zero tuples will
6116be executed. If I<all> bound values are scalars then one tuple
6117will be executed, making execute_array() act just like execute().
6118
6119The C<ArrayTupleFetch> attribute can be used to specify a reference
6120to a subroutine that will be called to provide the bind values for
6121each tuple execution. The subroutine should return an reference to
6122an array which contains the appropriate number of bind values, or
6123return an undef if there is no more data to execute.
6124
6125As a convenience, the C<ArrayTupleFetch> attribute can also be
6126used to specify a statement handle. In which case the fetchrow_arrayref()
6127method will be called on the given statement handle in order to
6128provide the bind values for each tuple execution.
6129
6130The values specified via bind_param_array() or the @bind_values
6131parameter may be either scalars, or arrayrefs. If any C<@bind_values>
6132are given, then C<execute_array> will effectively call L</bind_param_array>
6133for each value before executing the statement. Values bound in
6134this way are usually treated as C<SQL_VARCHAR> types unless the
6135driver can determine the correct type (which is rare), or unless
6136C<bind_param>, C<bind_param_inout>, C<bind_param_array>, or
6137C<bind_param_inout_array> has already been used to specify the type.
6138See L</bind_param_array> for details.
6139
6140The C<ArrayTupleStatus> attribute can be used to specify a
6141reference to an array which will receive the execute status of each
6142executed parameter tuple. Note the C<ArrayTupleStatus> attribute was
6143mandatory until DBI 1.38.
6144
6145For tuples which are successfully executed, the element at the same
6146ordinal position in the status array is the resulting rowcount.
6147If the execution of a tuple causes an error, then the corresponding
6148status array element will be set to a reference to an array containing
6149the error code and error string set by the failed execution.
6150
6151If B<any> tuple execution returns an error, C<execute_array> will
6152return C<undef>. In that case, the application should inspect the
6153status array to determine which parameter tuples failed.
6154Some databases may not continue executing tuples beyond the first
6155failure. In this case the status array will either hold fewer
6156elements, or the elements beyond the failure will be undef.
6157
6158If all parameter tuples are successfully executed, C<execute_array>
6159returns the number tuples executed. If no tuples were executed,
6160then execute_array() returns "C<0E0>", just like execute() does,
6161which Perl will treat as 0 but will regard as true.
6162
6163For example:
6164
6165 $sth = $dbh->prepare("INSERT INTO staff (first_name, last_name) VALUES (?, ?)");
6166 my $tuples = $sth->execute_array(
6167 { ArrayTupleStatus => \my @tuple_status },
6168 \@first_names,
6169 \@last_names,
6170 );
6171 if ($tuples) {
6172 print "Successfully inserted $tuples records\n";
6173 }
6174 else {
6175 for my $tuple (0..@last_names-1) {
6176 my $status = $tuple_status[$tuple];
6177 $status = [0, "Skipped"] unless defined $status;
6178 next unless ref $status;
6179 printf "Failed to insert (%s, %s): %s\n",
6180 $first_names[$tuple], $last_names[$tuple], $status->[1];
6181 }
6182 }
6183
6184Support for data returning statements such as SELECT is driver-specific
6185and subject to change. At present, the default implementation
6186provided by DBI only supports non-data returning statements.
6187
6188Transaction semantics when using array binding are driver and
6189database specific. If C<AutoCommit> is on, the default DBI
6190implementation will cause each parameter tuple to be individually
6191committed (or rolled back in the event of an error). If C<AutoCommit>
6192is off, the application is responsible for explicitly committing
6193the entire set of bound parameter tuples. Note that different
6194drivers and databases may have different behaviours when some
6195parameter tuples cause failures. In some cases, the driver or
6196database may automatically rollback the effect of all prior parameter
6197tuples that succeeded in the transaction; other drivers or databases
6198may retain the effect of prior successfully executed parameter
6199tuples. Be sure to check your driver and database for its specific
6200behaviour.
6201
6202Note that, in general, performance will usually be better with
6203C<AutoCommit> turned off, and using explicit C<commit> after each
6204C<execute_array> call.
6205
6206The C<execute_array> method was added in DBI 1.22, and ArrayTupleFetch
6207was added in 1.36.
6208
6209=head3 C<execute_for_fetch>
6210
6211 $tuples = $sth->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub);
6212 $tuples = $sth->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub, \@tuple_status);
6213
6214 ($tuples, $rows) = $sth->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub);
6215 ($tuples, $rows) = $sth->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub, \@tuple_status);
6216
6217The execute_for_fetch() method is used to perform bulk operations
6218and is most often used via the execute_array() method, not directly.
6219
6220The fetch subroutine, referenced by $fetch_tuple_sub, is expected
6221to return a reference to an array (known as a 'tuple') or undef.
6222
6223The execute_for_fetch() method calls $fetch_tuple_sub, without any
6224parameters, until it returns a false value. Each tuple returned is
6225used to provide bind values for an $sth->execute(@$tuple) call.
6226
6227In scalar context execute_for_fetch() returns C<undef> if there were any
6228errors and the number of tuples executed otherwise. Like execute() and
6229execute_array() a zero is returned as "0E0" so execute_for_fetch() is
6230only false on error. If there were any errors the @tuple_status array
6231can be used to discover which tuples failed and with what errors.
6232
6233When called in list context execute_for_fetch() returns two scalars;
6234$tuples is the same as calling execute_for_fetch() in scalar context and $rows is
6235the sum of the number of rows affected for each tuple, if available or -1
6236if the driver cannot determine this.
6237If you are doing an update operation the returned rows affected may not be what
6238you expect if, for instance, one or more of the tuples affected the same row
6239multiple times. Some drivers may not yet support list context, in which case
6240$rows will be undef, or may not be able to provide the number of rows affected
6241when performing this batch operation, in which case $rows will be -1.
6242
6243If \@tuple_status is passed then the execute_for_fetch method uses
6244it to return status information. The tuple_status array holds one
6245element per tuple. If the corresponding execute() did not fail then
6246the element holds the return value from execute(), which is typically
6247a row count. If the execute() did fail then the element holds a
6248reference to an array containing ($sth->err, $sth->errstr, $sth->state).
6249
6250If the driver detects an error that it knows means no further tuples can be
6251executed then it may return, with an error status, even though $fetch_tuple_sub
6252may still have more tuples to be executed.
6253
6254Although each tuple returned by $fetch_tuple_sub is effectively used
6255to call $sth->execute(@$tuple_array_ref) the exact timing may vary.
6256Drivers are free to accumulate sets of tuples to pass to the
6257database server in bulk group operations for more efficient execution.
6258However, the $fetch_tuple_sub is specifically allowed to return
6259the same array reference each time (which is what fetchrow_arrayref()
6260usually does).
6261
6262For example:
6263
6264 my $sel = $dbh1->prepare("select foo, bar from table1");
6265 $sel->execute;
6266
6267 my $ins = $dbh2->prepare("insert into table2 (foo, bar) values (?,?)");
6268 my $fetch_tuple_sub = sub { $sel->fetchrow_arrayref };
6269
6270 my @tuple_status;
6271 $rc = $ins->execute_for_fetch($fetch_tuple_sub, \@tuple_status);
6272 my @errors = grep { ref $_ } @tuple_status;
6273
6274Similarly, if you already have an array containing the data rows
6275to be processed you'd use a subroutine to shift off and return
6276each array ref in turn:
6277
6278 $ins->execute_for_fetch( sub { shift @array_of_arrays }, \@tuple_status);
6279
6280The C<execute_for_fetch> method was added in DBI 1.38.
6281
6282
6283=head3 C<fetchrow_arrayref>
6284
6285 $ary_ref = $sth->fetchrow_arrayref;
6286 $ary_ref = $sth->fetch; # alias
6287
6288Fetches the next row of data and returns a reference to an array
6289holding the field values. Null fields are returned as C<undef>
6290values in the array.
6291This is the fastest way to fetch data, particularly if used with
6292C<$sth-E<gt>bind_columns>.
6293
6294If there are no more rows or if an error occurs, then C<fetchrow_arrayref>
6295returns an C<undef>. You should check C<$sth-E<gt>err> afterwards (or use the
6296C<RaiseError> attribute) to discover if the C<undef> returned was due to an
6297error.
6298
6299Note that the same array reference is returned for each fetch, so don't
6300store the reference and then use it after a later fetch. Also, the
6301elements of the array are also reused for each row, so take care if you
6302want to take a reference to an element. See also L</bind_columns>.
6303
6304=head3 C<fetchrow_array>
6305
6306 @ary = $sth->fetchrow_array;
