6307
6308An alternative to C<fetchrow_arrayref>. Fetches the next row of data
6309and returns it as a list containing the field values. Null fields
6310are returned as C<undef> values in the list.
6311
6312If there are no more rows or if an error occurs, then C<fetchrow_array>
6313returns an empty list. You should check C<$sth-E<gt>err> afterwards (or use
6314the C<RaiseError> attribute) to discover if the empty list returned was
6315due to an error.
6316
6317If called in a scalar context for a statement handle that has more
6318than one column, it is undefined whether the driver will return
6319the value of the first column or the last. So don't do that.
6320Also, in a scalar context, an C<undef> is returned if there are no
6321more rows or if an error occurred. That C<undef> can't be distinguished
6322from an C<undef> returned because the first field value was NULL.
6323For these reasons you should exercise some caution if you use
6324C<fetchrow_array> in a scalar context.
6325
6326=head3 C<fetchrow_hashref>
6327
6328 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchrow_hashref;
6329 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchrow_hashref($name);
6330
6331An alternative to C<fetchrow_arrayref>. Fetches the next row of data
6332and returns it as a reference to a hash containing field name and field
6333value pairs. Null fields are returned as C<undef> values in the hash.
6334
6335If there are no more rows or if an error occurs, then C<fetchrow_hashref>
6336returns an C<undef>. You should check C<$sth-E<gt>err> afterwards (or use the
6337C<RaiseError> attribute) to discover if the C<undef> returned was due to an
6338error.
6339
6340The optional C<$name> parameter specifies the name of the statement handle
6341attribute. For historical reasons it defaults to "C<NAME>", however using
6342either "C<NAME_lc>" or "C<NAME_uc>" is recommended for portability.
6343
6344The keys of the hash are the same names returned by C<$sth-E<gt>{$name}>. If
6345more than one field has the same name, there will only be one entry in the
6346returned hash for those fields, so statements like "C<select foo, foo from bar>"
6347will return only a single key from C<fetchrow_hashref>. In these cases use
6348column aliases or C<fetchrow_arrayref>. Note that it is the database server
6349(and not the DBD implementation) which provides the I<name> for fields
6350containing functions like "C<count(*)>" or "C<max(c_foo)>" and they may clash
6351with existing column names (most databases don't care about duplicate column
6352names in a result-set). If you want these to return as unique names that are
6353the same across databases, use I<aliases>, as in "C<select count(*) as cnt>"
6354or "C<select max(c_foo) mx_foo, ...>" depending on the syntax your database
6355supports.
6356
6357Because of the extra work C<fetchrow_hashref> and Perl have to perform, it
6358is not as efficient as C<fetchrow_arrayref> or C<fetchrow_array>.
6359
6360By default a reference to a new hash is returned for each row.
6361It is likely that a future version of the DBI will support an
6362attribute which will enable the same hash to be reused for each
6363row. This will give a significant performance boost, but it won't
6364be enabled by default because of the risk of breaking old code.
6365
6366
6367=head3 C<fetchall_arrayref>
6368
6369 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref;
6370 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref( $slice );
6371 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref( $slice, $max_rows );
6372
6373The C<fetchall_arrayref> method can be used to fetch all the data to be
6374returned from a prepared and executed statement handle. It returns a
6375reference to an array that contains one reference per row.
6376
6377If there are no rows to return, C<fetchall_arrayref> returns a reference
6378to an empty array. If an error occurs, C<fetchall_arrayref> returns the
6379data fetched thus far, which may be none. You should check C<$sth-E<gt>err>
6380afterwards (or use the C<RaiseError> attribute) to discover if the data is
6381complete or was truncated due to an error.
6382
6383If $slice is an array reference, C<fetchall_arrayref> uses L</fetchrow_arrayref>
6384to fetch each row as an array ref. If the $slice array is not empty
6385then it is used as a slice to select individual columns by perl array
6386index number (starting at 0, unlike column and parameter numbers which
6387start at 1).
6388
6389With no parameters, or if $slice is undefined, C<fetchall_arrayref>
6390acts as if passed an empty array ref.
6391
6392If $slice is a hash reference, C<fetchall_arrayref> uses L</fetchrow_hashref>
6393to fetch each row as a hash reference. If the $slice hash is empty then
6394fetchrow_hashref() is simply called in a tight loop and the keys in the hashes
6395have whatever name lettercase is returned by default from fetchrow_hashref.
6396(See L</FetchHashKeyName> attribute.) If the $slice hash is not
6397empty, then it is used as a slice to select individual columns by
6398name. The values of the hash should be set to 1. The key names
6399of the returned hashes match the letter case of the names in the
6400parameter hash, regardless of the L</FetchHashKeyName> attribute.
6401
6402For example, to fetch just the first column of every row:
6403
6404 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref([0]);
6405
6406To fetch the second to last and last column of every row:
6407
6408 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref([-2,-1]);
6409
6410To fetch all fields of every row as a hash ref:
6411
6412 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref({});
6413
6414To fetch only the fields called "foo" and "bar" of every row as a hash ref
6415(with keys named "foo" and "BAR"):
6416
6417 $tbl_ary_ref = $sth->fetchall_arrayref({ foo=>1, BAR=>1 });
6418
6419The first two examples return a reference to an array of array refs.
6420The third and forth return a reference to an array of hash refs.
6421
6422If $max_rows is defined and greater than or equal to zero then it
6423is used to limit the number of rows fetched before returning.
6424fetchall_arrayref() can then be called again to fetch more rows.
6425This is especially useful when you need the better performance of
6426fetchall_arrayref() but don't have enough memory to fetch and return
6427all the rows in one go.
6428
6429Here's an example (assumes RaiseError is enabled):
6430
6431 my $rows = []; # cache for batches of rows
6432 while( my $row = ( shift(@$rows) || # get row from cache, or reload cache:
6433 shift(@{$rows=$sth->fetchall_arrayref(undef,10_000)||[]}) )
6434 ) {
6435 ...
6436 }
6437
6438That I<might> be the fastest way to fetch and process lots of rows using the DBI,
6439but it depends on the relative cost of method calls vs memory allocation.
6440
6441A standard C<while> loop with column binding is often faster because
6442the cost of allocating memory for the batch of rows is greater than
6443the saving by reducing method calls. It's possible that the DBI may
6444provide a way to reuse the memory of a previous batch in future, which
6445would then shift the balance back towards fetchall_arrayref().
6446
6447
6448=head3 C<fetchall_hashref>
6449
6450 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchall_hashref($key_field);
6451
6452The C<fetchall_hashref> method can be used to fetch all the data to be
6453returned from a prepared and executed statement handle. It returns a reference
6454to a hash containing a key for each distinct value of the $key_field column
6455that was fetched. For each key the corresponding value is a reference to a hash
6456containing all the selected columns and their values, as returned by
6457C<fetchrow_hashref()>.
6458
6459If there are no rows to return, C<fetchall_hashref> returns a reference
6460to an empty hash. If an error occurs, C<fetchall_hashref> returns the
6461data fetched thus far, which may be none. You should check
6462C<$sth-E<gt>err> afterwards (or use the C<RaiseError> attribute) to
6463discover if the data is complete or was truncated due to an error.
6464
6465The $key_field parameter provides the name of the field that holds the
6466value to be used for the key for the returned hash. For example:
6467
6468 $dbh->{FetchHashKeyName} = 'NAME_lc';
6469 $sth = $dbh->prepare("SELECT FOO, BAR, ID, NAME, BAZ FROM TABLE");
6470 $sth->execute;
6471 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchall_hashref('id');
6472 print "Name for id 42 is $hash_ref->{42}->{name}\n";
6473
6474The $key_field parameter can also be specified as an integer column
6475number (counting from 1). If $key_field doesn't match any column in
6476the statement, as a name first then as a number, then an error is
6477returned.
6478
6479For queries returning more than one 'key' column, you can specify
6480multiple column names by passing $key_field as a reference to an
6481array containing one or more key column names (or index numbers).
6482For example:
6483
6484 $sth = $dbh->prepare("SELECT foo, bar, baz FROM table");
6485 $sth->execute;
6486 $hash_ref = $sth->fetchall_hashref( [ qw(foo bar) ] );
6487 print "For foo 42 and bar 38, baz is $hash_ref->{42}->{38}->{baz}\n";
6488
6489The fetchall_hashref() method is normally used only where the key
6490fields values for each row are unique. If multiple rows are returned
6491with the same values for the key fields then later rows overwrite
6492earlier ones.
6493
6494=head3 C<finish>
6495
6496 $rc = $sth->finish;
6497
6498Indicate that no more data will be fetched from this statement handle
6499before it is either executed again or destroyed. You almost certainly
6500do I<not> need to call this method.
6501
6502Adding calls to C<finish> after loop that fetches all rows is a common mistake,
6503don't do it, it can mask genuine problems like uncaught fetch errors.
6504
6505When all the data has been fetched from a C<SELECT> statement, the driver will
6506automatically call C<finish> for you. So you should I<not> call it explicitly
6507I<except> when you know that you've not fetched all the data from a statement
6508handle I<and> the handle won't be destroyed soon.
6509
6510The most common example is when you only want to fetch just one row,
6511but in that case the C<selectrow_*> methods are usually better anyway.
6512
6513Consider a query like:
6514
6515 SELECT foo FROM table WHERE bar=? ORDER BY baz
6516
6517on a very large table. When executed, the database server will have to use
6518temporary buffer space to store the sorted rows. If, after executing
6519the handle and selecting just a few rows, the handle won't be re-executed for
6520some time and won't be destroyed, the C<finish> method can be used to tell
6521the server that the buffer space can be freed.
6522
6523Calling C<finish> resets the L</Active> attribute for the statement. It
6524may also make some statement handle attributes (such as C<NAME> and C<TYPE>)
6525unavailable if they have not already been accessed (and thus cached).
6526
6527The C<finish> method does not affect the transaction status of the
6528database connection. It has nothing to do with transactions. It's mostly an
6529internal "housekeeping" method that is rarely needed.
6530See also L</disconnect> and the L</Active> attribute.
6531
6532The C<finish> method should have been called C<discard_pending_rows>.
6533
6534
6535=head3 C<rows>
6536
6537 $rv = $sth->rows;
6538
6539Returns the number of rows affected by the last row affecting command,
6540or -1 if the number of rows is not known or not available.
6541
6542Generally, you can only rely on a row count after a I<non>-C<SELECT>
6543C<execute> (for some specific operations like C<UPDATE> and C<DELETE>), or
6544after fetching all the rows of a C<SELECT> statement.
6545
6546For C<SELECT> statements, it is generally not possible to know how many
6547rows will be returned except by fetching them all. Some drivers will
6548return the number of rows the application has fetched so far, but
6549others may return -1 until all rows have been fetched. So use of the
6550C<rows> method or C<$DBI::rows> with C<SELECT> statements is not
6551recommended.
6552
6553One alternative method to get a row count for a C<SELECT> is to execute a
6554"SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ..." SQL statement with the same "..." as your
6555query and then fetch the row count from that.
6556
6557
6558=head3 C<bind_col>
6559
6560 $rc = $sth->bind_col($column_number, \$var_to_bind);
6561 $rc = $sth->bind_col($column_number, \$var_to_bind, \%attr );
6562 $rc = $sth->bind_col($column_number, \$var_to_bind, $bind_type );
6563
6564Binds a Perl variable and/or some attributes to an output column
6565(field) of a C<SELECT> statement. Column numbers count up from 1.
6566You do not need to bind output columns in order to fetch data.
6567For maximum portability between drivers, bind_col() should be called
6568after execute() and not before.
6569See also C<bind_columns> for an example.
6570
6571The binding is performed at a low level using Perl aliasing.
6572Whenever a row is fetched from the database $var_to_bind appears
6573to be automatically updated simply because it now refers to the same
6574memory location as the corresponding column value. This makes using
6575bound variables very efficient.
6576Binding a tied variable doesn't work, currently.
6577
6578The L</bind_param> method
6579performs a similar, but opposite, function for input variables.
6580
6581B<Data Types for Column Binding>
6582
6583The C<\%attr> parameter can be used to hint at the data type
6584formatting the column should have. For example, you can use:
6585
6586 $sth->bind_col(1, undef, { TYPE => SQL_DATETIME });
6587
6588to specify that you'd like the column (which presumably is some
6589kind of datetime type) to be returned in the standard format for
6590SQL_DATETIME, which is 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS', rather than the
6591native formatting the database would normally use.
6592
6593There's no $var_to_bind in that example to emphasize the point
6594that bind_col() works on the underlying column and not just
6595a particular bound variable.
6596
6597As a short-cut for the common case, the data type can be passed
6598directly, in place of the C<\%attr> hash reference. This example is
6599equivalent to the one above:
6600
6601 $sth->bind_col(1, undef, SQL_DATETIME);
6602
6603The C<TYPE> value indicates the standard (non-driver-specific) type for
6604this parameter. To specify the driver-specific type, the driver may
6605support a driver-specific attribute, such as C<{ ora_type =E<gt> 97 }>.
6606
6607The SQL_DATETIME and other related constants can be imported using
6608
6609 use DBI qw(:sql_types);
6610
6611See L</"DBI Constants"> for more information.
6612
6613Few drivers support specifying a data type via a C<bind_col> call
6614(most will simply ignore the data type). Fewer still allow the data
6615type to be altered once set.
6616
6617The TYPE attribute for bind_col() was first specified in DBI 1.41.
6618
6619From DBI 1.611, drivers can use the C<TYPE> attribute to attempt to
6620cast the bound scalar to a perl type which more closely matches
6621C<TYPE>. At present DBI supports C<SQL_INTEGER>, C<SQL_DOUBLE> and
6622C<SQL_NUMERIC>. See L</sql_type_cast> for details of how types are
6623cast.
6624
6625B<Other attributes for Column Binding>
6626
6627The C<\%attr> parameter may also contain the following attributes:
6628
6629=over
6630
6631=item C<StrictlyTyped>
6632
6633If a C<TYPE> attribute is passed to bind_col, then the driver will
6634attempt to change the bound perl scalar to match the type more
6635closely. If the bound value cannot be cast to the requested C<TYPE>
6636then by default it is left untouched and no error is generated. If you
6637specify C<StrictlyTyped> as 1 and the cast fails, this will generate
6638an error.
6639
6640This attribute was first added in DBI 1.611. When 1.611 was released
6641few drivers actually supported this attribute but DBD::Oracle and
6642DBD::ODBC should from versions 1.24.
6643
6644=item C<DiscardString>
6645
6646When the C<TYPE> attribute is passed to L</bind_col> and the driver
6647successfully casts the bound perl scalar to a non-string type
6648then if C<DiscardString> is set to 1, the string portion of the
6649scalar will be discarded. By default, C<DiscardString> is not set.
6650
6651This attribute was first added in DBI 1.611. When 1.611 was released
6652few drivers actually supported this attribute but DBD::Oracle and
6653DBD::ODBC should from versions 1.24.
6654
6655=back
6656
6657
6658=head3 C<bind_columns>
6659
6660 $rc = $sth->bind_columns(@list_of_refs_to_vars_to_bind);
6661
6662Calls L</bind_col> for each column of the C<SELECT> statement.
6663
6664The list of references should have the same number of elements as the number of
6665columns in the C<SELECT> statement. If it doesn't then C<bind_columns> will
6666bind the elements given, up to the number of columns, and then return an error.
6667
6668For maximum portability between drivers, bind_columns() should be called
6669after execute() and not before.
6670
6671For example:
6672
6673 $dbh->{RaiseError} = 1; # do this, or check every call for errors
6674 $sth = $dbh->prepare(q{ SELECT region, sales FROM sales_by_region });
6675 $sth->execute;
6676 my ($region, $sales);
6677
6678 # Bind Perl variables to columns:
6679 $rv = $sth->bind_columns(\$region, \$sales);
6680
6681 # you can also use Perl's \(...) syntax (see perlref docs):
6682 # $sth->bind_columns(\($region, $sales));
6683
6684 # Column binding is the most efficient way to fetch data
6685 while ($sth->fetch) {
6686 print "$region: $sales\n";
6687 }
6688
6689For compatibility with old scripts, the first parameter will be
6690ignored if it is C<undef> or a hash reference.
6691
6692Here's a more fancy example that binds columns to the values I<inside>
6693a hash (thanks to H.Merijn Brand):
6694
6695 $sth->execute;
6696 my %row;
6697 $sth->bind_columns( \( @row{ @{$sth->{NAME_lc} } } ));
6698 while ($sth->fetch) {
6699 print "$row{region}: $row{sales}\n";
6700 }
6701
6702
6703=head3 C<dump_results>
6704
6705 $rows = $sth->dump_results($maxlen, $lsep, $fsep, $fh);
6706
6707Fetches all the rows from C<$sth>, calls C<DBI::neat_list> for each row, and
6708prints the results to C<$fh> (defaults to C<STDOUT>) separated by C<$lsep>
6709(default C<"\n">). C<$fsep> defaults to C<", "> and C<$maxlen> defaults to 35.
6710
6711This method is designed as a handy utility for prototyping and
6712testing queries. Since it uses L</neat_list> to
6713format and edit the string for reading by humans, it is not recommended
6714for data transfer applications.
6715
6716
6717=head2 Statement Handle Attributes
6718
6719This section describes attributes specific to statement handles. Most
6720of these attributes are read-only.
6721
6722Changes to these statement handle attributes do not affect any other
6723existing or future statement handles.
6724
6725Attempting to set or get the value of an unknown attribute generates a warning,
6726except for private driver specific attributes (which all have names
6727starting with a lowercase letter).
6728
6729Example:
6730
6731 ... = $h->{NUM_OF_FIELDS}; # get/read
6732
6733Some drivers cannot provide valid values for some or all of these
6734attributes until after C<$sth-E<gt>execute> has been successfully
6735called. Typically the attribute will be C<undef> in these situations.
6736
6737Some attributes, like NAME, are not appropriate to some types of
6738statement, like SELECT. Typically the attribute will be C<undef>
6739in these situations.
6740
6741For drivers which support stored procedures and multiple result sets
6742(see more_results) these attributes relate to the I<current> result set.
6743
6744See also L</finish> to learn more about the effect it
6745may have on some attributes.
6746
6747=head3 C<NUM_OF_FIELDS>
6748
6749Type: integer, read-only
6750
6751Number of fields (columns) in the data the prepared statement may return.
6752Statements that don't return rows of data, like C<DELETE> and C<CREATE>
6753set C<NUM_OF_FIELDS> to 0 (though it may be undef in some drivers).
6754
6755
6756=head3 C<NUM_OF_PARAMS>
6757
6758Type: integer, read-only
6759
6760The number of parameters (placeholders) in the prepared statement.
6761See SUBSTITUTION VARIABLES below for more details.
6762
6763
6764=head3 C<NAME>
6765
6766Type: array-ref, read-only
6767
6768Returns a reference to an array of field names for each column. The
6769names may contain spaces but should not be truncated or have any
6770trailing space. Note that the names have the letter case (upper, lower
6771or mixed) as returned by the driver being used. Portable applications
6772should use L</NAME_lc> or L</NAME_uc>.
6773
6774 print "First column name: $sth->{NAME}->[0]\n";
6775
6776Also note that the name returned for (aggregate) functions like C<count(*)>
6777or C<max(c_foo)> is determined by the database server and not by C<DBI> or
6778the C<DBD> backend.
6779
6780=head3 C<NAME_lc>
6781
6782Type: array-ref, read-only
6783
6784Like L</NAME> but always returns lowercase names.
6785
6786=head3 C<NAME_uc>
6787
6788Type: array-ref, read-only
6789
6790Like L</NAME> but always returns uppercase names.
6791
6792=head3 C<NAME_hash>
6793
6794Type: hash-ref, read-only
6795
6796=head3 C<NAME_lc_hash>
6797
6798Type: hash-ref, read-only
6799
6800=head3 C<NAME_uc_hash>
6801
6802Type: hash-ref, read-only
6803
6804The C<NAME_hash>, C<NAME_lc_hash>, and C<NAME_uc_hash> attributes
6805return column name information as a reference to a hash.
6806
6807The keys of the hash are the names of the columns. The letter case of
6808the keys corresponds to the letter case returned by the C<NAME>,
6809C<NAME_lc>, and C<NAME_uc> attributes respectively (as described above).
6810
6811The value of each hash entry is the perl index number of the
6812corresponding column (counting from 0). For example:
6813
6814 $sth = $dbh->prepare("select Id, Name from table");
6815 $sth->execute;
6816 @row = $sth->fetchrow_array;
6817 print "Name $row[ $sth->{NAME_lc_hash}{name} ]\n";
6818
6819
6820=head3 C<TYPE>
6821
6822Type: array-ref, read-only
6823
6824Returns a reference to an array of integer values for each
6825column. The value indicates the data type of the corresponding column.
6826
6827The values correspond to the international standards (ANSI X3.135
6828and ISO/IEC 9075) which, in general terms, means ODBC. Driver-specific
6829types that don't exactly match standard types should generally return
6830the same values as an ODBC driver supplied by the makers of the
6831database. That might include private type numbers in ranges the vendor
6832has officially registered with the ISO working group:
6833
6834 ftp://sqlstandards.org/SC32/SQL_Registry/
6835
6836Where there's no vendor-supplied ODBC driver to be compatible with,
6837the DBI driver can use type numbers in the range that is now
6838officially reserved for use by the DBI: -9999 to -9000.
6839
6840All possible values for C<TYPE> should have at least one entry in the
6841output of the C<type_info_all> method (see L</type_info_all>).
6842
6843=head3 C<PRECISION>
6844
6845Type: array-ref, read-only
6846
6847Returns a reference to an array of integer values for each column.
6848
6849For numeric columns, the value is the maximum number of digits
6850(without considering a sign character or decimal point). Note that
6851the "display size" for floating point types (REAL, FLOAT, DOUBLE)
6852can be up to 7 characters greater than the precision (for the
6853sign + decimal point + the letter E + a sign + 2 or 3 digits).
6854
6855For any character type column the value is the OCTET_LENGTH,
6856in other words the number of bytes, not characters.
6857
6858(More recent standards refer to this as COLUMN_SIZE but we stick
6859with PRECISION for backwards compatibility.)
6860
6861=head3 C<SCALE>
6862
6863Type: array-ref, read-only
6864
6865Returns a reference to an array of integer values for each column.
6866NULL (C<undef>) values indicate columns where scale is not applicable.
6867
6868=head3 C<NULLABLE>
6869
6870Type: array-ref, read-only
6871
6872Returns a reference to an array indicating the possibility of each
6873column returning a null. Possible values are C<0>
6874(or an empty string) = no, C<1> = yes, C<2> = unknown.
6875
6876 print "First column may return NULL\n" if $sth->{NULLABLE}->[0];
6877
6878
6879=head3 C<CursorName>
6880
6881Type: string, read-only
6882
6883Returns the name of the cursor associated with the statement handle, if
6884available. If not available or if the database driver does not support the
6885C<"where current of ..."> SQL syntax, then it returns C<undef>.
6886
6887
6888=head3 C<Database>
6889
6890Type: dbh, read-only
6891
6892Returns the parent $dbh of the statement handle.
6893
6894
6895=head3 C<Statement>
6896
6897Type: string, read-only
6898
6899Returns the statement string passed to the L</prepare> method.
6900
6901
6902=head3 C<ParamValues>
6903
6904Type: hash ref, read-only
6905
6906Returns a reference to a hash containing the values currently bound
6907to placeholders. The keys of the hash are the 'names' of the
6908placeholders, typically integers starting at 1. Returns undef if
6909not supported by the driver.
6910
6911See L</ShowErrorStatement> for an example of how this is used.
6912
6913* Keys:
6914
6915If the driver supports C<ParamValues> but no values have been bound
6916yet then the driver should return a hash with placeholders names
6917in the keys but all the values undef, but some drivers may return
6918a ref to an empty hash because they can't pre-determine the names.
6919
6920It is possible that the keys in the hash returned by C<ParamValues>
6921are not exactly the same as those implied by the prepared statement.
6922For example, DBD::Oracle translates 'C<?>' placeholders into 'C<:pN>'
6923where N is a sequence number starting at 1.
6924
6925* Values:
6926
6927It is possible that the values in the hash returned by C<ParamValues>
6928are not I<exactly> the same as those passed to bind_param() or execute().
6929The driver may have slightly modified values in some way based on the
6930TYPE the value was bound with. For example a floating point value
6931bound as an SQL_INTEGER type may be returned as an integer.
6932The values returned by C<ParamValues> can be passed to another
6933bind_param() method with the same TYPE and will be seen by the
6934database as the same value. See also L</ParamTypes> below.
6935
6936The C<ParamValues> attribute was added in DBI 1.28.
6937
6938=head3 C<ParamTypes>
6939
6940Type: hash ref, read-only
6941
6942Returns a reference to a hash containing the type information
6943currently bound to placeholders.
6944Returns undef if not supported by the driver.
6945
6946* Keys:
6947
6948See L</ParamValues> above.
6949
6950* Values:
6951
6952The hash values are hashrefs of type information in the same form as that
6953passed to the various bind_param() methods (See L</bind_param> for the format
6954and values).
6955
6956It is possible that the values in the hash returned by C<ParamTypes>
6957are not exactly the same as those passed to bind_param() or execute().
6958Param attributes specified using the abbreviated form, like this:
6959
6960 $sth->bind_param(1, SQL_INTEGER);
6961
6962are returned in the expanded form, as if called like this:
6963
6964 $sth->bind_param(1, { TYPE => SQL_INTEGER });
6965
6966The driver may have modified the type information in some way based
6967on the bound values, other hints provided by the prepare()'d
6968SQL statement, or alternate type mappings required by the driver or target
6969database system. The driver may also add private keys (with names beginning
6970with the drivers reserved prefix, e.g., odbc_xxx).
6971
6972* Example:
6973
6974The keys and values in the returned hash can be passed to the various
6975bind_param() methods to effectively reproduce a previous param binding.
6976For example:
6977
6978 # assuming $sth1 is a previously prepared statement handle
6979 my $sth2 = $dbh->prepare( $sth1->{Statement} );
6980 my $ParamValues = $sth1->{ParamValues} || {};
6981 my $ParamTypes = $sth1->{ParamTypes} || {};
6982 $sth2->bind_param($_, $PV->{$_} $PT->{$_})
6983 for keys %{ %$PV, %$PT };
6984 $sth2->execute();
6985
6986The C<ParamTypes> attribute was added in DBI 1.49. Implementation
6987is the responsibility of individual drivers; the DBI layer default
6988implementation simply returns undef.
6989
6990
6991=head3 C<ParamArrays>
6992
6993Type: hash ref, read-only
6994
6995Returns a reference to a hash containing the values currently bound to
6996placeholders with L</execute_array> or L</bind_param_array>. The
6997keys of the hash are the 'names' of the placeholders, typically
6998integers starting at 1. Returns undef if not supported by the driver
6999or no arrays of parameters are bound.
7000
7001Each key value is an array reference containing a list of the bound
7002parameters for that column.
7003
7004For example:
7005
7006 $sth = $dbh->prepare("INSERT INTO staff (id, name) values (?,?)");
7007 $sth->execute_array({},[1,2], ['fred','dave']);
7008 if ($sth->{ParamArrays}) {
7009 foreach $param (keys %{$sth->{ParamArrays}}) {
7010 printf "Parameters for %s : %s\n", $param,
7011 join(",", @{$sth->{ParamArrays}->{$param}});
7012 }
7013 }
7014
7015It is possible that the values in the hash returned by C<ParamArrays>
7016are not I<exactly> the same as those passed to L</bind_param_array> or
7017L</execute_array>. The driver may have slightly modified values in some
7018way based on the TYPE the value was bound with. For example a floating
7019point value bound as an SQL_INTEGER type may be returned as an
7020integer.
7021
7022It is also possible that the keys in the hash returned by
7023C<ParamArrays> are not exactly the same as those implied by the
7024prepared statement. For example, DBD::Oracle translates 'C<?>'
7025placeholders into 'C<:pN>' where N is a sequence number starting at 1.
7026
7027=head3 C<RowsInCache>
7028
7029Type: integer, read-only
7030
7031If the driver supports a local row cache for C<SELECT> statements, then
7032this attribute holds the number of un-fetched rows in the cache. If the
7033driver doesn't, then it returns C<undef>. Note that some drivers pre-fetch
7034rows on execute, whereas others wait till the first fetch.
7035
7036See also the L</RowCacheSize> database handle attribute.
7037
7038=head1 FURTHER INFORMATION
7039
7040=head2 Catalog Methods
7041
7042An application can retrieve metadata information from the DBMS by issuing
7043appropriate queries on the views of the Information Schema. Unfortunately,
7044C<INFORMATION_SCHEMA> views are seldom supported by the DBMS.
7045Special methods (catalog methods) are available to return result sets
7046for a small but important portion of that metadata:
7047
7048 column_info
7049 foreign_key_info
7050 primary_key_info
7051 table_info
7052 statistics_info
7053
7054All catalog methods accept arguments in order to restrict the result sets.
7055Passing C<undef> to an optional argument does not constrain the search for
7056that argument.
7057However, an empty string ('') is treated as a regular search criteria
7058and will only match an empty value.
7059
7060B<Note>: SQL/CLI and ODBC differ in the handling of empty strings. An
7061empty string will not restrict the result set in SQL/CLI.
7062
7063Most arguments in the catalog methods accept only I<ordinary values>, e.g.
7064the arguments of C<primary_key_info()>.
7065Such arguments are treated as a literal string, i.e. the case is significant
7066and quote characters are taken literally.
7067
7068Some arguments in the catalog methods accept I<search patterns> (strings
7069containing '_' and/or '%'), e.g. the C<$table> argument of C<column_info()>.
7070Passing '%' is equivalent to leaving the argument C<undef>.
7071
7072B<Caveat>: The underscore ('_') is valid and often used in SQL identifiers.
7073Passing such a value to a search pattern argument may return more rows than
7074expected!
7075To include pattern characters as literals, they must be preceded by an
7076escape character which can be achieved with
7077
7078 $esc = $dbh->get_info( 14 ); # SQL_SEARCH_PATTERN_ESCAPE
7079 $search_pattern =~ s/([_%])/$esc$1/g;
7080
7081The ODBC and SQL/CLI specifications define a way to change the default
7082behaviour described above: All arguments (except I<list value arguments>)
7083are treated as I<identifier> if the C<SQL_ATTR_METADATA_ID> attribute is
7084set to C<SQL_TRUE>.
7085I<Quoted identifiers> are very similar to I<ordinary values>, i.e. their
7086body (the string within the quotes) is interpreted literally.
7087I<Unquoted identifiers> are compared in UPPERCASE.
7088
7089The DBI (currently) does not support the C<SQL_ATTR_METADATA_ID> attribute,
7090i.e. it behaves like an ODBC driver where C<SQL_ATTR_METADATA_ID> is set to
7091C<SQL_FALSE>.
7092
7093
7094=head2 Transactions
7095
7096Transactions are a fundamental part of any robust database system. They
7097protect against errors and database corruption by ensuring that sets of
7098related changes to the database take place in atomic (indivisible,
7099all-or-nothing) units.
7100
7101This section applies to databases that support transactions and where
7102C<AutoCommit> is off. See L</AutoCommit> for details of using C<AutoCommit>
7103with various types of databases.
7104
7105The recommended way to implement robust transactions in Perl
7106applications is to use C<RaiseError> and S<C<eval { ... }>>
7107(which is very fast, unlike S<C<eval "...">>). For example:
7108
7109 $dbh->{AutoCommit} = 0; # enable transactions, if possible
7110 $dbh->{RaiseError} = 1;
7111 eval {
7112 foo(...) # do lots of work here
7113 bar(...) # including inserts
7114 baz(...) # and updates
7115 $dbh->commit; # commit the changes if we get this far
7116 };
7117 if ($@) {
7118 warn "Transaction aborted because $@";
7119 # now rollback to undo the incomplete changes
7120 # but do it in an eval{} as it may also fail
7121 eval { $dbh->rollback };
7122 # add other application on-error-clean-up code here
7123 }
7124
7125If the C<RaiseError> attribute is not set, then DBI calls would need to be
7126manually checked for errors, typically like this:
7127
7128 $h->method(@args) or die $h->errstr;
7129
7130With C<RaiseError> set, the DBI will automatically C<die> if any DBI method
7131call on that handle (or a child handle) fails, so you don't have to
7132test the return value of each method call. See L</RaiseError> for more
7133details.
7134
7135A major advantage of the C<eval> approach is that the transaction will be
7136properly rolled back if I<any> code (not just DBI calls) in the inner
7137application dies for any reason. The major advantage of using the
7138C<$h-E<gt>{RaiseError}> attribute is that all DBI calls will be checked
7139automatically. Both techniques are strongly recommended.
7140
7141After calling C<commit> or C<rollback> many drivers will not let you
7142fetch from a previously active C<SELECT> statement handle that's a child
7143of the same database handle. A typical way round this is to connect the
7144the database twice and use one connection for C<SELECT> statements.
7145
7146See L</AutoCommit> and L</disconnect> for other important information
7147about transactions.
7148
7149
7150=head2 Handling BLOB / LONG / Memo Fields
7151
7152Many databases support "blob" (binary large objects), "long", or similar
7153datatypes for holding very long strings or large amounts of binary
7154data in a single field. Some databases support variable length long
7155values over 2,000,000,000 bytes in length.
7156
7157Since values of that size can't usually be held in memory, and because
7158databases can't usually know in advance the length of the longest long
7159that will be returned from a C<SELECT> statement (unlike other data
7160types), some special handling is required.
7161
7162In this situation, the value of the C<$h-E<gt>{LongReadLen}>
7163attribute is used to determine how much buffer space to allocate
7164when fetching such fields. The C<$h-E<gt>{LongTruncOk}> attribute
7165is used to determine how to behave if a fetched value can't fit
7166into the buffer.
7167
7168See the description of L</LongReadLen> for more information.
7169
7170When trying to insert long or binary values, placeholders should be used
7171since there are often limits on the maximum size of an C<INSERT>
7172statement and the L</quote> method generally can't cope with binary
7173data. See L</Placeholders and Bind Values>.
7174
7175
7176=head2 Simple Examples
7177
7178Here's a complete example program to select and fetch some data:
7179
7180 my $data_source = "dbi::DriverName:db_name";
7181 my $dbh = DBI->connect($data_source, $user, $password)
7182 or die "Can't connect to $data_source: $DBI::errstr";
7183
7184 my $sth = $dbh->prepare( q{
7185 SELECT name, phone
7186 FROM mytelbook
7187 }) or die "Can't prepare statement: $DBI::errstr";
7188
7189 my $rc = $sth->execute
7190 or die "Can't execute statement: $DBI::errstr";
7191
7192 print "Query will return $sth->{NUM_OF_FIELDS} fields.\n\n";
7193 print "Field names: @{ $sth->{NAME} }\n";
7194
7195 while (($name, $phone) = $sth->fetchrow_array) {
7196 print "$name: $phone\n";
7197 }
7198 # check for problems which may have terminated the fetch early
7199 die $sth->errstr if $sth->err;
7200
7201 $dbh->disconnect;
7202
7203Here's a complete example program to insert some data from a file.
7204(This example uses C<RaiseError> to avoid needing to check each call).
7205
7206 my $dbh = DBI->connect("dbi:DriverName:db_name", $user, $password, {
7207 RaiseError => 1, AutoCommit => 0
7208 });
7209
7210 my $sth = $dbh->prepare( q{
7211 INSERT INTO table (name, phone) VALUES (?, ?)
7212 });
7213
7214 open FH, "<phone.csv" or die "Unable to open phone.csv: $!";
7215 while (<FH>) {
7216 chomp;
7217 my ($name, $phone) = split /,/;
7218 $sth->execute($name, $phone);
7219 }
7220 close FH;
7221
7222 $dbh->commit;
7223 $dbh->disconnect;
7224
7225Here's how to convert fetched NULLs (undefined values) into empty strings:
7226
7227 while($row = $sth->fetchrow_arrayref) {
7228 # this is a fast and simple way to deal with nulls:
7229 foreach (@$row) { $_ = '' unless defined }
7230 print "@$row\n";
7231 }
7232
7233The C<q{...}> style quoting used in these examples avoids clashing with
7234quotes that may be used in the SQL statement. Use the double-quote like
7235C<qq{...}> operator if you want to interpolate variables into the string.
7236See L<perlop/"Quote and Quote-like Operators"> for more details.
7237
7238=head2 Threads and Thread Safety
7239
7240Perl 5.7 and later support a new threading model called iThreads.
7241(The old "5.005 style" threads are not supported by the DBI.)
7242
7243In the iThreads model each thread has it's own copy of the perl
7244interpreter. When a new thread is created the original perl
7245interpreter is 'cloned' to create a new copy for the new thread.
7246
7247If the DBI and drivers are loaded and handles created before the
7248thread is created then it will get a cloned copy of the DBI, the
7249drivers and the handles.
7250
7251However, the internal pointer data within the handles will refer
7252to the DBI and drivers in the original interpreter. Using those
7253handles in the new interpreter thread is not safe, so the DBI detects
7254this and croaks on any method call using handles that don't belong
7255to the current thread (except for DESTROY).
7256
7257Because of this (possibly temporary) restriction, newly created
7258threads must make their own connections to the database. Handles
7259can't be shared across threads.
7260
7261But BEWARE, some underlying database APIs (the code the DBD driver
7262uses to talk to the database, often supplied by the database vendor)
7263are not thread safe. If it's not thread safe, then allowing more
7264than one thread to enter the code at the same time may cause
7265subtle/serious problems. In some cases allowing more than
7266one thread to enter the code, even if I<not> at the same time,
7267can cause problems. You have been warned.
7268
7269Using DBI with perl threads is not yet recommended for production
7270environments. For more information see
7271L<http://www.perlmonks.org/index.pl?node_id=288022>
7272
7273Note: There is a bug in perl 5.8.2 when configured with threads
7274and debugging enabled (bug #24463) which causes a DBI test to fail.
7275
7276=head2 Signal Handling and Canceling Operations
7277
7278[The following only applies to systems with unix-like signal handling.
7279I'd welcome additions for other systems, especially Windows.]
7280
7281The first thing to say is that signal handling in Perl versions less
7282than 5.8 is I<not> safe. There is always a small risk of Perl
7283crashing and/or core dumping when, or after, handling a signal
7284because the signal could arrive and be handled while internal data
7285structures are being changed. If the signal handling code
7286used those same internal data structures it could cause all manner
7287of subtle and not-so-subtle problems. The risk was reduced with
72885.4.4 but was still present in all perls up through 5.8.0.
7289
7290Beginning in perl 5.8.0 perl implements 'safe' signal handling if
7291your system has the POSIX sigaction() routine. Now when a signal
7292is delivered perl just makes a note of it but does I<not> run the
7293%SIG handler. The handling is 'deferred' until a 'safe' moment.
7294
7295Although this change made signal handling safe, it also lead to
7296a problem with signals being deferred for longer than you'd like.
7297If a signal arrived while executing a system call, such as waiting
7298for data on a network connection, the signal is noted and then the
7299system call that was executing returns with an EINTR error code
7300to indicate that it was interrupted. All fine so far.
7301
7302The problem comes when the code that made the system call sees the
7303EINTR code and decides it's going to call it again. Perl doesn't
7304do that, but database code sometimes does. If that happens then the
7305signal handler doesn't get called until later. Maybe much later.
7306
7307Fortunately there are ways around this which we'll discuss below.
7308Unfortunately they make signals unsafe again.
7309
7310The two most common uses of signals in relation to the DBI are for
7311canceling operations when the user types Ctrl-C (interrupt), and for
7312implementing a timeout using C<alarm()> and C<$SIG{ALRM}>.
7313
7314=over 4
7315
7316=item Cancel
7317
7318The DBI provides a C<cancel> method for statement handles. The
7319C<cancel> method should abort the current operation and is designed
7320to be called from a signal handler. For example:
7321
7322 $SIG{INT} = sub { $sth->cancel };
7323
7324However, few drivers implement this (the DBI provides a default
7325method that just returns C<undef>) and, even if implemented, there
7326is still a possibility that the statement handle, and even the
7327parent database handle, will not be usable afterwards.
7328
7329If C<cancel> returns true, then it has successfully
7330invoked the database engine's own cancel function. If it returns false,
7331then C<cancel> failed. If it returns C<undef>, then the database
7332driver does not have cancel implemented - very few do.
7333
7334=item Timeout
7335
7336The traditional way to implement a timeout is to set C<$SIG{ALRM}>
7337to refer to some code that will be executed when an ALRM signal
7338arrives and then to call alarm($seconds) to schedule an ALRM signal
7339to be delivered $seconds in the future. For example:
7340
7341 eval {
7342 local $SIG{ALRM} = sub { die "TIMEOUT\n" }; # N.B. \n required
7343 eval {
7344 alarm($seconds);
7345 ... code to execute with timeout here (which may die) ...
7346 };
7347 # outer eval catches alarm that might fire JUST before this alarm(0)
7348 alarm(0); # cancel alarm (if code ran fast)
7349 die "$@" if $@;
7350 };
7351 if ( $@ eq "TIMEOUT\n" ) { ... }
7352 elsif ($@) { ... } # some other error
7353
7354The first (outer) eval is used to avoid the unlikely but possible
7355chance that the "code to execute" dies and the alarm fires before it
7356is cancelled. Without the outer eval, if this happened your program
7357will die if you have no ALRM handler or a non-local alarm handler
7358will be called.
7359
7360Unfortunately, as described above, this won't always work as expected,
7361depending on your perl version and the underlying database code.
7362
7363With Oracle for instance (DBD::Oracle), if the system which hosts
7364the database is down the DBI->connect() call will hang for several
7365minutes before returning an error.
7366
7367=back
7368
7369The solution on these systems is to use the C<POSIX::sigaction()>
7370routine to gain low level access to how the signal handler is installed.
7371
7372The code would look something like this (for the DBD-Oracle connect()):
7373
7374 use POSIX qw(:signal_h);
7375
7376 my $mask = POSIX::SigSet->new( SIGALRM ); # signals to mask in the handler
7377 my $action = POSIX::SigAction->new(
7378 sub { die "connect timeout\n" }, # the handler code ref
7379 $mask,
7380 # not using (perl 5.8.2 and later) 'safe' switch or sa_flags
7381 );
7382 my $oldaction = POSIX::SigAction->new();
7383 sigaction( SIGALRM, $action, $oldaction );
7384 my $dbh;
7385 eval {
7386 eval {
7387 alarm(5); # seconds before time out
7388 $dbh = DBI->connect("dbi:Oracle:$dsn" ... );
7389 };
7390 alarm(0); # cancel alarm (if connect worked fast)
7391 die "$@\n" if $@; # connect died
7392 };
7393 sigaction( SIGALRM, $oldaction ); # restore original signal handler
7394 if ( $@ ) {
7395 if ($@ eq "connect timeout\n") {...}
7396 else { # connect died }
7397 }
7398
7399See previous example for the reasoning around the double eval.
7400
7401Similar techniques can be used for canceling statement execution.
7402
7403Unfortunately, this solution is somewhat messy, and it does I<not> work with
7404perl versions less than perl 5.8 where C<POSIX::sigaction()> appears to be broken.
7405
7406For a cleaner implementation that works across perl versions, see Lincoln Baxter's
7407Sys::SigAction module at L<http://search.cpan.org/~lbaxter/Sys-SigAction/>.
7408The documentation for Sys::SigAction includes an longer discussion
7409of this problem, and a DBD::Oracle test script.
7410
7411Be sure to read all the signal handling sections of the L<perlipc> manual.
7412
7413And finally, two more points to keep firmly in mind. Firstly,
7414remember that what we've done here is essentially revert to old
7415style I<unsafe> handling of these signals. So do as little as
7416possible in the handler. Ideally just die(). Secondly, the handles
7417in use at the time the signal is handled may not be safe to use
7418afterwards.
7419
7420
7421=head2 Subclassing the DBI
7422
7423DBI can be subclassed and extended just like any other object
7424oriented module. Before we talk about how to do that, it's important
7425to be clear about the various DBI classes and how they work together.
7426
7427By default C<$dbh = DBI-E<gt>connect(...)> returns a $dbh blessed
7428into the C<DBI::db> class. And the C<$dbh-E<gt>prepare> method
7429returns an $sth blessed into the C<DBI::st> class (actually it
7430simply changes the last four characters of the calling handle class
7431to be C<::st>).
7432
7433The leading 'C<DBI>' is known as the 'root class' and the extra
7434'C<::db>' or 'C<::st>' are the 'handle type suffixes'. If you want
7435to subclass the DBI you'll need to put your overriding methods into
7436the appropriate classes. For example, if you want to use a root class
7437of C<MySubDBI> and override the do(), prepare() and execute() methods,
7438then your do() and prepare() methods should be in the C<MySubDBI::db>
7439class and the execute() method should be in the C<MySubDBI::st> class.
7440
7441To setup the inheritance hierarchy the @ISA variable in C<MySubDBI::db>
7442should include C<DBI::db> and the @ISA variable in C<MySubDBI::st>
7443should include C<DBI::st>. The C<MySubDBI> root class itself isn't
7444currently used for anything visible and so, apart from setting @ISA
7445to include C<DBI>, it can be left empty.
7446
7447So, having put your overriding methods into the right classes, and
7448setup the inheritance hierarchy, how do you get the DBI to use them?
7449You have two choices, either a static method call using the name
7450of your subclass:
7451
7452 $dbh = MySubDBI->connect(...);
7453
7454or specifying a C<RootClass> attribute:
7455
7456 $dbh = DBI->connect(..., { RootClass => 'MySubDBI' });
7457
7458If both forms are used then the attribute takes precedence.
7459
7460The only differences between the two are that using an explicit
7461RootClass attribute will a) make the DBI automatically attempt to load
7462a module by that name if the class doesn't exist, and b) won't call
7463your MySubDBI::connect() method, if you have one.
7464
7465When subclassing is being used then, after a successful new
7466connect, the DBI->connect method automatically calls:
7467
7468 $dbh->connected($dsn, $user, $pass, \%attr);
7469
7470The default method does nothing. The call is made just to simplify
7471any post-connection setup that your subclass may want to perform.
7472The parameters are the same as passed to DBI->connect.
7473If your subclass supplies a connected method, it should be part of the
7474MySubDBI::db package.
7475
7476One more thing to note: you must let the DBI do the handle creation. If you
7477want to override the connect() method in your *::dr class then it must still
7478call SUPER::connect to get a $dbh to work with. Similarly, an overridden
7479prepare() method in *::db must still call SUPER::prepare to get a $sth.
7480If you try to create your own handles using bless() then you'll find the DBI
7481will reject them with an "is not a DBI handle (has no magic)" error.
7482
7483Here's a brief example of a DBI subclass. A more thorough example
7484can be found in F<t/subclass.t> in the DBI distribution.
7485
7486 package MySubDBI;
7487
7488 use strict;
7489
7490 use DBI;
7491 use vars qw(@ISA);
7492 @ISA = qw(DBI);
7493
7494 package MySubDBI::db;
7495 use vars qw(@ISA);
7496 @ISA = qw(DBI::db);
7497
7498 sub prepare {
7499 my ($dbh, @args) = @_;
7500 my $sth = $dbh->SUPER::prepare(@args)
7501 or return;
7502 $sth->{private_mysubdbi_info} = { foo => 'bar' };
7503 return $sth;
7504 }
7505
7506 package MySubDBI::st;
7507 use vars qw(@ISA);
7508 @ISA = qw(DBI::st);
7509
7510 sub fetch {
7511 my ($sth, @args) = @_;
7512 my $row = $sth->SUPER::fetch(@args)
7513 or return;
7514 do_something_magical_with_row_data($row)
7515 or return $sth->set_err(1234, "The magic failed", undef, "fetch");
7516 return $row;
7517 }
7518
7519When calling a SUPER::method that returns a handle, be careful to
7520check the return value before trying to do other things with it in
7521your overridden method. This is especially important if you want to
7522set a hash attribute on the handle, as Perl's autovivification will
7523bite you by (in)conveniently creating an unblessed hashref, which your
7524method will then return with usually baffling results later on like
7525the error "dbih_getcom handle HASH(0xa4451a8) is not a DBI handle (has
7526no magic". It's best to check right after the call and return undef
7527immediately on error, just like DBI would and just like the example
7528above.
7529
7530If your method needs to record an error it should call the set_err()
7531method with the error code and error string, as shown in the example
7532above. The error code and error string will be recorded in the
7533handle and available via C<$h-E<gt>err> and C<$DBI::errstr> etc.
7534The set_err() method always returns an undef or empty list as
7535appropriate. Since your method should nearly always return an undef
7536or empty list as soon as an error is detected it's handy to simply
7537return what set_err() returns, as shown in the example above.
7538
7539If the handle has C<RaiseError>, C<PrintError>, or C<HandleError>
7540etc. set then the set_err() method will honour them. This means
7541that if C<RaiseError> is set then set_err() won't return in the
7542normal way but will 'throw an exception' that can be caught with
7543an C<eval> block.
7544
7545You can stash private data into DBI handles
7546via C<$h-E<gt>{private_..._*}>. See the entry under L</ATTRIBUTES
7547COMMON TO ALL HANDLES> for info and important caveats.
7548
7549
7550=head1 TRACING
7551
7552The DBI has a powerful tracing mechanism built in. It enables you
7553to see what's going on 'behind the scenes', both within the DBI and
7554the drivers you're using.
7555
7556=head2 Trace Settings
7557
7558Which details are written to the trace output is controlled by a
7559combination of a I<trace level>, an integer from 0 to 15, and a set
7560of I<trace flags> that are either on or off. Together these are known
7561as the I<trace settings> and are stored together in a single integer.
7562For normal use you only need to set the trace level, and generally
7563only to a value between 1 and 4.
7564
7565Each handle has it's own trace settings, and so does the DBI.
7566When you call a method the DBI merges the handles settings into its
7567own for the duration of the call: the trace flags of the handle are
7568OR'd into the trace flags of the DBI, and if the handle has a higher
7569trace level then the DBI trace level is raised to match it.
7570The previous DBI trace settings are restored when the called method
7571returns.
7572
7573=head2 Trace Levels
7574
7575Trace I<levels> are as follows:
7576
7577 0 - Trace disabled.
7578 1 - Trace top-level DBI method calls returning with results or errors.
7579 2 - As above, adding tracing of top-level method entry with parameters.
7580 3 - As above, adding some high-level information from the driver
7581 and some internal information from the DBI.
7582 4 - As above, adding more detailed information from the driver.
7583 This is the first level to trace all the rows being fetched.
7584 5 to 15 - As above but with more and more internal information.
7585
7586Trace level 1 is best for a simple overview of what's happening.
7587Trace levels 2 thru 4 a good choice for general purpose tracing.
7588Levels 5 and above are best reserved for investigating a specific
7589problem, when you need to see "inside" the driver and DBI.
7590
7591The trace output is detailed and typically very useful. Much of the
7592trace output is formatted using the L</neat> function, so strings
7593in the trace output may be edited and truncated by that function.
7594
7595=head2 Trace Flags
7596
7597Trace I<flags> are used to enable tracing of specific activities
7598within the DBI and drivers. The DBI defines some trace flags and
7599drivers can define others. DBI trace flag names begin with a capital
7600letter and driver specific names begin with a lowercase letter, as
7601usual.
7602
7603Currently the DBI only defines two trace flags:
7604
7605 ALL - turn on all DBI and driver flags (not recommended)
7606 SQL - trace SQL statements executed
7607 (not yet implemented in DBI but implemented in some DBDs)
7608
7609The L</parse_trace_flags> and L</parse_trace_flag> methods are used
7610to convert trace flag names into the corresponding integer bit flags.
7611
7612=head2 Enabling Trace
7613
7614The C<$h-E<gt>trace> method sets the trace settings for a handle
7615and C<DBI-E<gt>trace> does the same for the DBI.
7616
7617In addition to the L</trace> method, you can enable the same trace
7618information, and direct the output to a file, by setting the
7619C<DBI_TRACE> environment variable before starting Perl.
7620See L</DBI_TRACE> for more information.
7621
7622Finally, you can set, or get, the trace settings for a handle using
7623the C<TraceLevel> attribute.
7624
7625All of those methods use parse_trace_flags() and so allow you set
7626both the trace level and multiple trace flags by using a string
7627containing the trace level and/or flag names separated by vertical
7628bar ("C<|>") or comma ("C<,>") characters. For example:
7629
7630 local $h->{TraceLevel} = "3|SQL|foo";
7631
7632=head2 Trace Output
7633
7634Initially trace output is written to C<STDERR>. Both the
7635C<$h-E<gt>trace> and C<DBI-E<gt>trace> methods take an optional
7636$trace_file parameter, which may be either the name of a file to be
7637opened by DBI in append mode, or a reference to an existing writable
7638(possibly layered) filehandle. If $trace_file is a filename,
7639and can be opened in append mode, or $trace_file is a writable
7640filehandle, then I<all> trace output (currently including that from
7641other handles) is redirected to that file. A warning is generated
7642if $trace_file can't be opened or is not writable.
7643
7644Further calls to trace() without $trace_file do not alter where
7645the trace output is sent. If $trace_file is undefined, then
7646trace output is sent to C<STDERR> and, if the prior trace was opened with
7647$trace_file as a filename, the previous trace file is closed; if $trace_file was
7648a filehandle, the filehandle is B<not> closed.
7649
7650B<NOTE>: If $trace_file is specified as a filehandle, the filehandle
7651should not be closed until all DBI operations are completed, or the
7652application has reset the trace file via another call to
7653C<trace()> that changes the trace file.
7654
7655=head2 Tracing to Layered Filehandles
7656
7657B<NOTE>:
7658
7659=over 4
7660
7661=item *
7662Tied filehandles are not currently supported, as
7663tie operations are not available to the PerlIO
7664methods used by the DBI.
7665
7666=item *
7667PerlIO layer support requires Perl version 5.8 or higher.
7668
7669=back
7670
7671As of version 5.8, Perl provides the ability to layer various
7672"disciplines" on an open filehandle via the L<PerlIO> module.
7673
7674A simple example of using PerlIO layers is to use a scalar as the output:
7675
7676 my $scalar = '';
7677 open( my $fh, "+>:scalar", \$scalar );
7678 $dbh->trace( 2, $fh );
7679
7680Now all trace output is simply appended to $scalar.
7681
7682A more complex application of tracing to a layered filehandle is the
7683use of a custom layer (I<Refer to >L<Perlio::via> I<for details
7684on creating custom PerlIO layers.>). Consider an application with the
7685following logger module:
7686
7687 package MyFancyLogger;
7688
7689 sub new
7690 {
7691 my $self = {};
7692 my $fh;
7693 open $fh, '>', 'fancylog.log';
7694 $self->{_fh} = $fh;
7695 $self->{_buf} = '';
7696 return bless $self, shift;
7697 }
7698
7699 sub log
7700 {
7701 my $self = shift;
7702 return unless exists $self->{_fh};
7703 my $fh = $self->{_fh};
7704 $self->{_buf} .= shift;
7705 #
7706 # DBI feeds us pieces at a time, so accumulate a complete line
7707 # before outputing
7708 #
7709 print $fh "At ", scalar localtime(), ':', $self->{_buf}, "\n" and
7710 $self->{_buf} = ''
7711 if $self->{_buf}=~tr/\n//;
7712 }
7713
7714 sub close {
7715 my $self = shift;
7716 return unless exists $self->{_fh};
7717 my $fh = $self->{_fh};
7718 print $fh "At ", scalar localtime(), ':', $self->{_buf}, "\n" and
7719 $self->{_buf} = ''
7720 if $self->{_buf};
7721 close $fh;
7722 delete $self->{_fh};
7723 }
7724
7725 1;
7726
7727To redirect DBI traces to this logger requires creating
7728a package for the layer:
7729
7730 package PerlIO::via::MyFancyLogLayer;
7731
7732 sub PUSHED
7733 {
7734 my ($class,$mode,$fh) = @_;
7735 my $logger;
7736 return bless \$logger,$class;
7737 }
7738
7739 sub OPEN {
7740 my ($self, $path, $mode, $fh) = @_;
7741 #
7742 # $path is actually our logger object
7743 #
7744 $$self = $path;
7745 return 1;
7746 }
7747
7748 sub WRITE
7749 {
7750 my ($self, $buf, $fh) = @_;
7751 $$self->log($buf);
7752 return length($buf);
7753 }
7754
7755 sub CLOSE {
7756 my $self = shift;
7757 $$self->close();
7758 return 0;
7759 }
7760
7761 1;
7762
7763
7764The application can then cause DBI traces to be routed to the
7765logger using
7766
7767 use PerlIO::via::MyFancyLogLayer;
7768
7769 open my $fh, '>:via(MyFancyLogLayer)', MyFancyLogger->new();
7770
7771 $dbh->trace('SQL', $fh);
7772
7773Now all trace output will be processed by MyFancyLogger's
7774log() method.
7775
7776=head2 Trace Content
7777
7778Many of the values embedded in trace output are formatted using the neat()
7779utility function. This means they may be quoted, sanitized, and possibly
7780truncated if longer than C<$DBI::neat_maxlen>. See L</neat> for more details.
7781
7782=head2 Tracing Tips
7783
7784You can add tracing to your own application code using the L</trace_msg> method.
7785
7786It can sometimes be handy to compare trace files from two different runs of the
7787same script. However using a tool like C<diff> on the original log output
7788doesn't work well because the trace file is full of object addresses that may
7789differ on each run.
7790
7791The DBI includes a handy utility called dbilogstrip that can be used to
7792'normalize' the log content. It can be used as a filter like this:
7793
7794 DBI_TRACE=2 perl yourscript.pl ...args1... 2>&1 | dbilogstrip > dbitrace1.log
7795 DBI_TRACE=2 perl yourscript.pl ...args2... 2>&1 | dbilogstrip > dbitrace2.log
7796 diff -u dbitrace1.log dbitrace2.log
7797
7798See L<dbilogstrip> for more information.
7799
7800=head1 DBI ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES
7801
7802The DBI module recognizes a number of environment variables, but most of
7803them should not be used most of the time.
7804It is better to be explicit about what you are doing to avoid the need
7805for environment variables, especially in a web serving system where web
7806servers are stingy about which environment variables are available.
7807
7808=head2 DBI_DSN
7809
7810The DBI_DSN environment variable is used by DBI->connect if you do not
7811specify a data source when you issue the connect.
7812It should have a format such as "dbi:Driver:databasename".
7813
7814=head2 DBI_DRIVER
7815
7816The DBI_DRIVER environment variable is used to fill in the database
7817driver name in DBI->connect if the data source string starts "dbi::"
7818(thereby omitting the driver).
7819If DBI_DSN omits the driver name, DBI_DRIVER can fill the gap.
7820
7821=head2 DBI_AUTOPROXY
7822
7823The DBI_AUTOPROXY environment variable takes a string value that starts
7824"dbi:Proxy:" and is typically followed by "hostname=...;port=...".
7825It is used to alter the behaviour of DBI->connect.
7826For full details, see DBI::Proxy documentation.
7827
7828=head2 DBI_USER
7829
7830The DBI_USER environment variable takes a string value that is used as
7831the user name if the DBI->connect call is given undef (as distinct from
7832an empty string) as the username argument.
7833Be wary of the security implications of using this.
7834
7835=head2 DBI_PASS
7836
7837The DBI_PASS environment variable takes a string value that is used as
7838the password if the DBI->connect call is given undef (as distinct from
7839an empty string) as the password argument.
7840Be extra wary of the security implications of using this.
7841
7842=head2 DBI_DBNAME (obsolete)
7843
7844The DBI_DBNAME environment variable takes a string value that is used only when the
7845obsolescent style of DBI->connect (with driver name as fourth parameter) is used, and
7846when no value is provided for the first (database name) argument.
7847
7848=head2 DBI_TRACE
7849
7850The DBI_TRACE environment variable specifies the global default
7851trace settings for the DBI at startup. Can also be used to direct
7852trace output to a file. When the DBI is loaded it does:
7853
7854 DBI->trace(split /=/, $ENV{DBI_TRACE}, 2) if $ENV{DBI_TRACE};
7855
7856So if C<DBI_TRACE> contains an "C<=>" character then what follows
7857it is used as the name of the file to append the trace to.
7858
7859output appended to that file. If the name begins with a number
7860followed by an equal sign (C<=>), then the number and the equal sign are
7861stripped off from the name, and the number is used to set the trace
7862level. For example:
7863
7864 DBI_TRACE=1=dbitrace.log perl your_test_script.pl
7865
7866On Unix-like systems using a Bourne-like shell, you can do this easily
7867on the command line:
7868
7869 DBI_TRACE=2 perl your_test_script.pl
7870
7871See L</TRACING> for more information.
7872
7873=head2 PERL_DBI_DEBUG (obsolete)
7874
7875An old variable that should no longer be used; equivalent to DBI_TRACE.
7876
7877=head2 DBI_PROFILE
7878
7879The DBI_PROFILE environment variable can be used to enable profiling
7880of DBI method calls. See L<DBI::Profile> for more information.
7881
7882=head2 DBI_PUREPERL
7883
7884The DBI_PUREPERL environment variable can be used to enable the
7885use of DBI::PurePerl. See L<DBI::PurePerl> for more information.
7886
7887=head1 WARNING AND ERROR MESSAGES
7888
7889=head2 Fatal Errors
7890
7891=over 4
7892
7893=item Can't call method "prepare" without a package or object reference
7894
7895The C<$dbh> handle you're using to call C<prepare> is probably undefined because
7896the preceding C<connect> failed. You should always check the return status of
7897DBI methods, or use the L</RaiseError> attribute.
7898
7899=item Can't call method "execute" without a package or object reference
7900
7901The C<$sth> handle you're using to call C<execute> is probably undefined because
7902the preceding C<prepare> failed. You should always check the return status of
7903DBI methods, or use the L</RaiseError> attribute.
7904
7905=item DBI/DBD internal version mismatch
7906
7907The DBD driver module was built with a different version of DBI than
7908the one currently being used. You should rebuild the DBD module under
7909the current version of DBI.
7910
7911(Some rare platforms require "static linking". On those platforms, there
7912may be an old DBI or DBD driver version actually embedded in the Perl
7913executable being used.)
7914
7915=item DBD driver has not implemented the AutoCommit attribute
7916
7917The DBD driver implementation is incomplete. Consult the author.
7918
7919=item Can't [sg]et %s->{%s}: unrecognised attribute
7920
7921You attempted to set or get an unknown attribute of a handle. Make
7922sure you have spelled the attribute name correctly; case is significant
7923(e.g., "Autocommit" is not the same as "AutoCommit").
7924
7925=back
7926
7927=head1 Pure-Perl DBI
7928
7929A pure-perl emulation of the DBI is included in the distribution
7930for people using pure-perl drivers who, for whatever reason, can't
7931install the compiled DBI. See L<DBI::PurePerl>.
7932
7933=head1 SEE ALSO
7934
7935=head2 Driver and Database Documentation
7936
7937Refer to the documentation for the DBD driver that you are using.
7938
7939Refer to the SQL Language Reference Manual for the database engine that you are using.
7940
7941=head2 ODBC and SQL/CLI Standards Reference Information
7942
7943More detailed information about the semantics of certain DBI methods
7944that are based on ODBC and SQL/CLI standards is available on-line
7945via microsoft.com, for ODBC, and www.jtc1sc32.org for the SQL/CLI
7946standard:
7947
7948 DBI method ODBC function SQL/CLI Working Draft
7949 ---------- ------------- ---------------------
7950 column_info SQLColumns Page 124
7951 foreign_key_info SQLForeignKeys Page 163
7952 get_info SQLGetInfo Page 214
7953 primary_key_info SQLPrimaryKeys Page 254
7954 table_info SQLTables Page 294
7955 type_info SQLGetTypeInfo Page 239
7956 statistics_info SQLStatistics
7957
7958To find documentation on the ODBC function you can use
7959the MSDN search facility at:
7960
7961 http://msdn.microsoft.com/Search
7962
7963and search for something like C<"SQLColumns returns">.
7964
7965And for SQL/CLI standard information on SQLColumns you'd read page 124 of
7966the (very large) SQL/CLI Working Draft available from:
7967
7968 http://jtc1sc32.org/doc/N0701-0750/32N0744T.pdf
7969
7970=head2 Standards Reference Information
7971
7972A hyperlinked, browsable version of the BNF syntax for SQL92 (plus
7973Oracle 7 SQL and PL/SQL) is available here:
7974
7975 http://cui.unige.ch/db-research/Enseignement/analyseinfo/SQL92/BNFindex.html
7976
7977A BNF syntax for SQL3 is available here:
7978
7979 http://www.sqlstandards.org/SC32/WG3/Progression_Documents/Informal_working_drafts/iso-9075-2-1999.bnf
7980
7981The following links provide further useful information about SQL.
7982Some of these are rather dated now but may still be useful.
7983
7984 http://www.jcc.com/SQLPages/jccs_sql.htm
7985 http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~shadow/sql.html
7986 http://www.altavista.com/query?q=sql+tutorial
7987
7988

7994Programming Perl 3rd Ed. by Larry Wall, Tom Christiansen & Jon Orwant.
7995L<http://books.perl.org/book/134>
7996
7997Learning Perl by Randal Schwartz.
7998L<http://books.perl.org/book/101>
7999
8000Details of many other books related to perl can be found at L<http://books.perl.org>

8003
8004Index of DBI related modules available from CPAN:
8005

8007 http://search.cpan.org/search?mode=doc&query=DBI
8008
8009For a good comparison of RDBMS-OO mappers and some OO-RDBMS mappers
8010(including Class::DBI, Alzabo, and DBIx::RecordSet in the former
8011category and Tangram and SPOPS in the latter) see the Perl
8012Object-Oriented Persistence project pages at:
8013
8014 http://poop.sourceforge.net
8015
8016A similar page for Java toolkits can be found at:
8017
8018 http://c2.com/cgi-bin/wiki?ObjectRelationalToolComparison

8020=head2 Mailing List
8021
8022The I<dbi-users> mailing list is the primary means of communication among
8023users of the DBI and its related modules. For details send email to:
8024
8025 dbi-users-help@perl.org
8026
8027There are typically between 700 and 900 messages per month. You have
8028to subscribe in order to be able to post. However you can opt for a
8029'post-only' subscription.
8030
8031Mailing list archives (of variable quality) are held at:
8032
8033 http://groups.google.com/groups?group=perl.dbi.users
8034 http://www.xray.mpe.mpg.de/mailing-lists/dbi/
8035 http://www.mail-archive.com/dbi-users%40perl.org/
8036

8112=head2 Sponsor Enhancements
8113

8115
8116If your company would benefit from a specific new DBI feature,
8117please consider sponsoring its development. Work is performed
8118rapidly, and usually on a fixed-price payment-on-delivery basis.
8119Contact me for details.
8120
8121Using such targeted financing allows you to contribute to DBI
8122development, and rapidly get something specific and valuable in return.

8127people I have worked with on the DBI project, especially in the early
8128years (1992-1994). In no particular order: Kevin Stock, Buzz Moschetti,
8129Kurt Andersen, Ted Lemon, William Hails, Garth Kennedy, Michael Peppler,
8130Neil S. Briscoe, Jeff Urlwin, David J. Hughes, Jeff Stander,
8131Forrest D Whitcher, Larry Wall, Jeff Fried, Roy Johnson, Paul Hudson,
8132Georg Rehfeld, Steve Sizemore, Ron Pool, Jon Meek, Tom Christiansen,
8133Steve Baumgarten, Randal Schwartz, and a whole lot more.
8134
8135Then, of course, there are the poor souls who have struggled through
8136untold and undocumented obstacles to actually implement DBI drivers.
8137Among their ranks are Jochen Wiedmann, Alligator Descartes, Jonathan
8138Leffler, Jeff Urlwin, Michael Peppler, Henrik Tougaard, Edwin Pratomo,
8139Davide Migliavacca, Jan Pazdziora, Peter Haworth, Edmund Mergl, Steve
8140Williams, Thomas Lowery, and Phlip Plumlee. Without them, the DBI would
8141not be the practical reality it is today. I'm also especially grateful
8142to Alligator Descartes for starting work on the first edition of the
8143"Programming the Perl DBI" book and letting me jump on board.
8144
8145The DBI and DBD::Oracle were originally developed while I was Technical
8146Director (CTO) of Ingeneering in the UK (L<http://www.ig.co.uk>) (formerly known as the
8147Paul Ingram Group). So I'd especially like to thank Paul for his generosity
8148and vision in supporting this work for many years.
8149
8150A couple of specific DBI features have been sponsored by enlightened companies:
8151
8152The development of the swap_inner_handle() method was sponsored by BizRate.com (L<http://BizRate.com>)
8153
8154The development of DBD::Gofer and related modules was sponsored by
8155Shopzilla.com (L<http://Shopzilla.com>), where I currently work.
8156
8157
8158=head1 CONTRIBUTING
8159
8160As you can see above, many people have contributed to the DBI and
8161drivers in many ways over many years.
8162
8163If you'd like to help then see L<http://dbi.perl.org/contributing>
8164and L<http://search.cpan.org/~timb/DBI/Roadmap.pod>
8165
8166If you'd like the DBI to do something new or different then a good way
8167to make that happen is to do it yourself and send me a patch to the
8168source code that shows the changes. (But read "Speak before you patch"
8169below.)
8170
8171=head2 Browsing the source code repository
8172
8173Use http://svn.perl.org/modules/dbi/trunk (basic)
8174or http://svn.perl.org/viewcvs/modules/ (more useful)
8175
8176=head2 How to create a patch using Subversion
8177
8178The DBI source code is maintained using Subversion (a replacement
8179for CVS, see L<http://subversion.tigris.org/>). To access the source
8180you'll need to install a Subversion client. Then, to get the source
8181code, do:
8182
8183 svn checkout http://svn.perl.org/modules/dbi/trunk
8184
8185If it prompts for a username and password use your perl.org account
8186if you have one, else just 'guest' and 'guest'. The source code will
8187be in a new subdirectory called C<trunk>.
8188
8189To keep informed about changes to the source you can send an empty email
8190to svn-commit-modules-dbi-subscribe@perl.org after which you'll get an email
8191with the change log message and diff of each change checked-in to the source.
8192
8193After making your changes you can generate a patch file, but before
8194you do, make sure your source is still up to date using:
8195
8196 svn update
8197
8198If you get any conflicts reported you'll need to fix them first.
8199Then generate the patch file from within the C<trunk> directory using:
8200
8201 svn diff > foo.patch
8202
8203Read the patch file, as a sanity check, and then email it to dbi-dev@perl.org.
8204
8205=head2 How to create a patch without Subversion
8206
8207Unpack a fresh copy of the distribution:
8208
8209 tar xfz DBI-1.40.tar.gz
8210
8211Rename the newly created top level directory:
8212
8213 mv DBI-1.40 DBI-1.40.your_foo
8214
8215Edit the contents of DBI-1.40.your_foo/* till it does what you want.
8216
8217Test your changes and then remove all temporary files:
8218
8219 make test && make distclean
8220
8221Go back to the directory you originally unpacked the distribution:
8222
8223 cd ..
8224
8225Unpack I<another> copy of the original distribution you started with:
8226
8227 tar xfz DBI-1.40.tar.gz
8228
8229Then create a patch file by performing a recursive C<diff> on the two
8230top level directories:
8231
8232 diff -r -u DBI-1.40 DBI-1.40.your_foo > DBI-1.40.your_foo.patch
8233
8234=head2 Speak before you patch
8235
8236For anything non-trivial or possibly controversial it's a good idea
8237to discuss (on dbi-dev@perl.org) the changes you propose before
8238actually spending time working on them. Otherwise you run the risk
8239of them being rejected because they don't fit into some larger plans
8240you may not be aware of.
8241

8265=head1 OTHER RELATED WORK AND PERL MODULES
8266
8267=over 4
8268
8269=item Apache::DBI by E.Mergl@bawue.de
8270
8271To be used with the Apache daemon together with an embedded Perl
8272interpreter like C<mod_perl>. Establishes a database connection which
8273remains open for the lifetime of the HTTP daemon. This way the CGI
8274connect and disconnect for every database access becomes superfluous.
8275
8276=item SQL Parser
8277
8278See also the L<SQL::Statement> module, SQL parser and engine.
8279
8280=back
8281
8282=cut

Report produced by the NYTProf 4.06 Perl profiler, developed by Tim Bunce and Adam Kaplan.
